description:
A really wonderful, classic Persian restaurant in the heart of North Beach. The service is quick and efficient, and the food is quite tasty. I had the joojeh and my partner had the chelo kabob koobideh. We both thoroughly enjoyed our food. 

The portions are quite large, so we each have enough for leftover lunch tomorrow! Note that parking can be a little tricky in this area, so I'd recommend taking an Uber.
author: Layla M.

description:
Worst Persian food I've ever had - not sure this place can call what they serve as Persian since they can't even make a decent kabob! Ridiculously overpriced, gross bathrooms, haphazard service. 

My table mates and I all hated the food we were served and we each ordered something different. My kabob was the least bad of everything we ordered. The bench seating was hard as rock, I couldn't sit on it, the chairs were not any more comfortable. 

This is a sad excuse for a restaurant in any city, much less SF, where there is so much competition between the many restaurants. Just a horrible, dilapidated restaurant that needs to be torn down and start everything over from scratch - including the menu.
author: Mahsa T.

description:
Went here on Saturday night this past weekend. Wonderful spot amid all the touristy places in North Beach. The atmosphere is first class, the service is too. And, for me, (as I am not an expert on Persian Cuisine) the food was delicious! 

Yet, keep in mind fellow Persian food fans, Maykadeh is pricey! 

I was hesitant to go in because it was only me and no one else. Persian food is something to be shared and so it is best having it with family and friends. Yet, I was so hungry and I had a few hours before I was to meet up with friends at Davies for the SF Symphony performance. 

To be honest, I had intended to eat very inexpensive. My aim was Golden Boy Pizza, which is nearby. But the line was all the way around the block. 

Most of the eateries in and around North Beach are expensive and they are for tourists. I am a local and did not want to get caught up in that. I figured if I am going to spend even a little bit of money, I might as well spend it on a place that is local and truly established. And, somewhere I could sit and enjoy my meal, not have to stand. I also wanted to be somewhere that was going out to a special place. But at the same time was a bit like home. 

Maykakeh has been in North Beach for years and it is one of the spots Persians and Persian-Americans go to have dinner and be with family. Whenever I go into North Beach I am often stuck with a bit of sadness because all of the family style Italian-American restaurants I remember as a little kid are gone. Caesar's, New Pizza, Capps Corner, the places I remember as family-style, they are all gone. All from another era. 

I watched as various groups arrived at Maykadeh; some dressed up and others more causal. 

Bits of Farsi could be heard amid the conversations and as one elegantly dressed older couple drove up. They asked the parking attendant outside the door to park their car. I watched them and I wondered, "are these expatriates? Would these be some of the people who escaped the turmoil that emerged in Iran in the late 1970s?" 

They looked distinguished, so glamorous, finely dressed. Persians are unique in their standards of dress and hospitality, compared to us Americans. For them it is important to always make guests feel like they are welcomed and honored. And, to dress up is a sign of respect as well as celebration.

Even most of the causally dressed people had at least one or two pieces of clothing that were stylish and chic. In a way, their gathering reminded me of those old Italian-American restaurants I recall. It was when families gathered for a Sunday dinner.

The aroma of the saffron rice and the roasted lamb was alluring, if not beckoning. 

Fortunately, the parking attendant was very persistent that I go in anyway and that yes, there is room for someone to dine alone. I sat at the little bar which is near the front door. Good thing I did because staff was making a "Persian Martini." It looked scrumptious. 

Still, mindful that I would be going off to the Symphony later on, I figured I best stay with a reliable standard, a glass of Syrah. 

I had the kabob appetizer. Wow! The staff was so gracious they provided me with fresh baked bread,warm right out of the oven.  And, they gave me fresh a green salad with basil to go with my lamb/beef kabob. On the plate was also a fresh stewed tomato and onions. Oh so delicious! 

I should have ordered some rice to go with it, so to soak up the gravy on the plate. 

I had been to Maykedeh once before and enjoyed it. I had forgotten that it is a hub of happy gatherings and savory meals.

I have been a Persian food fan for some time. Yes, even long before Anthony Bourdain's show (God Bless him, may his soul be at peace). 

Some years back, my nephew was dating a Persian-American girl from Sunnyvale. She introduced us to Persian food and all the Persian restaurants in the City. Albourz, Maykekeh and Lavash out in the Sunset, she took us to them all. We (my family and I, were instantly won over and have been fans ever since). 

Persian food is a delight for the senses and a taste sensation like no other. Well, yeah, there's Indian and Thai food. But Persian is made with that something special that sets it apart from all others. 

Anyway, back to my visit on Saturday night. I concluded my meal with Persian style Baklava and some Persian tea. Oh, so scrumptious! I wanted more. 

Service was excellent as everyone there aims to please. Yes, I will go back. I have to go back to try that "Persian Martini." But I will make sure I bring friends and family too. It is much more fun that way to share a meal so wonderful.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
My 2 Persian sisters and I visited on a recent Friday evening. We had reservations, but the place wasn't completely full at 7 PM.

The ambiance is nice, with roses at each table. The tables are not too close together, and we could hear each other speak quite easily.

We decided to share a few things and ordered the fancy salad to start, and the koobideh kebab and fesenjun with chicken as our mains. We also asked for tadigh, but they did not bring any. :(

They bring out warm bread to start, with a plate of butter, onion and sabzi.  Don't be shy, they'll bring out more if you finish!

The fancy salad was great. I loved the poached pears and it was a great start to the meal.

No complaints on our mains either. The koobideh was juicy and flavorful, and the fesenjun sauce was thick like a gravy, just how I like it. Both plates were served with generous portions of soft, buttery rice.

After we received our meals, my sister asked for a side of yogurt and the waitress brought out a huge dish of it. We were also charged $7 for this, so just beware.

Finally, we ordered the fallodeh for dessert. My sister chose this one, and I wasn't particularly looking forward to it. I wanted the bastani. Anyway, it was fine but it didn't quite hit the spot for me--- we ended up at baked bear later.

Overall, a very nice dining experience. It's a little on the pricey side for entrees, but if you go with a group and split some things, it may be more economical.
author: Roya B.

description: Delicious chelo-kebab koobideh. Order the feta cheese to eat with the bread, mint and radish. Try the Persian martini, it's amazing!
author: Angela H.

description:
For authentic Persian food from the perspective of a Persian gal, Maykadeh is heavy on pricing and not so heavy on portions or flavor. 
 
Although I thoroughly enjoyed my meal, it lacked the Persian flavors I expected and hoped for to brag about to the people I brought here that had never had Iranian food before. Their chicken kabobs were rather small, and resembled kabobs of simple Mediterranean food restaurants, so no bold Persian spices and tastes stood out to me. Also, their stews (we tried both Fesenjan and Ghormeh Sabzi) were decent, but rather watery. I do know this place is infamous for their lamb tongue/brain, so perhaps if you're brave enough for that, it is the only time I'd suggest making the trip in SF traffic with the not so plentiful parking to Maykadeh. 

I am forever grateful for the endless pita bread though....
author: Sayeh Z.

description:
I thought the foos was pretty great and it didn't take much time to get ready. We ordered shamshiri and Koubide. Both were good, not dry like in some of places. The staff were very nice and friendly. I only disliked the sitting and having a mirror behind the tables and felt a bit uncomfortable. Maybe some pillows would have made it better. 
I would definitely go back there though for the food.
author: Nioosha T.

description: I ordered the chicken koobideh and the chicken kabob though grubhub. The chicken koobideh did not taste like chicken at all. It was so bad that I threw it away after one bite. The chicken kabob was okay but it was nothing special either. For the money, they charge they could at least make quality, good tasting food. After working 12 hours, I wanted to to have a good dinner, I was disappointed at the quality and taste of the food. I will not come or order food from them again.
author: Mina L.

description: I can here because I really missed Lavash (i swear it had the best Persian cuisine in SF) and was pleasantly surprised. It's a little pricier than Lavash but the quality of food it still great. The meats were so tender and I got this goat cheese appetizer dip thing that was amazing. The restaurant atmosphere is good for dates too.
author: Amanda F.

description:
The best Persian Restourant in Bay Area.

High quality. Perfect customer service. Perfect ambiance. 
I always order Barg. It is perfect. All dishes are perfect, Kashke bademjan is my favorite as well. I am persian, I know persian food. We invited our American or European friends to Meykadeh, they all love the place and the food.
We go to Maykadeh at Least twice a month.

Highly recommended.
author: Hani G.

description:
Vow!!
Are you kidding me!
After two hours of Sunday workout and watching the World Cup decided to visit San Francisco and have some Persian food at Maykadeh restaurant.
Ordered koubideh and chicken breast and tahdig ghormeh sabzi for appetizer. It was all great however for the last 6 hours that I have been burping up and feeling sick in my stomach.Don't be fooled by good reviews since the quality of food is just not there anymore.This place is also too expensive . I don't mind the high price meal but at least deliver the quality.I love Persian food but NOT at this level of quality.
Sasha please look into this or reviews will hurt your business.
author: christine k.

description:
Accessibility (Parking / Wait Time)

0/1 Star: parking is horrible 

_____

Service (Waiter / Cleanness / Ambiance)

1/1 Star: service was great 

_____

Taste (0=Not Edible / 1=Edible / 2=Good (average) / 3=Must Try!)

2/3 Stars: the beef/lamb, chicken, and salmon were are pretty good. I also really enjoyed their ice cream. 

_____

Overall Experience

3/5 Stars 

_____

Last Words
The food was good and worth a try if you haven't had much Persian food.
author: Elliott N.

description:
Awesome food and lovely places also its only place you can have really delicious Persian food.

Friendly service, open daily, great for families.
author: O E.

description:
The Maykadeh restaurant is not a very big restaurant. 
Does have valet on weekends.
The tongue stew is phenomenon.
The price are quite bit high, but the quality of foods , even wines Are highly up.
The servers are chill and easy going.
If you like to try meykadeh,please try tongue stew as your appetizer.
Most recommended for travelers and SF residents.
author: Atosa T.

description:
Food - 3.5 stars
Price - $$$$tar$
Ambiance - 4 stars 
Service - 3 stars 

I ordered a kebob combo plate, Koobideh & Joojeh, and also the Ghorme Sabzee.  
Portion size is so so depends on what your comparing.  Other Persian restaurants portions and some flavors are more in my opinion.  This place is still pretty good.  The biggest downfall to me is the Price, very pricey.  

Kebobs were flavorful and delicious, chicken was tender some had better flavor than others, and I always enjoy these.  They are my go to.  Rice was cooked nice.

Ghorme Sabzee was light on the flavor, portion was good, and meat was tender.  Flavor is what stand out on the pallet, and that was lacking in this dish.  

I enjoy eating Persian food, I only come here when friends or clients request.  The price is just a bit high for what you get.
author: Jason M.

description: I decided to take my fiancé here on his birthday and he ended up loving this place. For the appetizer,  I ordered the banjaan borani(eggplant) and Greek salad and OMG it was delicious. For the entree, my fiancé ordered the Ribeye steak and I ordered the combo mignon and shami kabob. The meat was juicy and filled with so much flavor that I wanted more. The service is great here and it's a very elegant place to enjoy high quality food. I loved the fact they had valet parking which made my life so much easier. I'll def be back here again soon!
author: Neloffer E.

description:
came here with a large group, first of all staff seems to be very clueless when it comes to drinks, one of our groupmates ordered a manhattan with a glass of Pellegrino on the side, but they came back (after a long time) with a manhattan diluted with Pellegrino (huh....?!?!?!?!) this was the first time anyone has ever thought it was a possible request form guests when they order a drink. Maybe they should've just clarify with the guest about the order instead? Also the other drinks we ordered (dirty martinis) not only were they out of balance, the olives in the drinks were served with tiny toothpicks and it was impossible to reach them as they sinked to the bottom of the glass.

The food was delicious, we had the brain, assortment of apps (eggplant dips, crispy rice with lambs, etc) and followed by the kabob filet mignon, chicken, and ground lamb. meat was really delicious though cooking was uneven as some filet was cooked to well done and some at medium and some at medium rare. this was simply execution mistake as those steak meats were uneven in size, and of course when you grill them they will end up cooking unevenly. 

Dessert was interesting, we had the ice cream mixed with rice noodles, cheery syrup, and lime juice. the texture was interesting and the sweetness was just right so it's not too heavy. nice way to end the dinner.
author: Joyce C.

description: Discovered this place a few years ago with a friend and have been back several times. Food is typical Persian dishes, but good quality over all. A bit on the higher end so make sure you bring your cc. Peking is horrible,  so best get a ride or have valet park your car.
author: Raquel V.

description: The food is always consistent and absolutely delicious.  The ghormeh Sabzi is the best ever (don't tell my mom)!  So is all their kabobs (especially their spicy chicken).  The only place I be brave enough to try the brain- ever!   The prices are more than most are used to pay for Iranian food, especially if you lived in LA and got three times the portions for half the price.  However, an area of improvement is their delivery.  They are consistently late.  For example, if they say it will taken45-60 minutes, plan on 2hours, at least.  Also, I suggest you checking your order, as they will routinely forget a dish you ordered or give you the receipt for someone else's order.  But I go back because the food is worth it when I want Iranian food.
author: Rose S.

description:
In early December, I was planning on taking my girlfriend to Lavash on a Monday and to our ignorance, Lavash was closed. So I scrambled and improvised until I found Maykadeh! With stellar reviews and a solid reputation, we called our Uber to get here.

When we walked in, I was a little nervous to see it so empty around 645 PM. But then again, it was a Monday. We were immediately sat at a table by the entrance. The interior is beautifully decorated with a fresh red rose on each table.

Now let's get to the important part - the food! Oh my lord, the hummus and Baba Ganoush are impeccable! Such flavor and to be honest, my only mistake was eating too much. For our entrees, we got both a chicken and a lamb kebab and I still dream about that chicken. I know right ? I talked about the chicken over the lamb. Believe me when I say there was so much flavor and moisture captured in the meat that you cannot forget it. Mixed with the rice, pita and hummus, our dinner became unforgettable. 

The only improvement I could see is that my girl friend and I were looking to have a wine paired with our dinner; however, the waitress seemed a little confused. Maybe it's us and we are not suppose to pair wines. Ended up with a nice Chardonnay at her recommendation. 

I look forward to returning one evening! Thank you for a wonderful experience.
author: Tar R.

description: This was my first visit back in more than 20 years. Well before the social media era. I'm glad to have a chance to come back to SF and visit this Persian restaurant again. I can only give a 3 star because of the following: loved the Eggplant "Bademjune" stew with the lamb shank, the beef koobideh was good and tasty but on the dry side, the basmati white rice and the aromatic saffron was better than average, and unfortunately the boneless chicken breast kabob "chunks" were not that tasty at all and this should've been the easiest of the dishes- didn't care for their marination. The sitting, service, and the generous size complimentary pita bread and fresh "sabzi" greens were well above average. And finally the overall prices were way up there, compared to SoCal or other Persian restaurants across the major cities in the U.S.
author: Shawn A.

description: A persian gem in bay area of San Francisco. The most juiciest koobidah kabob! It is a blend of angus beef and lamb. The rice is so delicious with every bite you can smell and taste the saffron. Their portions are huge, two skewers with rice and a grilled tomatoe. Don't forget to keep room for their persian tea and fallodah (persian icecream consists of ices noodles with rose water) - trust me on that!
author: Naser A.

description:
Kind of a difficult review to write. Overall the dinner experience was slightly above average. The Greek salad was good, baba ghanoush was not my favorite, the lamb chops were very tasty, the rice and vegetables on the side were just okay. The green beans and vegetables on the side were not fresh or crisp, kind of soggy and almost had the frozen vegetable look. The rice was overwhelming, given the quantity they give you.

At their price point, I would prefer to dine somewhere else.
author: Michael C.

description: Food is good but the service could be way better. It is a very loud in the restaurant so if you're trying to have a conversation know that you will be yelling over neighboring tables and the music - the acoustics are not great in this place. The food is highly priced for what it is. There are other way better Persian food spots in the Bay with nicer ambience for way less money. My guess is the food is highly priced because of the location. For example, they charged $6 for an extra side of plain rice - and gave way less rice than what other places do for half that price. I won't be coming back.
author: Lily R.

description: Had a Barg kabob and it is absolutely delicious! Believe it or not I've had barg kabob in Tehran's grand bazzar but this is something else! I cannot believe that I had this kabob in USA and I strongly recommend it. To be honest their Koobideh (Ground beef/lamb) is normal but the Barg Kabob is really good. Thanks and I hope you were in Los Angeles so that we could eat that everyday!
author: Steve F.

description: Great food and ambiance. Service was ok. We had lamb shank with eggplant was soo yummyyyy. Thank you guys.
author: Daphne S.

description: Everything I've tried here has been amazing. Dishes are always fresh and very authentic - reminiscent of homemade Persian food I grew up eating. Great hummus, mast o musir is delicious (made just right, which few places can claim). Koobideh is also SO solid and not too strong on lamb flavor for those who are iffy on that. More adventurous but absolutely worth it: Fesenjoon. But what really makes Maykadeh are the people. We live nearby and the owner (?) Sasha comes out to say hi to us, knows my two kids by name, etc. When we see the valet (won't even try spelling his name), my two year old squeals "it's my friend!"
author: RJ B.

description: After a long day in the city, we ambled into this restaurant for dinner, expecting amazing food judging by the previous reviews. We ordered the chicken koobideh and Bagholi Polo, which apparently is a "Sunday special". It's a dill seasoned rice with fava beans and lamb shank. Sounded good... on paper. The meat was falling off the bone, I give them that! But that's where the good part stops. There was absolutely no flavor in the meat and the rice was way too overpowering with Dill. Also for the prices they are charging, man, I expect a little more meat on the lamb shank. The chicken koobideh was a little spiked on salt... come on! All in all, we left disappointed. Will not be returning, sorry!
author: Prav R.

description:
Prices on a lot of items seem a tad spendier than other Persian restuarants that I've been to in the Bay Area such as Shalizaar in Belmont or Negeen in Campbell. And parking is a total pain here (although they do offer valet service).

But I found that I did get higher quality with higher prices, if entrees like the shishlik (rack of lamb chops marinated with basil, garlic, saffron, onion, lime juice; served alongside vegetables and Basmati rice) were any indication. Really deliciously marinated and perfectly grilled stuff. Portions were reasonable given the prices, and smaller dishes like the baba ghanoush (smoked roasted eggplant) and baklava were fairly priced and quite yummy.

Service was also reasonably friendly and professional. Overall, a classy establishment offering fare that's pleasantly just a tad beyond what you'd normally expect here in North Beach.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Birthday of my in Maykadeh restaurant was excellent. Fantastic food with friendly staff, manager, and excellent service.
I definitely recommend this reastaurant
author: Sara N.

description: Had the joojeh kebab it was fantastic. The other plates that my friends had looked great as well so I will definitely recommend this restaurant to others. I've had persian food in the bay area in other places and this one is hands down the best.
author: Harry B.

description: Great Iranian spot! While I was hesitant at first because it seemed too pricey, the portions are huge. I got the ghemyeh and the kasht bademjoon, and they were both great. My only complaint is that the house made doughe was not great, it needed some more salt. Would have loved if they had aub ali carbonated doughe!
author: Shabnam E.

description:
I love this food! I got introduced to this restaurant through Postmates. Unfortunately, they don't seem to offer this restaurant in postmates anymore but I will definitely begin going here from now on. 

Delicious!

----
After writing this original review I went in person and it was even better! Most authentic Iranian/ persian food in the area for sure. Kabob was wonderful, lamb was great. 

Extremely impressed.
author: C S.

description: Poussin was really amazing, the chicken was mind blowing. We also tried Hummus which was okaish. It was a good experience, although towards a bit costlier side.
author: Abhishek J.

description: I love Persian cuisine! Food was delicious, perfectly cooked kabobs, juicy and flavorful. Of course Persian rice is the best and it was great! I'd definitely go back again!
author: Samira A.

description: This is my favorite Persian food place in SF now on, quality food, good portions and friendly staff, a little pricy but it worth it.
author: Jay G.

description:
Food was yummy. Not sure the names of what we ordered but as apps we got something like babaganoush and crispy fried rice with veggie curry and beans. For entrees loved the filet. Chicken thighs weren't my fave. Their homemade baklava was bomb. 

Solid!!
author: Laura D.

description:
My entire meal was absolutely amazing from
Start to finish! One course was more delicious than the next! I would consider this place the GOLD
STANDARD for Persian Restaurants/Cuisine. Although the restaurant was completely packed, the service was excellent, the attention to detail
was perfect, and the food was divine!
author: shaya H.

description:
For the prices you pay here for persian food definitely not worth it. They have one guy who is host and the only waiter (probably the cook in the back too!), took them 20 minutes just to take our orders. Not worth it!!

UPDATE: the food was great so I changed it to 2.5 stars.
author: MJ A.

description:
The service is terrible. I sat down waiting for my friends to arrive and didn't get offered water or a drink order for 15 minutes free having to waive to one of the servers signaling that I needed something. 
I'm Persian so I believe my review on Persian food can be trusted. The Kashk-e-Bademjan is ok at best. The tadig is chewy and extremely greasy. Instead, it should be crunchy and flaky. I asked for it to be topped with Fesenjoon stew sauce and it was totally drenched in sauce. And the sauce was too sweet and tangy. Inedible. I was embarrassed to take my American friends there.
author: melanie s.

description: My family and I love Maykadeh and it's great atmosphere. Every time I am in San Fransisco I make sure to stop by. The lamb tongue is to die for!
author: Megan R.

description:
Best Persian food in San Francisco. In fact, I'm eating take out from there now...

Highly recommend the Chelo-kebab Koobideh (for those who like lamb/beef), Hummus (which comes with pita), Joojeh Kebab (for the chicken lovers), and if you're in house.. the Persian Martini.

5 stars every time; they never disappoint.
author: Cassandra L.

description:
Loved it,the Kababs were so good!We will be back!
Loved their koobideh and kashke bademjoon,and their service was a bit slow but food tasted so good! Worth the wait totally!
Parking is a bit tricky in the area,they have valet parking for 10$ which is good in that area!looking forward to go back with colleagues and family!
author: Khatereh M.

description: Maykadeh is my go-to Persian restaurant in the city. The food is a bit pricey but it's absolutely delicious. Their koobideh is extremely flavorful and I'm obsessed with the rice (it's pretty addicting so be warned). I've ordered takeout from here and when the food arrived, it was still very warm which was a great surprise. I've tried the joojeh but can't seem to remember how it was which makes me think it was just okay. I think the koobideh is the entrée worth trying if you were to try one. Definitely a great spot!
author: Radhika G.

description: We LOVE this place. The food is delicious and the atmosphere is very classy. We have been going here for special occasions since 2002. The Persian food is outstanding - always fresh and delicious.
author: Doug B.

description: As a Persian, I was nervous about eating here after calling to make reservations and hearing an English speaking voice with no accent in the other end of the phone. But the food was just about perfect. Menu featured all the classic Persian fair, and it was all executed wonderfully. The service was relatively prompt and maitre d' (who I believe was the owner) was exceptionally kind and welcoming, not to mention Persian (clearing my fears from the English speaking gentleman I spoke with on the phone). My only complaint was that I didn't like how the Baklava was prepared. Was very soggy and didn't taste much like Baklava.
author: Michael L.

description: Good food but small place and no parking at all. People are nice who works there and the food is fresh. The only problem is the small place and parking problem so you have to take uber to be able to go there. Over all I liked the food and the restaurant. Also good thing of it that they are halal so makes more comfortable for me to eat there
author: Mac P.

description:
Visited this restaurant back in August 2008 for the first time and they are to this date the only Persian restaurant I've been to in SF. Most recent was last week. The service and food is consistent. Friendly staff, warm atmosphere and great service. 

I believe this is the closest experience you can have to an actual Iranian Restaurant, outside Iran.

Started with the usual Feta Cheese, Basil, Reddish and Naan. Can't really go wrong there. (Maybe adding few pieces of walnuts could improve that?)

Kashk-e-Badmjan (eggplant starter) was tasty. could use a little bit more Kashk but that's just a preference thing I guess. And I'm pretty sure you can just ask the staff to bring you more.

We ordered Soltani and Shish Kabob plus a side of Ghorme Sabzi since I was with a non Iranian friend and wanted her to try something other than Kabob dishes. (I personally never order stews at an Iranian restaurant, feels like waste of opportunity not getting more kabobs!)

The Ghorme Sabzi dish was alright IMO, can't complain for $12. But I still prefer my sister's Ghorme Sabzi better!

My favorite was the Barg portion of the Soltani. Shish Kabob was my friend's favorite. All pretty good and left me satisfied for a Persian cuisine experience outside of Iran. (Finished every food obviously!)

The Persian music is a nice touch and I like the ambiance of the whole place. (Not many changes there since my first visit)

Didn't like the Dough. I will probably just stick to water next time. 

Before I left, I over heard another customer ordering Aab Anaar (pomegranate juice). I've had to try it after I saw the actual thing! It was perfect with a touch of salt and Golpar ( Persian Hogweed?)

We finished with some Persian Tea and Baklava.

All and all I'm pretty picky with my Persian restaurants in the US, to the point I rather not even going to a Persian Restaurant since they are mostly too inferior compare to the actual deal. But I would definitely go back to Meykadeh anytime I happen to be in SF and feel a little bit extra Persian.
author: Amir S.

description: Very nice clean place. White table cloths seems like fine dining.  The staff was super friendly and accommodating. Ordered the Koobideh and it was amazing, super tender and juicy the best I've ever had.  Also ordered a lamb shank that was served in a lovely sauce with whole eggplants. The lamb was super tasty and not too lamby.  Dessert was saffron ice cream with pistachios, and flan. Beautiful presentation.  Good spot when in North Beach if you're not in the mood for Italian.
author: Krystal R.

description: Visiting San Francisco from Los Angels where we have the largest Persian population with more than few hundred Persian restaurants. Maykadeh has the best lamb kabob. Highly recommended.
author: Mitra A.

description: Great service and tasty food. Bathroom could've been cleaner and the wine by glass  is overpriced. Would return.
author: Daniel K.

description:
We ordered a large amount of food from Maykadeh for an office lunch, and absolutely LOVED everything! The meat (chicken, beef, lamb) was all great according to my colleagues and was consumed in a matter of minutes. The vegetarian items (grilled veggies, baba ghanoush, torshee, and mast-o-khiar) were also delicious--the show stopper being the kashke bademjan.

Sasha from the restaurant called me with a question regarding the preparation of the dishes, and I really appreciated that. Delivery was ahead of time and everything we ordered was included!

Highly recommend Maykadeh for office events. They did a great job and we couldn't have been happier with the food!
author: Zoe H.

description: This place is awful, please do not waste your time or money. I am persian myself, and could instantly tell the food was absolutely not authentic, no hesitation. Besides the poor quality food, the prices are way beyond outrageous!!  For a $43 soltani I was expecting so much more. The soltani wasn't even decent, it was so off in flavor and quality. If you are going to charge people double the prices, at least make the quality acceptable. A very very very high quality and authentic soltani is $30 (A decent tasty one is around $18) tops and for the price this restaurant charges you, its nowhere near good.
author: Audrey H.

description:
Come here to explore Persian cuisine and left genuinely satisfied. The food was seasoned well and had excellent flavor all around. Service was a bit off, but otherwise it was a great experience.

We began our meal with the Feta Cheese Spread, composed of oven roasted tomatoes, basil, and olive oil mixed with feta cheese. This spread went really well with the pita bread provided. However, the portion size was pretty large so we really only got through half, trying to save room for our entrees....wrong move. About 30-40 minutes after we stopped picking at our appetizer, we noticed the waitstaff making more frequent visits to our table to "check in" - refilling water, rearranging the utensils, taking away plates....but never to update us on whether or not our entrees would (if ever) arrive. That's when we came to the conclusion that we probably were supposed to finish all the cheese first...

I understand not wanting to "rush" patrons, but observation should have shown that we were pretty ready for our entrees...a simple question would have sufficed rather than constant checks. Eventually, we did receive our entrees (and we didn't even have to finish the cheese!) and what we ordered was really good!

The Shishlik was our runaway favorite! Done medium-rare, these lamb chops were impossibly tender with amazing flavor and just enough char. The order is delivered with 6 bone in chops - a great value too! Second favorite was the Khoresht Fesenjoon. Made of pomegranate and walnuts, you can really pick up on the fruity and nutty undertones in this "sweet and sour" sauce. The chicken was also fork tender. The Ghorme Sabzee was pretty good. The kidney beans mixed in with the onion, leeks, herbs, and lime was a nice touch...perfect accompaniment for the basmati rice in my opinion. The lamb shank was also fall of the the bone tender. The only dish I was a bit unsatisfied with was the Koobideh. It was definitely juicy, but there just wasn't much pizzazz compared to our other dishes.

All in all, delicious meal...albeit taking a lot longer than we had expected due to a tiny snafu.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Food is 4 start, service is almost 4, however i believe it's very overpriced. So I'll give them 3 overall.
Koobideh is my favorite persian kabob, and the kobideh here is definitely one of the best koobidehs that I've had in US so far. 
Rice was properly cooked and it tasted very authentic and original. 
Doogh (yogurt drink) very authentic and original. We loved doogh here and there was fight at our table over it. 
I didn't try any other food, cause kobideh is the only think that i easy in a persian restaurant. And it was really good. 
Do not forget; they have valet parking and it worth it every penny. So hard to find a parking spot around the restaurant. Even if you find one going up and down the hills are not very easy. The green street is pretty steep.
author: Saeed D.

description: Amazing food, if your in the city and want Persian food maykadeh is the place to go.  I ordered the chicken and beef shami combo which was very tender and flavoful
author: Wil R.

description: Very good quality food, absolutely delicious, great service! Definitely will go again! The lamb feet were tasty! Gheymeh was delicious and their yogurt is very good tasting!
author: Elli A.

description:
I am writing this long overdue review because I just had a horrific experience in Los Angeles at a terrible restaurant that serves Persian food. . And remembered this place. 

This restaurant has the best Persian food I have ever ate. The staff was professional and friendly. The food was  delicious and fresh. Good clean restaurant.
author: Sadaf S.

description:
I have been in this place few times in the past. The very first time was years ago and it was good. Last year, me and my friend went there and got the worst customer service. They weren't busy and only there was two or three tables and they kept ignoring us even by passing our table to go the only other table without checking on us. We were so disrespected by their worst customer service. I don't know why I forgot to write a review then!! Maybe I just wanted to forget the experience. 
Yesterday we went there again for my cousin's bday. Her husband invited us there and I always like to give places a second or third chance. This time it wasn't as horrible as the last but somehow they don't like to check on their customers. I think this is how they run the business but I don't think it is right. Because we had to wait for them to come around or ask the waiter. Again, they weren't busy and there were many servers working too. The food was just ok comparing to other Persian restaurants. The chicken kobedah was awful and chewy. It seemed that it was pre cooked and then over cooked in microwave. The beef kobedah was juicy but no flavor at all. I don't add salt in my food but this time I had too. The salad was very fresh and good. The fesonjoon was very delicious to be honest. 
The waiter didn't come to ask us about the meal and we had to wait until he came to the next table to tell him about the bad chicken. The chicken breast was very good and we ordered another one of that instead. 
I don't know if I want to go back to this place for the price you pay not only for the food but for the parking too. 
Hope they can fix these issues and check on their customers to see everything is ok.
author: Dee O.

description:
Best Salmon in San Francisco!.
My new fav spot. 
No champagne by the glass but bottles of beautiful wine and the menu is amazing!
author: Anna M.

description: Best Persian restaurant, kabab barg was really good, highly recommended. Good experience in San Francisco
author: Nader B.

description:
We had a employee lunch training day today and lucky for me we ordered take out from Maykadeh Restaurant. 

It was a very delicious treat to say the least. I ordered the Maykadeh Solanti. Upon opening the box the fragrant aroma of the perfectly cooked basmati rice mixed with the savory smells of the meat captivated my senses. It was also a very large portion and for a petite person like myself I easily made this into two meals which makes the initial pricier cost less so. 

The rice was cooked well, but slightly under seasoned which was fine because the juices of the meats marinated the rice adding more savory flavor that makes my mouth water just thinking about it. The solanti (filet mignon) itself was juicy, full of flavor and married well with the rice. The koobideh, though well seasoned, wasn't as tasty as the solanti nor did the meat melt in my mouth as did the solanti did. Probably because of the type of meat it was. Overall, a great dish, though next time I would just order the Maykadeh kebab (barg) because the filet mignon was the way better of the two meats, that way I'll save the extra $4 and put it towards the Persian ice cream :)
author: Melissa N.

description: I'm a fan of Maykadeh! We have been coming here for over 20 years now, since I was a kid! We always have great service, and really appreciate Sasha always going above and beyond for us. As Persians, we can be really picky about how kabob is cooked. I can honestly say I am never disappointed in Maykadeh. We often order delivery from here as well and its always ontime, and its always hot and fresh. My mother in law always uses them for parties and event. I love their Koobideh, their chicken Koobideh is really good too. I love their mast o moousir and kashk e bademjoon. I usually get my kabob with veggies, but when I do get their rise, its VERY good. Overall this place has good quality food for when you're craving some homey persian food. And I love the place too, its in a cute part of North Beach and the location is cozy.
author: Jasmine M.

description:
* Too expensive 
* Food below average, I've eaten in several Persian restaurants before and i can honestly say this one is on the bottom 2! 
Their hummus is delicious, but everything else isn't worth it. 
* Restaurant needs renovation 
* Restrooms are really gross

Bottom line, don't eat there.
author: Sarah A.

description: One of the best Persian food that I had in a long time. Their Barg Kévin is filet minion and very tender and tasty. The ground chicken is excellent. Juicy and flavorful. Ground beef opposites of other restaurant is very juicy and nothing extra mixed with it. Just let everyone know that if you decide to eat a real Persian food try this place. I know it's been there for a long time. I thanks them for such a delicious food that remind me of when I was in Iran.
author: Najmi G.

description:
Neither of us in our party had experienced Persian food before. We were delighted with the friendliness of the server, who explained how to enjoy the basil/onion/radish/butter/pita. We had hummus, a chicken kebab entree, and the lamb shank entree. I'm proud of how much we ate. The portions were quite large. We also shared the Malbec. Prices were affordable for the quantity and quality of food served.

Our only complaint is that we were sat at a two-top. There wasn't nearly enough space on our table for the amount of plates the food came on. I would have continued eating the pita and hummus, but one ended up stacked on the other.
author: Annie W.

description: Very long wait for the food, the staff got the order wrong and could care less about how to fix it. The food was ok but nothing special to blow you away. The spices used for the beef kabob wasn't authentic at all and could taste Ginger! In their food! Overall this place needs better decor, service and food. Till then won't be back at all
author: Michael I.

description:
It is not all about carpets!!

Almost every time I have a chat about Persian history, culture and art I hear comments about the "magnificent Persian carpets"! True that they are beautiful in the eyes of many, but there is a lot more to Persian culture than the carpets; Persian Cuisine being an example. At Maykadeh Restaurant they do an excellent job of providing proof of my argument.

Most who have dined in a Persian restaurant would agree that the Kebabs and the rice are delicious, but more adventurous diners, may wish to try some of the other dishes. For example if you like eggplants, try the Kashke Bademjan for appetizer. If not an eggplant fan, try Mast-o-Khiar which is homemade yogurt mixed with cucumbers and mint.

For main course, you can't go wrong with the kebabs of course, but you may also wish to try Khoresht Ghaymeh, an stew that is made with Pieces of lamb, yellow split peas, saffron, tomato, sun dried lime and served with Basmati rice. In cold weather Khoresht Fesenjoon may be a good choice. It is a stew made with dry roasted walnuts, pomegranate juice, and chicken thighs and/or breast. It has a sweet and sour taste and is served with Basmati rice.

What is the meaning of Khoresht you might wonder? As you may have guessed by now, "khoresht" is a generic term for stew dishes in Persian cuisine that are usually served with rice.

For appetizer you may want to try a cup of Persian tea with homemade Baklava. You will not be disappointed with Persian Ice cream either.
author: Afshin A.

description:
My wife and I ordered one chicken breast kabab and rice, with one additional skewer of koobideh.  The chicken tasted awful and borderline spoiled. Between the two of us, we could not finish the meal. 

My wife started throwing up that night and  spent the next day in our hotel room, having upset stomach and throwing up!  I was out, but felt not a whole lot better. 

When you pay $85 for one meal plus a couple of appetizers and two yogurt drinks, the least you expect is not getting sick from having that food.
author: Reza K.

description: I've ordered food from here several times and have not been disappointed. Everything is seasoned perfectly and the vegetables are so fresh! Delicious food.
author: Callie C.

description: Overall, we had a pretty disappointing experience. Service was bad (we waited for nearly an hour to get our food). While head waiter and manager were cordial and nice, i can't say the same for rest of the staff.  As for the food, ash we ordered was really good, I would even say one of the best I had. However, kebabs were quite mediocre (koobideh was slightly undercooked, while spicy joojje had a strange sauce on top, which I had never experienced before in Persian cuisine.)  overall, we were not happy with our experience, and next time will probably stick with other Persian restaurants in the city.
author: Onur E.

description: We had dinner last night. It was great food, good atmosphere, and great service. The folks went out of their way to make us happy. I love the lamb. It was awesome!!
author: OJ J.

description: I enjoyed every bite of my food. Such a friendly and welcoming host. This was our first time here and i am so glad that we chose this restaurant.. I ordered jooje kabob and my boyfriend ordered shish kabob as main course. We had kashkebademjoon as the appetizer. Their persian ice cream was the best. I highly recommend this place to all my friends.
author: Dorsa S.

description: If you're looking for some delicious Persian food in San Francisco, look no more. This place made my evening with its great food and welcoming staff.
author: Soroush A.

description: Best Iranian restaurant in San Francisco. The jujeh kebab is the juiciest that I've ever had. And all of the stews are top notch, especially the gormeh sabzi. Service is attentive and the quantity of food is very good for the price point. I just fish they had kidney and some other popular Iranian dishes.
author: Heidi P.

description:
Used to be my favorite Persian restaurant 20+ years ago...but alas, it's good but not the best anymore. Order the kaskeh bademjoon, beef koobideh, and the faloodeh/bastani for dessert.
Skip the ash, tahdig was not amazing nor was the Ghormeh Sabsee. The service was excellent, but I feel that they need to get ambitious and better chefs. 4 stars for sentimental reasons and a kind manager/hosts.
author: Sharen E.

description:
This is my first Persian food experience and I'm so glad my friends chose this place !!
The ambience is absolutely classy and every table had a bright red rose flower in a vase, beautifully place with a lit candle. 
The service was fantastic and the people are so kind there. 
I went along with my Iranian friends and they recommended me the food there.
But if you're a newbie, definitely go for the eggplant appetizer, and the yogurt drink! Also there's a yogurt dip appetizer too that goes well with the nan bread they bring out to nibble on before your entrées are brought in. 
The place is pricey but it's worth the rollercoaster of flavours you mouth  experiences!
Thank you for the wonderful experience and I will definitely visit soon!!
author: Rohini E.

description:
Best Persian we've eaten anywhere around the world (okay, I confess, we've not been to Iran to eat the real deal Persian food).  My wife and I both got the chicken joojeh along with the beef/lamb koubideh (sp?) kebab.  I love the chicken, she loves the beef/lamb, so we swapped kebabs so I ended up with two chicken and she had two beef/lamb.  Absolutely fantastic.  Eating there reminded me it's time for me to cook my own joojeh (I found a recipe that's pretty darn good) again!

You will not be disappointed eating at Maykadeh.  We've been there so many times and the food is always outstanding.
author: Tim L.

description: Just horrible service horrible food I would never go there again save your money . Food was horrible the waiter was so loud and ghetto she kept yelling and talking with people outside. They sent a Asian lady to bring our stuff who didn't speak any English and we had to repeat ourselves to her then to the waiter. We were the only people there so it's not like they were busy. The chicken was filledddd with (zarchube)  all over horrible .
author: Kimya R.

description: Excellent food. My sister and I eat here often. Yet to have a bad meal. The managers are very kind and give great customer experiences
author: Cricket G.

description:
Food is the best Persian in the city, the service is not consistent. Why would someone make a reservation if the table wont be available? Should we make reservations for 45 mins before our arrival?

Its fine for a 10 minute wait or maybe even 20, but 45 minutes is just shameful especially when you're inviting a friend to come try some of this awesome cultural food. Implement Open Table or something please!
author: George W.

description: My biggest complain is that they absolutely did not honor the reservation. They keep saying another 10 minutes and gave out the tables. Apprently the online reservation doesnt count.
author: Meysam W.

description:
If you're looking to try Persian food for the first time, I would probably not come here, but if you're a veteran Persian Cuisine enthusiast, and you're in the neighborhood... sure.

I had not come here in years, but happened to meet a friend for dinner since they lived in the neighborhood.  It hadn't changed much since 2009. The atmosphere is nice, and the restaurant strives for the upper level "steak-house" feel. We sat against the window, and the cushions on the booth-like seats were not that comfortable.  

For appetizer, we got the classic Kashkobademjaan (an eggplant dish), which was fairly good. They brought out complementary bread and greens.  I ordered the breast kabob and since I'm trying to shed the lbs, I asked for a salad instead of the jasmine rice.  Our waiter suggested getting grilled vegetables, which I did.  Excellent choice.  My friend ordered the Khorsesh Badejaan with lamb, which was fairly good.

The staff were quite nice and responsive.  I would have given Maykadeh 4 stars, I just feel that their prices are a little high for the food provided and ambience.  I will probably come back even if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Arman J.

description: Nice restaurant! I went here for Christmas with my family and it was very crowded! The goje kabob with bone is good with a rice that is not regular. The rice with zaffaroon is so oily. But otherwise, it was a nice restaurant with a great staff!
author: Darian A.

description: This Persian Resturant is truly one of the best I have ever been to....wonderful kabobs and food.
author: Shawn N.

description: Top 3 plates are kebabs, giant prawns, and lamb shank. In the order. I've eaten here 4 times now and every single time it's consistently phenomenal.
author: Kristina Noel K.

description: Excellent Persian food. Their koobideh was some of the best I've had across the country.  Try the mast moosir and the eggplant appetizer.  Their khoresht hit the spot as well!!
author: Sam A.

description: If you are Persian and are looking for GREAT kabobs, this isn't the place to go! I am from San Jose and the Persian restaurants are WAY BETTER than the food we experienced tonight. Service was poor and the portions were very small. I ordered the chicken with bone in and it was not enough chicken!! This was our first time and it will be the last time we visit. They didn't allow me to substitute the rice for salad and I can understand a small fee, but THEY DO NOT DO IT PERIOD. I had to pay $12 for a salad that had lettuce, tomatoes and a small dash of feta (greek salad). In a nut shell everything was way below average.
author: N L.

description:
This is my first Persian/Iranian food. My friend recommended this place. We made a reservation, thinking it will be busy during lunch time but when we got there, there were no one inside. I thought. .. Ummm that's not a good sign. I was seated and the host was really nice. We ordered 3 things from the menu.

Joojeh Kebabs- Boneless chicken thighs marinated in saffron, onion, and lime juice, with basmati rice. I ordered this dish and the chicken was really good! Very juicy and tender. The vegetables were also on point.

Shish Kebabs- lamb. My friend ordered this dish and she loved it. I don't like lamb so I would dislike the dish regardless

Kashkeh Eggplant- don't remember the name of this appetizer but it was primary eggplant in liquid form. It was really good. I liked it with my naan. 

Environment- clean, good cultural music, staff were friendly, my table was so clean... too bad we left several stains on the table lol

I would come back here again and order Joojeh Kebabs.
author: Jennifer B.

description: Some of the juiciest Persian food I've had. Ordered the chicken koobideh, beef koobideh, lamb chops and eggplant appetizer, all delicious
author: Kamran K.

description:
This place doesn't need any reviews LOL !!!
you can tell it is the best place to have a quality healthy food
by the first taste of your food.  Have been going there for 
30 years everytime I am in town.  
Thanks, Sasha.
author: Philip B.

description: Great food in a great location! My favorite is the Lamb Shang with eggplant, koobideh and chicken kabob. I also recommend Kashk Badenjoon; that's fried eggplant with a creamy whey, onion, and mint..This is not spicy, but it is very flavorful. A complimentary plate of greens, radishes, is served; along with a basket of warm flatbread. This restaurant is located in a very nice area of North Beach. A neighborhood that is a perennial hit with tourists, and also to remain beloved by San Franciscans.
author: Amir A.

description: I've been coming here for over 15 years and the quality is still great as the first time.  The best Persian restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Parwez F.

description:
Their Ghorme Sabzi was good

Koobideh wasn't good.

Overall this is the only Persian food restaurant I find acceptable in sf
author: S S.

description: Food was ok nothing to impressed by specially if you are Persian. Service not so good since they don't check on you as often as they should. We had a vegetarian Asian guest and when he was asking for food options the server was not so helpful and acted as if he was bothered with all the questions. Won't go there again since there was much more Persian options in San Fransisco. The place was not so busy otherwise I won't blame the service on it. Bathroom sink was leaking and dripping water all over you as you were on the toilet. Disappointed!
author: Mahbobe M.

description:
I order maykadeh at least once a week. Their food is ALWAYS delicious and even when I eat there via delivery - their service shines through. 

If you're not familiar with Persian food and want something other than kabob, try the zereshk polo. It's amazing- all my non Persian friends are HOOKED!
author: Nina L.

description: Excellent service, delicious food. Can't go wrong!
author: Andrea C.

description: Great restaurant. Second time there and always great food. They master any dish with eggplants in them.
author: Ruben L.

description: You can not go wrong with the Persian food cooked here at Maykade to the perfection . Spicy Joojeh Is at the top of my list!
author: Rana K.

description:
I order maykadeh at least once a week. Their food is ALWAYS delicious and even when I eat there via delivery - their service shines through. 

If you're not familiar with Persian food and want something other than kabob, try the zereshk polo. It's amazing- all my non Persian friends are HOOKED!
author: Lily N.

description: We ordered ghorme sabzi and zereshk polo . Ghorme sabzi was not bad but we didn't like zereshkpolo the rice was sweet and lots of chicken sauce had made the dish watery.the service was good
author: Rana T.

description: I visited this restaurant with my boyfriend and his family last night. Even though all of us are quite aware of the shortage of good quality, authentic Persian cuisine in the Bay Area, we were craving kabob and thought we would give Maykadeh a chance. We are Persian and we have a palate that understands what kabob is supposed to taste like and don't mess around. To our dismay, the kabob here is meant for people who don't know where Iran is on a map or claim they're cultured, yet they can't even pronounce Iran correctly. That's the only reason why the place is crowded. People just don't know what authentic Persian food is supposed to taste like otherwise they wouldn't be frequenting Maykadeh. Let me explain the food to you. We all ordered Barg and Koobideh kabobs and had a gheyme tadig appetizer and masto-mosier. The Barg tasted like bacon and it was sooooooo rubbery....and it was purple in tint. And did you know it's $37? We had soltanis so it was $43 for a small skewer of mediocre, off-tasting Barg and a skewer of koobideh that was forgettable. All in all, the kabob is literally double the price of all big city Persian restaurants I've been to, yet you are getting a smaller quantity and an average kabob that lacks freshness, juiciness, and taste. Maykadeh isn't fancy and it's not in Beverly Hills so why it charges double anywhere else baffles me. What are you going to charge next? $50? Oh and their chicken kabob which we had to send back has a whole host of random herbs in it that is clearly not found in Persian cuisine. Please don't come here if you are an actual Iranian, although I don't blame you for coming since there isn't much else in the Bay Area to choose from unfortunately. Before I end, I will say the gheyme tadig was pretty tasty!
author: Shirin K.

description: It's pretty hard to find authentic and delicious Persian food in the Bay but Maykadeh has really done it. Their service is amazing - friendly and attentive staff, plus the warm noon and fresh sabzi a bonus. Their kebab tops the charts - super juicy and excellent. No other restaurant can top Maykadeh.
author: Yalda B.

description:
Spicy joojeh, koobideh and poussin (chicken w/ bones) are great. At times, the chef over-butters the food but overall great food. The eggplant appetizers are good and service is ok...
Weekends can get busy so I recommend making a reservation.
author: Noor S.

description: Juicy kabob, I recommend the kubideh. And they have a really nice variety of not only kabob but also persian foods that are made in Persian households. It's a bit pricey but so worth it and it's in an awesome part of SF
author: Mina S.

description: Good service, great Persian food, very nice environment and location, very nice and friendly people. Best Persian food you can eat in the city!
author: Majid D.

description: I went here yesterday with a few friends and it was my first time. Overall I was rather impressed with the food. I ordered a ribeye steak that was cooked perfectly: not too charred and not too light either...just the perfect taste. The roasted potatoes were amazing as well! I'm only knocking this otherwise joyful establishment down a star due to how the prices seem unnecessarily high and it can take a while for them to bring your final bill. In the end I have no problem recommending this place, especially if you are a fan of Persian cuisine.
author: Jason P.

description:
This is only for the takeout, as I ordered delivery from here earlier this week. 

I can see that the food would be great if it had been served in person or the menu were clearer on what you would receive with each item. I ordered the lamb chops, which came with rice, and some hummus on the side. 

The menu could use some clarification. For example, the hummus is $9 (!) and I surmised this must be either the most amazing hummus ever, or a large portion, or include something else-- but the menu didn't specify. I ordered it anyway, and also a side of pita for $3. 

As suspected, a decent sized portion of hummus arrived, in addition to a full bag of pita (containing 4 rounds) and a smaller tray of sliced pita (equal to 2 rounds-- what we ended up eating). Not sure what part came with what, but we obviously overordered on the pita. We also received a small box containing one quarter of a raw onion and some basil leaves-- perhaps meant to be a salad, or maybe a garnish? 

All in all, I bought one entree (the lamb chops, which are 3 chops on top of rice) and one appetizer (the hummus/pita) to share with my husband: it was filling and the chops were seasoned well, but expensive for a weeknight one-entree/appetizer takeout meal. And the hummus was okay, but not $9 amazing.

I might come to the restaurant for a special occasion, but I'll probably skip takeout.
author: Krista L.

description: I went with my husband who has never had Persian food before. We shared a koobideh and khoreshte bademjan (lamb shank eggplant stew). Husband enjoyed the koobideh, which was not overwhelming with cumin and spices. Lamb was cooked to perfection, very tender and complimented well with the tomato/sour grapes sauce. I wish this was closer to me, but if I ever come back to SF this is where I will come to eat.
author: Meshel R.

description: The most gorgeous lamb head's soup I've ever had. And a short walk up to Coit Tower afterwards to help digest the half of a lamb you just consumed.
author: Nadia K.

description:
This is by far the worst Persian restaurant I have ever been too! 1) The service was awful- our waitress didn't attend to us for over 15 mins after we sat down, forgot our drinks until a minute before our meal came even though we reminded her of it, and ignored our requests for butter with our bread at the beginning of the meal. 2) I have never had more disappointing "Persian" food and for such a ridiculously expensive price!! We ordered a joojeh kabob which is just chicken thighs and the chicken was not fully cooked, had little to no flavor, and was full of uncooked fat that made trying to chew any salvageable pieces impossible. We told our waitress who grabbed the manager. After we told him of the issue with the chicken he told us "with that many pieces of meat (no more than 8-10 mind you) some of them might not cook all the way" WTF. Raw chicken can cause salmonella, it's not like meat where you can have it medium rare! He wanted to make us new ones which at that point we were already so disappointed and sadden by our meal experience did not want to have to wait for a new one and asked what else could be done (ie hoping they would refund the chicken as it was inedible leaving us hungry and upset) and he dismissed any opportunity to rectify the situation further. We also ordered doogh or a yogurt based drink that genuinely tasted like it was blended with acetone. We are all Persian at the table and have grew up with this drink- never had one taste as funky as this. Our go to Persian place (Lavash) is closed and had heard great things about this place and were so so so frustrated by this experience- it's not worth it and I hope someone in higher management has the opportunity to see this and hopefully adjust the quality of food and service at this restaurant. We paid an inordinate amount of money for food we didn't get to eat and service that was lacking- will never be coming back or recommending this place to anyone.

I will say, perhaps there other menu items are better and though we didn't get to try them it was ultimately the poor attitude of the service that will stop us from giving it another chance though others seem to enjoy this place.
author: Jessie R.

description: I love this place! My taste buds were happy from all the different flavors they had encountered.  Please try their Persian Martini, it's to die for!
author: Barbra K.

description:
My husband (who's Persian) and I came to Maykadeh 2 years ago and it was fantastic! So on this trip we were excited to come back. Unfortunately the food quality has gone down and the portions have gotten smaller. The prices seemed a bit steep. We also felt the food was on the saltier side. 

That said, their service was excellent. The food came out pretty quickly and our server was attentive throughout the night making sure our water bottle was always full. 

It's a nice Persian restaurant if you want to come to a fancier place with decent food but I didn't leave craving to come back.
author: Essie K.

description: Their food tastes good. It is pricy compared to Persian restaurants outside of SF (Shalizar is my favorite)
author: Eli E.

description: Very nice place, portions are huge. I'd recommend if you can get past the sticker shock
author: Garrett N.

description: Awesome authentic food plus awesome variety of Persian food including Kalleh Pacheh. Very polite professional staff . Very courteous and go out of their way to make me feel like a special guest .
author: Joe U.

description: Love the food at this restaurant, I can honestly say that this is the best Persian food I have had in SF, and believe me I have tried them all! I always do yelp delivery and they are never on time, so that's why I am giving it 4 star. 5 star would mean an impeccable service every time.
author: Shanzay H.

description: Not that impressed wth their food. Over priced Persian food that was let's say average.  My base of comparison is probably some of the much better restaurants in the So Cal area.
author: tony s.

description:
Love Persian food, so decided to try this place out on my Cali vacation. 

Do yourself a giant favor and order the filet mignon. It was THE most amazing steak I have ever had. It was perfect. It melts in your mouth and it's covered in a delicious mushroom sauce and it's making my mouth water just thinking about it. SERIOUSLY, order it. 

Service was good and the staff was nice. My friends got the rib-eye and the barg. The barg was no good but the rib-eye was good (but not as good as the filet mignon). 

This place is a bit pricey but very worth it.
author: Sunia C.

description: My wife and I both agree this is the best Persian food available in San Francisco. The wait can be long and especially for delivery, which is the only reason I am giving four stars instead of five, but then again the same is true for the other Persian options around. I also realize some of the Persian dishes take time to prepare. Their fesenjoon is phenomenal. My wife is a Persian immigrant and she says it tastes just like it did at home growing up. She said it is the most authentic she has had from either San Francisco or San Diego. The Kebabs are also good.
author: Yrev T.

description: One of the worst Persian restaurant I have ever been! I ordered soltani and the meat was undercooked and it wasn't taste good at all. The dough (yogurt drink) tasted horrible it seemed they made the dough with tap water! Horrible place and over priced would NOT recommend to anyone!!
author: Teni A.

description: Not sure why this place gets such great reviews - it's a pricey North Beach restaurant and seemed to be full of tourists so perhaps they are less discriminating - but I found the food totally mediocre and overpriced (well, for SF overpriced is the NORM, but MEDIOCRE doesn't have to be).  The service was fine - no problem there - even though the place was packed, we were not neglected . . . . But. . .the food was totally disappointing.  We were a large group and ordered a wide sampling of the foods, and the problems started immediately with  very uninspired flatbreads . . . .
author: Hoo.asked. U.

description: I've been eating here for over 10 years and couldn't recommend it enough! Being Persian, I can confirm that Maykadeh is the best in the bay. Definitely get the kabob and chicken koobideh - portions are large, so you can definitely share with someone!
author: Mileen Z.

description: Yessss that koobideh hit the spot. So soft and juices. Perfect combo of spices. You can tell it's probably one of their best sellers bc they sell pieces al la carte. Awesome spot.
author: Jesse J.

description: Been ordering delivery from them lately and they do an excellent job. Their food has always been on time or earlier and is well packed - so they're ahead of the game right there. I've been ordering their chicken breast kabob which has been consistently good and includes plenty of grilled veggies, which allows me to feel less guilty about constantly eating takeout. Sorry Mom, I'll do better in the future I promise!
author: Jeremy S.

description:
One of my all-time favorite Persian restaurants not just in San Francisco but overall. You know it's authentic when they start the meal with a basil,onion, radish, butter and pita bread and the Sumac is dispensed from a small bowl not a shaker. 

Everything here is good but my favorite is to start with the mastokhiar and hummus and then have the Joojah Kebab. 

Clean bathroom. Elegant ambiance but you can come dressed in tourist casual. 

You know it's a good place when there are native Persians eating there (just like at any other ethnic cuisine restaurant).
author: Susanne R.

description:
Another hungover Sunday led us to order from EAT24 and Maykadeh was on top of EAT24's recommended list.  Now I can see why that was the case.  Food came quick and swift and wrapped really neatly and with care.  You can tell that this isn't the type of restaurant to cut corners, use cheap ingredients, and slap together gross dishes a la Chinatown restaurants, etc.  No worries about food poisoning from this place!

Got the popular Koobideh (beef kebob and basmati rice), which really hits the post-Halloween boozing spot for us.  Also tried their Khoresht Fesenjoon, which is a Persian version of sweet and sour chicken.  My bf didn't care for it because it was "too sweet and plummy tasting," but I loved it.  I suspect it's made with tamarind which may not be suitable for all tastes.  Our meals even came with extra basmati rice, pita bread, and some basil + butter garnish that I wasn't sure what to do with?!?  Maybe that means I'll have to make a trip to this restaurant in person for them to teach me how to eat Persian food properly.  Thanks Maykadeh!
author: Bailey N.

description:
Poor service waited 30 minutes to get a cup of water. I spent $400 don't waste your money.
Food is OK nothing to write home about.
We tried ghormsabzi,  Barg, koobedeh and khoresht badengan .

Don't recommend
author: Jahanbakhsh S.

description:
This was an excellent meal. The portion size is large and the service fast. 

I started with the Yogurt drink which is good but really doesn't quench one's thirst. 

The joojeh kebab dish was excellent. The chicken pieces were large and tender. It came with rice and veggies that were fresh and well cooked. 

My two friends ordered lamb shank dishes that came out impressively. It was all fall off the bone tender. Very impressive.

The sweet and sour chicken dish was my favorite. Again, the meat was impeccably done. The flavors really worked in this dish. The rice added to the dish. 

For dessert, we couldn't decide so got the poached pear as well as the baklava. I felt that both of these could have been better. The pear could have been softer. The baklava was actually too sweet if that's possible. But still good.
author: James W.

description: Spicy chicken kebabs were very good. Highly recommended. Good ambience, excellent service, and close to a lot of bars in North beach.
author: Shreyas N.

description: Some of the best saffron chicken I have had, juicy, flavorful and cooked to perfection.Definitely a wonderful meal, with delicious rice and perfectly prepared asparagus. Paired very well with their French rosé, dry, crisp and not sweet. The ambiance was lovely and the service was efficient. My only regret was skipping dessert.
author: Erin D.

description:
We used Maykadeh for partial catering of our wedding in May, 2017 (we had a mix of Indian and Persian cuisine).

Sasha (their head of catering) was great to work with. He met with us a couple of times as we finalized our menu. He walked us through the whole process of deciding portions, the dishes, etc. He suggested a good mix of different gravies and meats and made some customizations to match what was best for us.

On the day of the event he and two of his staff came to manage the catering of the Persian food. He arrived on time and setup everything perfectly. The food was absolutely delicious and was displayed very nicely (he brought his own serving platters to ensure that the display was perfect). He also worked well with our Indian caterer and together they did a great job for us. At the end of the evening, he packed up all the leftovers for us and cleaned up by the required time.

One thing to keep in mind is that Sasha gets very busy so if you have a large event, its best to speak with him on the phone and meet him in person to finalize things. Aside from that, once you finalize things, he executes perfectly and you get exactly what you want.
author: Ankit A.

description: I was in town for work and a local recommended that I dine at Maykadeh for authentic Persian cuisine.  When we sat down, we were right away greeted by the manager or possibly owner.  Our waitress was fabulous a too and recommended dishes for us to try.  We tried the Lamb Tongue, Lamb/Beef Koobideh, the Koresht Bademhja Lamb shank, Ghorme Sabzee Lamb and Hummus.  100% Recommend!
author: Claudia V.

description:
The staff is generally very nice and welcoming with a warm atmosphere. 

However, the food is not great and maybe hardly a 3 star. I'm a Kabab lover and I'm very sensitive about it. I didn't find the meat for the Kabab Barg ( in Meykade Kabab and Soltani) 

The Koobide Kabab was a little overcooked in the sense that the outer surface was fairly burnt.

We also tried the Fesenjoon and it really didn't taste good.

My friend also ordered a team and she was really unhappy with it. She had us test it and I agreed that it wasn't tasty and it felt it was watered down.

In general I disn't find the restaurant a good Iranian food experiece. However, to be fair the staff are nice. The food is fairly a 3 but I decided to give the restaurant 2 because of the menu was definitely overpriced.
author: Salim M.

description: What's not to love!  Exceptional service.  Delicious food.  Great variety and excellent portions.  This is a hidden gem on telegraph hill.  Highly recommend the Lamb Badenjan.   Ran out of room to try other things but I'm sure it's all excellent.
author: Brittany K.

description: The food was excellent, but I only got to eat about half of it, as my Nima tested the (assured by the person who answered the phone) supposedly-gluten free hummus as full of gluten.
author: Fat Lazy Celiac Z.

description:
This review is long overdue, as I dined here several months back, but it's never too late to write a review.

I wanted to have a dinner with a group of relatives after I graduated from SFSU and we had dinner here several days after commencement.

Despite having spent a significant portion of my time in San Francisco while I was a college student and despite being half-Persian, I had never taken the time to come by here and get some food.

Some facts:

* The interior is relatively small, so it may seem a little cramped once you're inside.
* There is a full bar for you to sit at and grab a drink as well.
* Most of the waiters/waitresses are bilingual in English and Persian, in case you have people in your group who understand Persian, but not English.
* Valet parking available

For my first experience here, it was pretty good!  The portions were rather large and you get your money's worth.  The prices are definitely not cheap, but, at the same time, not ridiculously expensive either.  Our waitress was attentive and, overall, I felt like coming here was a good decision.  

4 stars
author: Michael F.

description: Friendly service and excellent food. Make sure to order lamb tongue OMG!!! Taste so good, great appetizer. We also like the barg and shish kabab. I will come back to try more dishes next time. Oh Banafsheh was awesome!!
author: AL N.

description: Very cozy, the manager accommodated us without a reservation. Friendly service, great food and cozy environment.
author: Seble L.

description:
This restaurant was very easy to find, tons of street parking. 

Went in to dine for lunch and it was  amazing. Persians cuisine is very tricky to get right, the fact that this place is a staple says A LOT! I've been to probably 20-30 different Persian restaurants worldwide.

We ordered: mast o khiar (cucumber yogurt), Cornish hen and koobideh! Every table automatically gets fresh herbs and fresh warm pita bread. 

If you have never tried Persian food, you must!!!! If you are a Persian food connoisseur it will not dissapoint. TRY, TRY, TRY!
author: Yasmin S.

description: Service is good. Had koobideh, which sounded delicious (as it's angus beef and lamb blend), but unfortunately, was disappointing bland.
author: Ali G.

description:
Hummus was decent. Dry in my opinion.

The fancy salad wasn't all that fancy. Look if you want to pass it off as fancy because you've added poached pears, then don't be stingy about it. IJS.

I had a very forgettable eggplant dish. Majorly disappointing. Meh, head to Aziza, you won't be disappointed there.
author: Gabriela W.

description:
This is a high-end Middle Eastern joint tucked in the upper corners of North Beach.  Classy, expensive food that's not quite worth it.

We started with the Fancy Salad (yes that's the actual name, told you the place was classy).
It had poached pear, baby spinach, hearts of palm, candied walnuts, pomegranate vinaigrette.  Sounds good but it was amateurish, just didn't come together.

For my main, I had the Shishlik: a rack of lamb chops marinated with basil, garlic, saffron, onion, lime juice, vegetables, basmati rice.  The lamb chops were quite good but not epic, I've had better at Tuba in the Mission (for a lot cheaper).  

My wife's vegetarian eggplant dish was forgettable. Our friends' dishes sounded like they landed in about the same place: so-so; good but not great.
author: Saminda W.

description: Genuinely great Persian cuisine, friendly & professional people provide first class service . I and my family dine there when in the City and would like to have kebab
author: Amir H.

description: delicious food, nice service and pleasant ambience
author: LUDMILA G.

description:
Food: Fantastic Persian food! I ordered "Lamb Tongue" and " Ghorme Sabzi" and both were delicious! 
Staff: Polite
author: Feri Y.

description: Best Soltani ever! We are visiting from S Cal with abundant of Persian Restaurant and yet this was the best Soltani I had in US. The quality of their meat was great and the meat was so tender. Koobideb kebabob was mixed with Safaran and did not taste like onion. They served the dishes with generous amount of sabzi (herbs, basil).
author: Hourieh F.

description:
We are pretty much a regular here, either we come in for dinner or order it via third party apps for delivery. I would say they are the best Persian restaurant in SF (I live in SF and have been to all the Persian restaurants new and old). Their staff is always friendly and accommodating. The food actually always arrives so fast (in the restaurant). They check in on us frequently to make sure we have everything we need.

I usually order the following:

for appetizer-
Kashkeh Bademjoon
Salad Shiraz
Mast-o-Musier

for main dish-
Soltani (Koobideh & Barg)
Ghormeh Sabzi
