Amazing food. Also one discovery I made is that they have my fav Wine by Darioush Winery : Shiraz! Can't usually find it anywhere except at their Winery!
author: Sepi N.

description:
I really wanted to like this place since I heard so much about it but I just can't.

The one positive thing is the delivery came within 30 min as opposed to the 45-60 they quoted me. 

The koubideh kabob was so burned. Really a bummer. The tomato was not even ripe. The rice was good but not worth $17. 

The pita bread was okay and went nicely with my kaskabatomjoon (wrong spelling - eggplant appetizer).

Salad shirazi was okay but a little too much vinegar for my taste. 

I'm Persian and have been eating delicious food from all over the Bay Area but this isn't one of them.

Maybe when you order at the restaurant it's better?
author: Brittany G.

description: Let's just say they'd be getting four stars If their prices weren't totally absurd. As a persian I absolutely love having persian restaurants we can go out to eat at. Maykadeh was good but definitely not the best. They charged 34$ for a zereshk polo with one chicken skewer. 16$ for heir tahdig and fessenjoon. Don't get me wrong, the flavor taste quality was all good but definitely over priced. Fessenjoon was very sour. Wouldn't go back.
author: Desiree A.

description:
Delicious! Being Persian, I must admit that my standards for Persian food are quite high :) and Maykadeh is one of the best in the Bay!

My family and I recently came here for Father's Day and had a fanastic lunch. Everything from the kashkeh bademjan (eggplant dish) to the kabob koobidehs to the kabob barg just hit the mark. The kabobs were juicy, tender, and perfectly cooked. The taste is still on our tongues! Can't wait to come back.
author: Sara T.

description:
I had heard a lot about this restaurant so I decided to go with my family.

Outcome: 
It lived up to the hype. Everything thing was delicious from they bread, to the maast moussir, to the kabob.

Recommendation:
-Breast kabob (joujeh kabob with breast meat only)
-Ghorme sabzi
author: Sep N.

description: Loved the pomegranate curry and the eggplant entrée. Please try these. Didn't expect it to taste so good but it did. Definitely recommend it.
author: Karthik V.

description: Kebabs were good but kinda over priced. Restrooms were super dirty. We found lipstick stains on the glasses and no one apology for that.
author: Pegah N.

description:
My favorite Persian restaurant in Northern California.
Outstanding service, everyone was very helpful, especially the manager , Mr. Sasha.
If you are looking for a good Persian Restaurant in San Francisco, I highly recommend them.
author: payam b.

description: I loved this place! I came here as a tourist in SF - it's a pretty high class place, I got the zereshk polo & it was delicious (I'm Persian so I know what a good polo should taste like). Also - I LOVED the music they were playing, it was a mix of classical Persian, modern persian, and pop music.
author: Sheeva S.

description: This is a review for the delivery business.  The food at the restaurant is fantastic but both times that we ordered delivery, the chicken breast kabobs were dry as a bone and the pita hardened to rock within minutes.  Not sure where the disconnect is happening but skip the delivery and eat AT the restaurant.
author: Monica K.

description: Called in advance to see if I arrived at 10 if the kitchen would still be open and when I call 15 minutes before 10 to let them know I'm on my way they say they are closing the kitchen early!!!! Why not inform me of this earlier?!??! I understand workers are tired but I made specific plans to come there tonight with my friends for my birthday after work!!!
author: Vivian L.

description: Everything in this restaurant was a straggle ... I first wanted to get half rice and half salad with my kobadie but I was told I can't get it like. Then I asked to get my daughters Solomon  a la carte and they told me it wasn't possible. With all that straggle the prices are too high for the type of food. This is not a gourmet food but the prices sure felt like it was. Don't go unless you want to leave with a big bill and lots of disappointments.
author: Amir I.

description:
certainly best iranian restaurant i have been to outside iran.
high quality food. 
reasonable service (sorry i have low expectations of iranian restaurants when it gets to service).
rice was not that good...still loved my food enough to rate it a five.
i used to go to maykadeh while living in san francisco, and now each time i go back for a visit.
author: Mehran F.

description: What a fabulous find - A very nice white tablecloth restaurant- the roses on the table add an elegant touch.   This is non Americanized Persian food.   Staff & Service is very attentive with above par hospitality.   All the  food I have tried is superb- I love the lamb plates.  This is arguably  the best Persian restaurant in the country - excellent place !
author: NancyChurro C.

description:
I highly recommend this place. Great food, great service, nice ambiance and they also serve alcoholic drinks . I am Persian myself and have tried so many places around the U.S. This one beats all.
My husband and his friends agreed.
author: Jeff R.

description:
I would have given a 0 if I could! 
All the Kebabs had baking powder and that was the reason for them being slushy. 

Will NEVER go back. 
I wish I wouldn't have spend time and money there... 
The stews we ordered were frozen definitely! 

DON'T GO!!!
author: Alireza P.

description:
went here on a Tuesday night at around 7pm. When we arrived the entire restaurant was empty. Over the course of the dinner, 3 other diners came in. I was a bit surprised given that we were in San Francisco on a fairly nice day. 

anyways, I ordered the Giant Prawn dish which was $30. the Prawns were large and excellent, however the order came with just 4 of them. Didn't see a great value. If I was uber-wealthy, I would have ordered another plate of 4. 

What sort of struck me as strange, was their rice. this is the staple. I have been here about 5  times over the years,  and the rice was always standout. the rice came very moist, almost had extra water on the plate. I expected the rice to be on the firm -drier side. 

we had some apps, a Greek Salad which was standard, if not on the side of not being super fresh, and a plate of Feta and Olives which were good. 

Service was great, as to be expected seeing that we were the only table on the side of the dining room occupied. 

at the end of the day, I totally enjoyed the Prawns. ..but for the cost and the rest of the meal just being average, I wouldn't go out of my to return.
author: Garfield J.

description: First time I went to this place I loved it. But the second time I went I ordered Brest chicken kabob ... that didn't tasted good at all. Think the chicken was not cooked enough. But the rest of my family I was with said they liked the food.
author: Belma M.

description: The BEST Persian food around the city. Their chicken koobideh is divine and melts right in your mouth. You need no knives at this restaurant as everything is so dang tender. Our usual go to dishes are mast-o-museer (yogurt with elephant garlic) as a dip, tahdig with fessenjoon and ghormeh sabzi and the chicken koobideh and beef koobideh kababs. It appears that all the yogurt dishes are homemade as a lot of Persian restaurants opt for premade from vendors like Abali. I will say the only thing that bums me out is that they do not have carbonated doogh. The staff is super friendly and the host is very gracious. Anytime we are in the city and we have out of towners with us, we make sure to drop in on this place. Also, as parking is non existent in this part of SF, do note that there is a valet and uber is probably your best option.
author: Andy A.

description: Fresh, generous, friendly. I just love the soul you can taste in this food. You can tell it's made from the heart. The meats are incredibly soft, juicy, and seasoned. The basil is so fresh and organic..I even ate some raw onion because it was totally fresh and perfect. Very appreciative of this restaurant - no wonder they've been around this long!
author: Lera D.

description: Fantastic food, authentic or not. About half of my Persian friends give me grief. The rest eat from here. Yum.
author: Paul C.

description:
Mmmm Maykadeh is pretty delicious. I've actually only ordered via Yelp and never stepped inside the restaurant. My boyfriend is Persian, and we switch of coming here and Lavash. Both are good at different things, but nothing compares to his moms cooking. 

Koobideh- SO much flavor. My favorite thing to get here. 
Maykadeh Kebab (Barg)- When I'm feeling more fancy, I go for this. It's really good. The meat is perfectly cooked. 
Ghorme sabzee- Boyfriend always gets this, I'm not a huge fan of theirs. It's a little too greasy for my taste. I prefer Lavash's. 
Breast Kebab- I usually pass on this. I like Lavash's more. Usually pass on this. The beef ones are much better. 

I like Maykadeh, but it's expensive. Persian food just is.
author: Gabrielle C.

description:
We were so looking forward to eat there. Made a reservation and we were late 5 minutes . They made us wait at the door for 45 minutes and let other people go ahead of us. They were very rude and inconsiderate. The Barge was not cook and everything was cold and small portion. 
Never again going there.
author: Fay K.

description: Their lamb tongue appetizer is heavenly! I often go back to this restaurant just for this appetizer (it's actually enough for a meal if you are not a heavy eater). We also had kabob barg, and that was quite good too.
author: Mohammad m.

description:
Not as good as I had hoped. The ambience was OK. The service reasonable. I was just not that impressed by the food. 

Chelo-kebab Chicken Koobideh - Ground chicken breast, onion, Persian spices - Good, but not great. I have had better.

Joojeh Kebab
Boneless chicken thighs marinated in saffron - Very Good - I liked this dish.

Khoresht Fesenjoon - Way too sweet for my taste - I had to abandon this one

Homemade Baklava was ok
author: David T.

description: Our server Bibi was great. We loved her service and the food. We enjoyed everything here and will come back next time we're in San Fransisco. The only problem was parking but they valet parking solved it easily.
author: Dr. Kay S.

description: Best kabob and customer service in the city! Not only is the food incredible, everyone who works there genuinely cares about the customer and is nicely dressed. One time they forgot part of our delivery order, when we called to tell them, they quickly brought us the kissing item AND surprised us with dessert.
author: Ashley W.

description: Came out here on a Saturday night with a friend. I up getting the chicken kabobs and he the ghorme sabzi. The kabobs, were, AMAZING! So juicy. I tried the ghorme sabzi and it was a delicious dish as well, different and herby with a tasty sauce. We also got the Persian tea and some ice cream to end off the night with. Service was great the whole night. We will definitely be back!
author: Tim P.

description:
Excellent and never failing delicious diners!
And special Thank you! For making my sons 16th birthday a very special one!!!!
You guys took a great care of teens! They had blast!
author: galina c.

description: I loved the restaurant ambiance and the food. This our 2nd time having persian food in the same week. We went to Lavash the first time and I have to say Maykadeh is way better in terms of everything. The food was amazing.  We reserved table for two ahead of time and did not have to wait at all in a full restaurant on valentines night. Only thing I would say is the some of the staff isn't very friendly. The lady waitresses, none of them greeted us or said hi. Well its okay I dont mind it but when a lady came to our table to drop the complimentary bread and butter, we said hi with a smile and she didnt bother to reply. Later another lady served us food and she also looked very pissed just dropped the food and left hahah. That was a little surprising for us. But we will definitely go there again just for the food.
author: Fariha T.

description:
One of the worst persian resturant i have ever been , the rice was soaked with oil and koobideh was burnt totally 
They dont know squat about persian cusine
author: Amir S.

description: High quality meat for kebabs. The lamb is amazing. The stews were also good which is rare for restaurants vs. home cooked Iranian food. Expensive but amazing.
author: M. M.

description: I went here with a group of 8 people and everything was cooked to perfection. Their Koobedeh was juicy and fresh, their ghormesabze was the best i've ever had in a restaurant. And their rice was buttery. Everything was amazing. No complaints.
author: Sara K.

description:
It's a little funny to not eat Italian food in North Beach, but we gave it a try based on someone's recommendation.  I wished I had asked for more details beforehand.  I didn't know it was this formal, with white tablecloths.  Fortunately a giant group of tweens were having a birthday party, so our children were completely muffled, and we were not ruining anyone's intimate date!  

Having only had Persian food once, ordering was both difficult and embarrassing.  I couldn't pronounce any of the names, didn't understand the symbol for halal, and had decision paralysis with all the dishes that sound so similar (chicken or lamb? chicken or lamb?)

Finally I had the young chicken which came with a plate of very fragrant and very large rice.  The grains were humongous!  I have never had rice like this before.  The chicken was tender and well flavored.  

My husband's lamb shank looked almost like a plate of pork shoulder.  Meaty and falling off the bone tender. 

Overall, the food was good, as well as the service.  I'd be interested in trying some of their other dishes.
author: Candice B.

description: I had a great time with my family in Maykadeh restaurant. The food was so delicious. Bibi the waitress was so nice. She served us very well. We enjoyed a lot.
author: Shirin J.

description:
The food: we ordered hummus, chicken kabob, and koobideh.  Those are our usual order every time we go to a Persian restaurant.  The order came with pita bread.  They were definitely very generous with the pita bread.  Unfortunately, the pita bread was not that good.  If the food isn't tasty, then I don't care for the generous portion size.   The reason for that is we just end up not being able to finish the food and end up wasting it - which i hate to do.  Their hummus was okay.  The koobideh and the chicken kabobs were good.  It was cooked well,  not dry.  Overall, this place is more expensive than the other persian restaurants we've been to and the feel of the restaurant is more "fancy" and romantic.

The service:  our server was nice.  He was attentive and checked on us.
author: JD W.

description:
It's good food here. We ordered a drink called the dough, pretty interesting similar to the salted indian lassi. For the main course we ordered the kashke bademjan (Interesting-Its mashed eggplant cooked in a mint garlic sauce) We ordered the maykadeh soltani (marinated Filet mignon slices - Good, koodideh - I liked this better) We also ordered the joojeh kebab (it was good) 
Now let me share a funny experience. I've seen in many cases that people still have some food on their plate that they intend to finish. However I see that sometimes the waiters carry all the plates away in one fell swoop, if they see some of the people have finished eating. The same thing was going to happen here in mykadeh and I had to tell the waitress I had not finished. She came back later for my plate and by then I had finished my koobideh :) Happy to have been able to hold on to my plate. Lol.
author: Amrita G.

description:
I'm a bit surprised by the reviews for this place, I thought the food was below average with above average prices.  It just doesn't seem like they try that hard or care.  The location is great, right off of North Beach and the park, very neighborhoody and quaint, too bad it's not something worth coming back for. I might be being a bit harsh, but I expected much better.

We came here on a Wednesday night, the place was pretty much empty and filled up a bit later but not packed.   When I looked at the menu, I was a bit surprised by the prices of some dishes, $30 for a lot of them and instinctively I knew they wouldn't be that good. 

Food: 

Humus: we make way better at home, it was thick and not enough tahini, no flavor.

Pita: seemed like it was warmed up and not home made.

Cucumber salad: good, lots of lemon, refreshing.

Baba ghanoush: the eggplant didn't taste roasted, had way too much lemon in it, didn't like it all. 

Feta spread: was basically crumpled feta.

Lamb shank: it was tender, but lacked flavor or care, it just seemed very average and uninspired. 

We did have a bottle of Earthquake Zinfandel which I highly recommend.
author: Inga W.

description:
Complete disappointment! Writing this review fresh out of eating there.

I'm shocked at how misleading the reviews for this place were.

My order was a simple kebab koobideh w saffron rice.  My feedback is this:

-your saffron rice is the worst I've ever had in my life. Not only did it lack flavor and proper texture but it was also salty and the basmati was overlooked.


-the koobideh itself lacked true Iranian spicing and tasted at best, okay. It was not bad but I've had much better koobideh at much cheaper places.

-why is the onion not grilled like the tomato? That might have saved this plate.

Two stars for attentive service and nice layout. The horrible food does not make up for it though. Complete miss and won't come back.
author: Mia F.

description:
Came here based on a recommendation from a friend. We ordered the koobideh and barg for main course and the mast o khiar and kashk o bademjoon for appetizer.  The food was overall very tasty.  The meat was nice and juicy. Everything was a fresh.  Only down side is it didn't really feel like a Persian restaurant. They were playing Indian/Arabic music.  The menu had items that you
Never find on a Persian restaurant menu.  Prices were probably the most Expensive I have seen at a Persian restaurant.  But hey, it's in San Francisco in a nice area.  Overall I still rate it 5 stars.  Service was good and quick.  I'll definitely come back and would recommend to friends.
author: Sarah F.

description:
kubideh is one of the best I have had.
 Also check out the Saffron + Pistachio ice-cream. More flavor less sweet.
author: Husain D.

description: I ordered Fesenjoon stew with rice and I can say that it was amazing! The rice was cooked perfectly and the stew had a delicious sour taste. The yogurt was also perfect. However, I didn't like the Dough drink. It could be more tasty.
author: Farima F.

description:
This place is great - I love Persian food plus they deliver!  It has entered our rotation

We typically order:
Joojeh kebab (chicken SOOO good)
Maykadeh Soltani (steak, also great!)
zereshk polo (tender chicken with gravy/curry sauce)

get some yoghurt sauce to throw on top and you are GOOD to GO!
author: Kevin F.

description:
Food-wise, we ordered the main Yelp highlights (lamb tongue, chelo-kebab koobideh and khorescht bademjan (lamb shank & eggplant) that everyone has already reviewed and deemed delicious. The tongue was a little weird at first, but it's pretty delightful how it just melts in your mouth (yes, it's that soft and tender!) Highly recommend ordering a glass of cabernet to go with the lamb-heavy meal!

Tip for first-timers on how you're supposed to prepare the your basmati rice for you meat dishes! Our server instructed us to melt the butter onto the rice, then mix in the roasted tomatoes (which is on every single entree dish we ordered), and then pair that with any of the meats. Buttery rice, I mean, come on... We all know how delicious that is!

If you're not into the rice, you'll also get a basket of naan and plate of basil/half a raw onion/ radish/butter upon seating. I was confused (and overheard other tables asking) how we're supposed to eat it. Just butter up that naan, add some basil and koobideh. Don't forget some raw onion to go with each bite!
author: Joanna H.

description: Worst service in my opinion, felt unwelcome and they weren't friendly. Food isn't the best either.
author: Aisha A.

description: Too pricey and food was disasters plus so mean waitress. They charged us 10$ for parking. I'll never come back again
author: Matin H.

description:
Get the spicy joojeh (boneless chicken thigh)--$17.  Tasty and good portion.  Comes with pita bread, basmati rice, broiled tomato, and green beans.  Green beans are not so good but everything else is great.  

I also like the ground beef/lamb koobideh--$16.  Sometimes it's really tender and fantastic, but other times it can be dry.

Big portions with a lot of the delicious basmati rice, pita bread, butter, and raw extras (onion, mint).  Delivery is convenient and they even give the sumac spice (purple stuff) and butter.
author: Vanessa O.

description:
I know real good Persian food and this is real good Persian food.  The koobideh was the perfect combination of tender and flavorful.  The joojeh was seasoned perfectly and the rice was fluffy and tasty.  

It's a little bit of a bummer that they do not bring out feta cheese with the sabzi and bread:  I believe it's $7.  Other than that, the service was a little subpar, with the waiters being pretty slow to come around even though we went in between lunch and dinner when there was hardly anyone else in the restaurant.  

Overall, I highly recommend Maykadeh.
author: Nora R.

description: This place charges you for luxury service and food, but the food is very casual, and rice portion is very very small.
author: Sean R.

description: I'm from NY where there isn't very good Persian food, so I often eat at Maykadeh when I'm in SF. Food is excellent and it has been for over a dozen  years. I have to say the service is not as good as it once was. A few times it has been a struggle to get the attention of the waitress, who's off chatting with another staff member, and the manager (who's generally great) is distracted taking telephone orders. They need to beef up the staff to radial the food. Food would get 5 stars, but service brings it down to three this time.
author: J D.

description:
Koobideh was fresh.
Portions were generous.

Ambiance was nice, with Persian music.

Overall, a decent experience.
author: Arman R.

description:
We were out on our regular Tuesday-night restaurant hunt and found this place while touring the area. Yep, that's right, we didn't Yelp, just took a chance and it was well worth it.

I ordered Zereshk Polow and loved it. I've had the dish in other restaurants before but Maykadeh beats them all. Chicken was nice and juicy and the rice done just right. Quantity was pretty big I could only finish a quarter before asking for a box. I'd highly recommend this place anyone looking to enjoy Persian food.
author: Syed A.

description: Legit Persian food, unreal!  The beef lamb tongue appetizer is incredible and melts in your mouth, perfectly cooked.  Their rice is spot on and might cook their lamb the best in the city.  Always consistent and full of flavor.  Keep it up guys!
author: Joe I.

description: Nice ambiance, great service and really tasty food. We ordered koobedeh, lamb skewer and then falooda and ice cream for dessert. Everything was fantastic. Prices are ok but a little bit on a high side. All in all, great experience. Highly recommended and will go again.
author: Faisal A.

description: The first time I tried the food here at Maykadeh was about a year ago and it was just great. However, my second visit of Maykadeh wasn't anything but disappointment. The food quality wasn't anything like what it used to be. Their rice was like the rice you get at a Chinese takeout with some butter and Kabab was raw inside  and burnt outside. I wouldn't go back.
author: Kamran D.

description:
I ordered takeout from here on my way home from SFO after the breakfast on my flight left me hungry. I ordered the Barg Kebab and the Zereshk Polo. Both were flavorful and tasty.

I must make a special mention of the Barg Kebab. We have all been that person who sees the photo of a dish and becomes disappointed when it arrives as it looks nowhere as good and appetizing as the photo. Well, their Barg Kebab looks as good as it is on the photo - perfectly juicy beef and grilled tomatoes served on top of flavored rice. This is now one of my favorite Kebabs ever.
author: Sadique A.

description:
I Brought my mom telling her this is one of the best persian Restuarant in the City, WRONG! 
Don't get me wrong, it used to be but this time i can truly say it was the worst. The rice didn't taste anything like persian rice and it looked brown and it was really dry. The koobideh was too dry and the Barg just didn't taste good. I was so disappointed considering each dishes was twice the price of any other persian restuarant which i wouldn't have any problem if it was good.
author: Maryam P.

description:
Ghorme Sabzee (Lamb, leeks, chives & herbs) is disgusting...

I probably won't be coming back.

Prices are decent. Service was ok.

Sorry, not even worth spending my time with this review bc of how bad my food was!
author: Tammy F.

description: Should really be more like 3 1/2 stars. The food was pretty good, but somewhat inconsistent.A few things were really delicious, then then another thing was just ok. I'll probably give them another try, through
author: Dan E.

description: Maykadeh is a wonderful restaurant. I've come here twice: once with friends and once for my birthday dinner. The service is always excellent and the food is amazing! I cannot begin to describe how wonderful this restaurant is; from the atmosphere to the service, to the food. I would definitely recommend eating here to a friend, and I would also recommend the Persian Tea!
author: Laura G.

description: Tried koobideh and a few sides like must a kheer and hummus. I ordered Delivery, and I thought the food was good quality, but not great.
author: Asim V.

description: The only reason I tried them cuz of yelp, but very disappointed at Kabob quality specially koobideh. Hopefully they stop adding preservatives to their food.
author: Reza A.

description: Old-school Persian in an unassuming tucked away Street in North Beach. Excellent food and great service. I am surprised that it was not busy on a Thursday lunch. Hopefully it is busier for dinner, because I would really like to see the business thrive.
author: L S.

description:
MAYKADEH serves by far the best Persian food in Northern California!!

My suggestion on what to order:

Appetizers: mast mousir and salad shirazi. 

Main Course: Soltani - Chicken barg and a beef skewer with zereshk polo
author: Nikki A.

description:
I first ate at this restaurant nearly 25 years ago. I've probably eaten there somewhere between 20-25 times. Since I don't live in the city, it would have to be a special occasion for me to make the drive. I always order the lamb tongue and the soltani (filet mignon and koobideh). I also love the ghormez sabze because it taste just like my Persian friend mom's home cooking.

The hands down favorite is the tongue. I've never had anything like it.  I'm going to have to elaborate on this order because I found the best way to eat it.  It's tender, tart and creamy but not the milky creamy taste. More yogurt creaminess. It's an appetizer but I always ask for it to be served with my meal. It goes so well with rice, the red tart stuff, and raw onions. YES, the raw onion adds a sweet kick to the tart flavor. You'll thank me on the onion suggestion but not your significant other.

The only downside to this place is how pricey the soltani has gotten over the years. It was in the high teens back in the early 90s but it's over $30 now.  I don't mind paying for good meat, and it is supposedly filet mignon. However, I would rather eat filet mignon at a steakhouse.  Their koobideh is nearly just as good. For $19, you get a generous portion. Also, they used to provide complimentary feta cheese with the bread and sabze, but it's now extra charge for the cheese.

I would give 5 stars if the prices are more reasonable or maybe if they brought back the feta cheese (lol, I know it's just cheese but I hate it when something is taken away). Also, I love how this place retain their employees. I've seen some of the same people from the 90s!
author: Victor L.

description: Okay -- they made up for the F'd up delivery but making a free delivery the following day. Food was amazing, and on time -- So I am giving their delivery service another chance. Thank you Maykadeh for rectifying the problem.
author: Nolan M.

description:
I was walking in San Francisco one day, somewhat delirious from a strenuous interview with one of the locally sourced international tech giants. Maykadeh called my name. It saved me! 
The Soltani was a piece of heaven mixed with memories of childhood. The perfect balance of creaminess and tanginess of Maast Moosir along with the taste of Dough carried me home and back. All I could do was to call the hotel and delay my check out, so I could stay just a little longer with this heavenly feast. I remember I ran to the airport afterwards and barely made my flight. It was totally worth it.
author: Jon S.

description: The service and food was delicious here. I had the steak kebabs and everything was tender and delicious. My best advice is to avoid taking a car if you go on the evenings or weekends. My cousin ordered this dish with a pomegranate sauce which was delicious too unfortunately I don't remember the name of the dish. I
author: V M.

description:
By far the best persian restaurant in Northern California.    Food quality has been consistently very good for all the years that we've frequented this place.  

If they are busy don't expect the best service, but enjoy the food as it makes up for the frenzy during the busy nights.

Highly recommend to anyone wanting to get a true taste of good persian food.
author: Danny D.

description: I went with my family for Christmas Eve hoping for a great start to the holiday. Instead we had horrible service and felt disrespected. We had a reservation and were made to wait 35 minutes. The host was rude and proceeded to seat people that came after us before us. The food portions were small and the food was very average for the high prices they charged. My meat was undercooked and overall the experience was horrible with a below average atmosphere. Embarrassing for them to represent Persians. Never going back or suggesting this place.
author: Nasim K.

description: This is the top notch Persian Cuisine in the Bay Area. Not only the food is remarkable but so is the ambiance and the service. The Manager (Sasha) goes over and beyond and never fails to smile. THANK YOU, thank you Maykadeh for making my birthday memorable.
author: Samineh H.

description: Ok...maykadeh is one of the best Persian restaurants in Northern California. Their kabobs are always on point.  Why do they lose a star ? I always order Shirazi salad with my food and this is the only Persian restaurant I have ever been to that puts parsley instead of mint leaves in their salad.  Someone please fix this!!!!!!
author: David S.

description: Came here on Saturday Nowruz for lunch, happy with everything, the lamb tongue is the bomb here, great flavors, melt in your mouth texture, the lime flavor sauce is finger licking good...
author: Jean Q.

description: I've been coming here for 20 years and most recently came here twice in a week and I'm so happy the quality of this place still stands. The staff was attentive and nice. All the kebabs were moist and delicious, the stews, salads, the appetizers, bread, yogurt, wine, drinks, and dessert were all excellent. We came on a Thurs night and then a Sat night and I did notice that the kebabs were on the saltier side on Sat than Thurs. Maybe they season stuff heavier on the weekends or it was just a random thing but we noticed.
author: Vivian L.

description: I've only been once, loved the food. It was a Saturday night, we were surrounded by Persian-speaking people who had dressed up for a night out -- a really lovely experience. The favorite dish at our table was a chicken dish in a tamarind sauce.
author: Andy B.

description:
First of all, I have to mention that , food is perfect . Real persian food which is delicious . I've tried a lot of places in the city , especially where offering kebabs and etc. But this place is perfect. The basmati rice is special one , i've never met this kind of rice anywhere . 

Even , 
I tried to order online via eat24 , and I asked for butter , bread and some vegetables which they are offering in the restaurant for free , and they put them into my order . 

Its delicious place , and really good ! 
I recommend to anyone and I can discuss anything about this place , who gives bad review they r totally wrong
author: Jay M.

description:
So I looked this place up on Yelp and was really excited to see the great reviews.  There's not a lot of good Persian food in Seattle, and I know SoCal has plenty, so I figured this would be great too... boy, I was so wrong!  I cook Persian food at home and I get as much of it as I can when I'm down in the OC, so I've had my fair share of good and bad Persian food.

I ordered the Maykadeh Soltani which consists of rice, grilled tomato, koobideh kebab, and barg kebab.  It looked and smelled great when it came out.  I dug in immediately and even forgot to put on sumac the first few bites.  The meat was kind of tough and the flavor was off... I'm not sure what it was, but it's not what I'm used to having.  The koobideh was a little bit better, but it still wasn't hitting the spot.  It seemed as if it was missing something, or the mixture of onions, herbs, and spices were off.  The tomato was also undercooked and wasn't quite ripe. I usually finish this before I run out of meat and rice, but this time I just left it on the side after about 3 bites.  Hopefully I went on an off night, but I doubt i'd go back  again for the $30 price tag.  

Also they only take Visa and MC, no AMEX for you business travelers...

The place itself was pretty and had an upscale feel, but overall, I am very disappointed.  :-(  Maybe next time I'll find something better in SF.
author: Diana C.

description: Hands down, they have the best Kabob barg I have eaten in my entire life. The only reason I am not giving this place 5 stars is the fact that it is overpriced. In general they have very good customer service, valet parking, and a nice and clean environment.
author: Adorina B.

description:
I would like to think I'm an adventurous person when it comes to food and other "extracurricular" activities.

Variety is the spice of life and I will eat almost anything. Grasshoppers, wax moth larvae, ox penis, pig snout, chicken testicles, fish eyeballs, I've eaten these all and I'm always looking for the next adventurous food item to devour.

I adore offal and Maykadeh's menu sold me with their offal delicacies like lamb tongue, lamb head, brains and feet (halal menu also available). However, I have not been having the best of luck with new restaurants lately and Maykadeh is sadly one of them.

I only ate a packaged ramen that day so I was anxiously anticipating dinner at Michelin recommended (not to be confused with Michelin starred) Maykadeh only to sorely regret it (literally) later on.

Make no mistake, I love Persian food and what we had at Maykadeh for the most part was delicious. We started dinner with complimentary pita bread which was nice and toasty but we had no idea what to do with the accouterments of raw onion, radish, basil, and butter: http://bit.ly/11ULXib. I think they forgot the feta cheese? *Sigh* 

A must order, the Lamb Tongue ($15) was incredibly soft and was swimming in a divinely creamy sauce of sour cream, saffron and lime: http://bit.ly/Xt1Vs7. The lamb tongue is one of the top three tongues I've tasted; aside from Mr. NSS' of course. The intensely rich, liver-like Brain ($15) would have been more manageable to eat and enjoyable had it been chopped down before cooking. I felt like I was on an episode of Fear Factor tearing into a hunk of mystery meat: http://bit.ly/WTS5Dr. Not sexy. I would skip this. The much raved about Koobideh ($14.75) of ground Angus and lamb was tender and well-spiced though I favor Lavash's more because it's more flavorful and the char marks giving it a smoky nuance: http://bit.ly/12z5kx7. I loved the aromatic basmati rice which was a perfect canvas for the koobideh. Don't forget to order a side of the tangy Cucumber and Yogurt Sauce ($6) for a refreshing accompaniment to your meal: http://bit.ly/TUFAYg.

Service was just as pleasant as the professional and cordial staff. The crisp white linen tables, shiny gold striped chairs and banquettes, and warm pink decor was classy and romantic (albeit circa 1990s). The availability of valet ($10) makes parking a breeze in this otherwise parking nightmare part of SF.

As we left Maykadeh, I had every intention of giving them 4 solid stars.

Several hours pass...

Severe stomach cramping ensues and the next thing I know, I was hugging the porcelain throne with my ass cheeks. For 36 hours (and counting), I never thought I could do so many butt exercises sitting down but I did.

Lesson learned.

From now on, all my adventurous endeavors will take place behind closed doors...in the bedroom. 

The End.
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Great food, generous portions, substandard service, horrible parking situation unless you're going to do valet, and quite pricey compared to other Persian restaurants.
author: Food K.

description: The food here is terrible. Overpriced, small-portioned, greasy, oily, and just full of fat. We ordered chicken chelo and beef chelo. Both were spongy and dripping of oil. Made me feel disgusting. Told the manager about it, he couldn't care less. No need to come to this over-priced, snobby restaurant.
author: Raahim A.

description: Simply awful. The food doesn't worth the quality. The waitress are very rude and we didn't feel welcome at all. They were kind of in hurry that we should leave the place soon. I never come to the place again and I felt embarrassed in front of my guest.
author: Ali M.

description: Maykadeh has the best chicken & beefkoobideh in SF. Their white rice is delicious as well. They serve really good yogurt with cucumber, it reminds me of the delicious food back home in Lebanon. I definitely recommend this place for all the persian food lovers.
author: Jaafar L.

description:
Mmmmmm..... I love me some Persian food!

Delicious! Their food is very consistent and always gives me the warm and fuzzies. I usually order their delivery so my experience is a bit different. I am Iranian and ordering delivery from Maykardeh is my idea of comfort food.

The food is really great, but often times there is one item they slightly drop the ball on (otherwise, I would give them 5 stars)

They also are a tad overpriced and have odd menu items that throw me off a bit. Its still the best Iranian delivery food (partially because there are no other options)
author: Farnaz K.

description: Best Persian restaurant in town by far! Excellent food, perfect quality. I am Persian and I know what the homemade good quality Iranian food is!
author: Mohammad K.

description: I've had lots of Persian food in Boston. Ever since moving to sf, I've been trying to find similar quality. Maykadeh fits my needs. I had chicken with cranberry rice (excellently unique) and afterwards, I topped it off with the faloodeh, a rice ice cone like snack with sour cherry dressing. It was amazing. Now my mouth is in heaven
author: George L.

description: Kabob falvor, quality and techique is on point.
author: Nima J.

description: Simply the best Persian food in the Bay Area. I've been going here for 20+ years, just like home cookin'. Order the Joojeh Soltani if you're a newbie, otherwise, order your favorite dish.
author: Yo M.

description: Their food is pricey but the portions are big and enough for two people. Finding a parking spot in this neighborhood is not easy, but this place has valet parking.
author: Saharnaz N.

description:
This was really great food.  Definitely enjoyed my experience here.  We came with an authentic Iranian friend of ours who recommended this as the best in the area.  He said that while its not like his mom made (is it ever?), it came very close.  Which I think is the greatest compliment someone can give to a meal.  This is a Persian restaurant that specializes in kabobs and stews.  

I got ghorme sabze (a lamb stew) and my wife got the chicken koobideh (a kebab).  My dish was basically a lamb shank that was cooked in this dark stew of different spices and vegetables.  The lamb literally fell off the bone - it was perfectly tender and not at all tough.  The dish came with rice as well.  This isn't the forgettable cheap kind you get at asian restaurants - this was rice cooked up well and the rice on its own tasted yummy!  I mixed up the stew into the rice and went to town - happy camper here.  

My wife's kebab also came with rice and 2 large skewers of the meat.  The portion I tried was very tender, juicy, and delicately seasoned.  Another winner.  

The prices here are a little more than I am used to - for 2 skewers and the rice (my wife's entree) cost 20 bucks.  That seemed a little on the high side to me but you could tell they put more care into their food than the regular middle eastern restaurants.  

Its not pretentious or anything but it seemed much classier than your typical kebab/gyro place.  Cutlery, silverware, napkins, etc all were classy.  Not to say you need to get dressed up to come here - but a lot of people were.  

I think this place is the real deal as my Iranian friend attested to its authenticity.  Good food - moderate prices - and really nice ambience (classy).
author: Venk R.

description:
Took me 30 minutes to find a parking spot, I highly recommend you use the Valet. 

Food was great, I got the eggplant dip to start.
Chicken breast, and beef koobideh. Really nice, and tasty.

My friends liked their food, we will definitely be back!
author: Moe A.

description: Chicken kabob and shirazi salad are my go to. I love there food. Get there early because parking is tough.
author: Rania S.

description: Chicken k is the way to go. Delicious and the rice is excellent too. Loses 1 star because it's a bit over priced, by about 20%
author: Sai S.

description:
If you know Persian food, this place is it. The stews are great. I had soltani and the Mrs Bademjan (aubergene) Stew. We shared. Yum. I Pigged out. 

Try it, you will like it.

nuff said
author: Sia M.

description: Average Persian restaraunt. Their Koobideh was very mediocre. And for $18 the size of the kabobs was dissapointing. There are much better places in San Jose. Their service was lacking even when there was nobody there.
author: Darius A.

description:
I have been coming here for twenty years! This is the best persian restaurant
in the city. Everything on the menu is fabulous. Start with hot pita bread and feta
cheese to die for. The saffaron rice is the best in S.F. I bet they would  take the pepsi challage on this one. The meats and kabobs are sesaoned beautifully.BABA Ganoush
is truley spectacular. In fact all my middle eastern friends love this place, that
should be a direct indication of how good it is. The atmosphere is loud, however
coming from a big Italian family I am used to it. Pomagranate martini to wash it all
down. The whole table loved it!!!!!!
author: Mia A.

description:
Recently, I made the mistake of ordering food from this "restaurant" on EAT24. I am honestly baffled by how this place has earned 4 stars or even met health SF health standards. I'm just going to cut right to the chase...they served me RAW chicken. That is correct, my poultry was uncooked and raw. It's like they diced up raw chicken thigh, coated it in a bland yellow sauce, and called it that "Joojeh Kebab". Unfortunately I realized that it was under cooked after eating a whole piece. I write this to you all pre-illness, I'm hoping nothing comes of this, but eating RAW UNDERCOOKED CHICKEN IS ACTUALLY TERRIBLE FOR YOU AND THE ODDS ARE NOT IN MY FAVOR. Oh, and when I called the place to complain about this egregious mistake, they offered me EAT24 credits....WHAT?!? YOU SERVED ME UNCOOKED POULTRY THAT COULD VERY WELL RESULT IN A BACTERIAL INFECTION AND YOU OFFER ME A CREDIT TO EAT24??? I don't understand what kind of establishment they are running here but if you have a death wish order the chicken from this disgusting place.

Probably a moot point by now but just to top things off, their bread and hummus was awful. It was like dipping cardboard in a ground mushy paste that they serve prisoners in the penitentiary. If you enjoy the food here you've probably never head real Middle Eastern food and are extremely uncultured. Waiting to see Chef Robert Irvine tear this place down with a sledgehammer on the next episode of Restaurant Impossible.
author: Waseel A.

description: The best persian food in the bay area. Hands down! The closest to moms cooking it gets. Come here, you wont be disappointed.
author: Parasto S.

description: Excellent food and service. I learned about this place from an Uber driver proud of his heritage. I'm so glad I listened. The flavored were refreshing. We got a tomato/feta appetizer and an eggplant appetizer (not baba ganouche sp?) and a lamb kebab and a chicken breast kebab and shared family style. Delish! Followed it up with the pear dessert and a piece of homemade baklava. A satisfying experience indeed.
author: Renee L.

description: I would've gave this place 5 stars if I left a review the very first time I came in. The very first time, I got their home made "dough", which is a yogurt drink and it was absolutely delicious. I went on about it for months and recommended the place to everyone I knew who liked Persian food. Not only was that delicious but so was my kabob barg and my friend's soltani. We were satisfied with the delicious food along with the shirazi salad and tadeeg with stew. The customer service was great and they checked up on us a couple of times. Although, as each time passes by that we went here it was a hit or miss with the dough drink. But the service was always wonderful and so was the food. I will always return if I'm in the area.
author: Kiana R.

description: This place sucks. Everything we ordered was mediocre at best. The rice taste was off and the chicken and beef was lacking in flavor and quality. The only okay thing about this place was the ice cream.
author: Sugar Q.

description: Great koobideh,not greasy and moist. Khoresh ghamei was warm and great flavor. The salmon was beautiful and delicious. Ordered tasty Persian martini, fresh juice and refreshing. Friend ordered a margaritta and said it was the best margaritta she had in a while. Great service. It's not dressy but if you wear jeans they don't make you feel uncomfortable. My favorite Persian resturant in all of California.
author: Ehya T.

description:
When we came for dinner on a Saturday night we made a reservation probably like 45 minutes beforehand but ended up being a bit late because we couldn't find parking. However when we got there, he didnt even know we had a reservation. Granted we had made it so last minute, but it seems like if you are allowing us to be able to make a reservation at that time, then it should probably work. We ended up having an extremely long wait with not seats and really crowded small lobby.

WITH THAT BEING SAID, the rest of the night was amazing! The wine we delicious and the good was large in quantity and super authentic and yummy gourmet. Felt fancy. The service was also great and she will our wine glasses really attentively which is uncommon. We ate so much and loved it all :)

Hate to say it, but worth the long wait when we got there!
author: Alexandra W.

description: The best Persian food that I have ever had in my life... And I lived in Persia (Iran) for a while and I am Persian. They know how to give the food flavor and make it juicy. It gives me such a cozy and happy feel. Too bad I live 380 miles away. I LVE this place sooooo much. I give it a 10 out of 5 stars. I recommend the Barg and the Jojeh Kebab. I LVE IT.
author: Nick N.

description: It was awesome experience. Respectful manager with delicious food and REYHOON . I'll be come back again . Just try it once ; you will be loving it . All the best ...
author: Amir H A.

description: Friendly and responsive staff. Delicious food. Real flowers on linen tablecloth. Hard to park. 12$ valet.
author: lucas t.

description: The Chicken kabob was very good and juicy. The beef Koobideh was very juicy but lacked seasoning. We tried the normal rice and another rice they were both just okay. The prices seemed a bit steep for Persian food.
author: Omid M.

description: My GF and I probably order from here 3-4x a month. I realized this is far and away the most common place for us to order food so it must be good. I don't write many reviews but, somehow, I just felt compelled to comment on how much we like Maykadeh.
author: Eric P.

description:
I have been here few times already so I obviously love the food. It is by far one of the best. 

I highly recommend their mast-o- musir garlic yoghurt it is alot of yoghurt to be served as a starter, more like a side dish. Their sabzee is really good (very similar to a spinach stew) and has the most delicious soft lamb shank. I have also had the fasanjoon here, it is a thick brown sweet and sour sauce not to everyones taste. Speaking of that maybe refrain from pacha too; a lightly spiced boil up of lamb bones (hooves included). I personally like it and think they do it to prefection, but it has a leather like after taste if it is your first time. Their grills and kabobs are fantastic if you are not feeling like being an Anthony Bourdain. A must try is their ice cream quite sweet but a perfect end to a great meal. 

Why not 5 stars uhmmm their waiting staff are not quite there which is a shame because their managers are wonderful.
author: Nora B.

description: Ordered a home delivery from them, they delivered it early and warm and it was deeeeelicious. This isn't the first time that I order a delivery in this city but it's the first time that I have received fresh, warm and tasty food. I highly highly recommend this place.
author: Hamda A.

description:
So I been really wanting to try this place for years and a few weeks ago I had my chance.  I ordered the (sultani) which has a skewer of filet and a skewer of ground beef kabob...$38 for this dish by the way...same dish in Alborz in SF is $21.95...complete rip off!!! The kabob portions are not even big and it has very little rice...
Anyway I ordered it anyway because I wanted to taste this dish because of all the hype! 
I am native to Iran but I grew up here in Cali so I know good from bad in our food and the quality of service we expect here in the states. (And I served all through college) 
One guy was serving the whole restaurant he was good till he got busy then he was running around like a chicken with no head...he was a one man show and his service suffered towards the end...took us about 25 min before we got our check (he passed the check books out to about 6 tables) he carried them around with him till he was ready to pass them all out at the same time! 
Now the food...the ground beef was delicious but the filet was just ok not any different (not juicier or especially tender) than the rest of the restaurants I have been to... I got it medium/medium rare too by the way cause I don't destroy my meat like most Iranians and cook it to death lol  
My friend got the chicken and she wasn't too crazy about it either...I tasted it and it was ok nothing special 
Anyway this was my experience 
Overpriced by A LOT! 
mediocre service 
Ok food 
I would definitely go to Alborz next time I am in the city for Persian food!
author: Patty H.

description:
I had a reservation on Saturday night. On arrival the place was packed but we were seated within 5 minutes of the appointed time. Food was excellent and large portions.  Raw onion and mint served with flat bread. Shirazi salad was fresh. I liked my Koobideh and my wife liked her lamb shank stew (ghorme sabzee).

Tables are close together and it was pretty noisy but not annoying, just lively.
Totally satisfied.
author: Steve F.

description: You don't have so many options in SF when it comes to Persian food and in general they are not something to write home about but among that few Maykadeh offers the best food. Don't get chicken there. Go for ghormeh sabzi or kebab.
author: Omid A.

description:
The Maykadeh is truly our FAVORITE restaurant in San Francisco, of all time, Persian or otherwise.  We have been enjoying the restaurant and its excellent food and superb service since it first opened!  The owner and his wife are proud of their Maykadeh and we are excited each and every time we enter our Persian home away from home, albeit neither of us are of Persian descent or from anywhere in the region of the former great Persian Empire...

The food is always fresh, perfectly prepared, beautifully served, generous in portion and the menu choices richly represent the heritage of one of the world's most important cuisines.

You must not miss the Saffron and Lime Lamb Tongue Appetizer, the Roasted Elephant Garlic Yogurt 'Mast-o-Musir', the Bottom Rice Dish 'Tah-dig', the Beef and Lamb Grilled Kebab 'Chelo Kebab Koobideh' (Be certain to order an egg yolk for your rice), any of the lamb shank dishes as all are extraordinary, especially the 'Ghormeh Sabzi' (Fresh Green Herbs and Kidney Beans) and the 'Khoresht Bademjan' (Eggplant and Tomato), the Dill, Lima Bean and Chicken Dish 'Baghali Polow', the Yogurt and Dried Mint Drink 'Doogh', the Rose and Pistachio Ice Cream 'Bastani', and just about everything else on the menu.  All choices are superb -- You will not be disappointed except that you cannot try more as the portions are both huge and filling...

We cannot say enough but suffice it to say, that the Maykadeh could well be your favorite restaurant too after just a single visit.  Thank for for over thirty-two years of enjoying your delicious food.  Merci!
author: Bruce I.

description: We always get take out from this place. They have good quality and tasty food. You should definitely try kashk-bademjan, soltani,and tongue
author: Sara K.

description:
We had friends visiting from So Cal on Labor day weekend and decided to have dinner at Maykadeh based on Yelp reviews. Throughout the time we spent there, the service was lacking and the staff was unfriendly and had a "don't give a shit" attitude. I believe you cannot have a good culinary experience when the staff is never smiling.

We were seated after 30 minutes and given food menus. We waited patiently for the wine list for 15 minutes before one of us lost patience and asked for it. We were hungry and decided on our appetizer order while waiting for the wine list, but they were too busy to take our first order for the next few minutes. So, 30 minutes into the escapade and all we had was free pita (no appetizers or drinks). The appetizers were out fairly quickly once we ordered and were decent.

We were ready to order the main course and one of our friends wanted to substitute plain rice for Bagadi Pollo and the waitress wanted to charge $5 extra, which my friend was ok with. I expect that a "fine-dining" place to do better when we are bound to spend $250+ All our entrees were decent, but we've all had better before!

At the end of this, they charged us 18-20% gratuity for a party of 5. Maybe, they had a clause somewhere which said that, but we felt that they knew their service sucked and didn't want to lose out on tips.

We won't go back and would recommend our friends to avoid it as well.
author: Selma A.

description:
Highly recommend!!

Went there for the 5th time in the last month today! Wow man, this place is legitimate. The Soltani is to die for! Prepared with such detail and perfection from the Filet Mignon Kabob known as "Barg" to the season ground beef kabob known as the "Koobideh". The rice is phenomenal!  

I ordered the Filet Mignon with the Stroganoff sauce today. WOW! I mean wow! The sauce takes 3 days to make and it is prepared with precision. These guys know their food down to a science but prepare it as though it's an art form. I really could not believe how tasty this dish was. 

The staff is amazing! After going here so many times I have been acquainted with the hosts Mehran and Sasha. They are the nicest and most accommodating people in the restaurant business that I have encountered. Hands down the top Persian Restaurant in the Bay Area and probably in all of California. I have eaten at all of the top places in LA, Santa Monica, Irvine and OC. Maykadeh in San Francisco is the best of the best!

All of the food here is amazing! I am probably going to go here more often and explore other dishes on the menu.
author: Sam N.

description:
Amazing Persian, and great for delivery. The Kubideh and Fesenjoon are perfect. The kashk-e-bademjan is super rich and super tasty. Good doogh too.

Will try the brain and lamb tongue sometime...
author: Sam C.

description:
I absolutely LOVE this restaurant! 

My family of four eat here as often as we can because we all can find something we enjoy - and that includes a picky 13 year old! The service is always prompt and friendly and sometimes they'll bring us free samples of new items. Highly recommend Maykadeh!
author: Judy J.

description: It's exceedingly rare to find a restaurant with consistently excellent food,  decent prices,  and a truly classy atmosphere and staff (who are also very hardworking). As a bay area native,  I've never associated North Beach with Persian food,  but this restaurant is a true gem,  and one that I am certainly planning to be a return customer for.
author: Zachary M.

description: Great service and fast delivery! Very authentic food and the hummus is spot on. Will be a regular!
author: Nicole T.

description:
well i heard the name for long time from my friends,so i decided to give it a chance and tried Koobide which was not comparable to other Persian restaurants in Bay area(especially Anar).
it is also alittle more expensive than some other restaurants. overal my experience was Meh!
author: Mohammad M.

description:
I've been to every Persian restaurant in Los Angeles and my family has the best cooking, but this is hands down one of the best top 1% of Persian food I have had. Amazing.
The rice, tadig, stews, fish and chicken are unbelievable. 
Highly recommended, will come back.
author: John A.

description:
Maykadeh, oh maykadeh, how I heart thee. My fickle palate goes boom boom at the thought of your succulent stews and fluffy mounds of golden basmati polo. how I long to shove a spoonful of that tasty eggplant dip into my mouth. And wash it back with that fizzy yogurt beverage the cute Asian server- who appears to speak perfect Persian - calls dugh. Oh yes please. 

Outside of LA land, this place rocks Persian food like grannie working her magic in her kitchen. The name of the place means "wine (may) house (kadeh)". Have the kabob with a bottle of Shiraz.
author: Jahan T.

description: One of the best persian food around sf. We travel 2 hrs to come to eat at this place. I love their sultani
author: Ben L.

description: Tasty, fresh, tender lamb and fluffy rice are a winner here. A little on the pricey side but worth the attention and deliciousness.
author: Matt A.

description:
Being Persian and loving Persian food we decided that we had to go to the Persian restaurant that we have been hearing about. We didn't make reservations as we were going for lunch. We got there and were greeted by the gentleman in the front and seated immediately. 

Once we sat down they brought over pita bread and sabzi (veggies). 

Our complete order was:

Drinks:
1 corona
4 diet cokes 

Appetizers:
Mast-o-musir
Tahdig w/ ghameh. 

Entree:
Beef soltani w/ rice
Chicken kabob (breast) w/ rice

Let me start off my saying again that I am Persian. I have tried all Persian restaurants in LA and OC. Not to mention my mom is the best Persian cool ever. Walking in I thought maybe the place could use a little make over. I was hoping that all the good reviews weren't just a thing of the past and the food quality had changed but NO. 

For those of you who don't know what mast is.. It's yogurt and this particular one has garlic and shallots. I typically love this dish but this one I feel like was sheep or lamb yogurt and I didn't love it. The tahdig appetizer is always no matter what- what you order when you go to any Persian restaurant. When ordering tahdig you order a stew with it. We got the ghameh. It had chunks of lamb which I really don't love but was still good. 

They brought our main dish. We had the meats on one plate and our own plate of rice. I was skeptical of trying the koobideh because as I mentioned before I don't like lamb and the meat they use is a mixture of lamb and beef. I tried a piece first. Ummm. WOW. Not gammy at all. Juicy. FULL of flavor. The barg. WOW just as good. Barg kabob is really hard to make and to make juicy?? Never even knew it could be made so perfectly! Tender, juicy and flavorful. Of course I had a side of onions. I couldn't eat my kabob any other way. Yes. Raw onions with every bite. So delicious. The chicken was good too. Not seasoned like your typical Persian chicken kabob but that's what made it so good. Tender and juicy. You could really taste the basil and it was a fresh element to it. I should mention that the rice was also really good. Typically Persian restaurants lack on the quality of the rice but not here. You can tell the quality of everything is impeccable  

Overall: I am thoroughly satisfied. Our total bill was $88 for two people. Not super cheap but for the best of Persian food. Worth it. Considering you go to a steakhouse or any other restaurant and pay just that much if not more for one person. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone and I definitely hope to have the opportunity to go back!
author: Ida A.

description: My Iranian friend invited me and my friends here for an authentic meal- her favorite restaurant in the city, and it didn't disappoint!
author: Monica S.

description:
This is is perhaps the only Persian restaurant I have eaten at that actually that does a good job representing the cuisine. The two times I've been here, the second being last night, have been lovely. Their kebab barg, which is basically a filet mignon, is super juicy and delectable. And I LOVE their warm pita bread and sabzi (herbs). 

Their koobideh (ground beef) is great too. They also have nice Persian ice cream (bastani) with a light saffron flavor and I usually don't eat Persian ice cream because of all the rose water and high amount of saffron! Try the poached pear, it's awesome. 

Although it is pricey for Persian food, it is totally worth it.
author: Bahar A.

description:
Kashke Bademjan? (roasted eggplant dip w spices?) way better than hummus

Joojeh kebab - gotta appreciate the much juicier chicken thighs
Chelo-kebab - beef and lamb grounded together? Yes! delicious!
Even the roasted tomato goes well with veggies and rice.

First time I tried fresh pita with butter, mint and radish. Always fresh and tasty
author: Ken S.

description: The food was good but not outstanding. I lived in London for a while where the Iranian community is much bigger and you can find Persian restaurants quiet easily. So my expectations were maybe a bit too high as this is one in my favorite one. The service was good and the portion were big but wasn't impressed by my meal flavor.
author: Zoe P.

description:
ZERO stars!

Discriminatory against service animals! We are taking immediate action with the necessary bureaus.

11/08-We had a medical service dog with us and we were turned away. The manager turned us away after telling us we could sit anywhere before he saw we had a service dog. We made it clear it was a service animal and attempted to show the tags but he opened the door to show us out. He said they only allow service animals for the blind and kept on saying "It's Halal-It's Halal" what the heck is Halal? We looked it up only to find that he was saying something untrue. He told us to look it up as it was the law they could not allow us there and therefore he lied. They are not the exception to the rule. We told them we would follow on this as it is discriminatory.

DO NOT EAT HERE. GO to another Persian restaurant instead. Many better ones.
author: CR C.

description:
First of all the prices there are not $$ its a fair $$$ - restaurant. All Entrees are $30 and more

For the price we paid it was meh. Too much rice, all the meats were served with the same sauce.... -- I was surprised by it...
author: Anelya S.

description:
There were four in our party -- two were not vegetarians. We stayed for close to three hours and never felt rushed. The food was great.

I had the barley vegetable soup -- just delicious! In fact, it filled me up but I did manage to have some of the baba ganoush I also ordered; the smoky, lemony freshness of that dish was another treat. I took the rest home and mixed it with hard boiled eggs for breakfast. Don't knock it till you've tried it...I''m on to something here.

My partner had a vegetarian eggplant dish which seemed to have a similar sauce to the lamb dish our friends had. An appetizer of feta cheese and roasted tomato was shared at the table as well as a "fancy salad." No misses with any of the dishes. ;-)

When we first arrived -- 7:15 p.m. -- it was a very family crowd and I wondered if we'd feel comfortable but thank goodness San Francisco is light on snootiness. We had a great time!
author: Leslie K.

description:
First visit to this Persian restaurant with my former co-worker.  It was very enjoyable but a little pricey not your daily stop for a quick bit kind of place.

The Soltani (skewered thin slices of filet mignon and skewered Koobideh i.e. lamb + beef, marinated in lemon juice and onion) was delicious, mouth watering and outstanding.  Highly recommended for meat kebab lovers.  You won't regret it.  Their Basmati rice was out of this world.

Be sure to try their Persian Lady (vodka and pomegranate juice), the Persian tea, and the Makhlaut with rice stick.
author: Thomas L.

description:
If youre Persian/Iranian, you will only come here to take someone to a "nice" formal Persian dinner. 

I've been here many times over the past decade and it hasn't improved or changed. 

Some Pros
+ Valet
+ Decent Ambiance
+ Gormeh Sabzi
+ Mast o Khiar 
+ Salad Shirazi

Cons (um everything)
- The Joojeh and Koobideh - dry, tasteless 
- Zereshk Polo - sucks
- SERVICE - horrible
- no LAVASH bread.... 
- no Family style (only set entrees)


Please do yourself a favor and eat real persian food at Anar in SOMA (new) or Lavash. I also love Rose Market in Mtn View for Kabobs (south bay has more options for quality, traditional dishes) fyi, good rice is VERY hard to come by outside of a Persian home. 

But jeeze, Maykadeh ruined an evening for me. I was taking a very special person to eat Persian food for the first time and so I thought we would come to the "best" persian place in SF - the service was horrible, food mediocre at best, overall I left feeling upset and dissatisfied with everything. 

I have made sure to share my horrible experience with other people who have said they are going or want to go to Maykadeh. Persian food is delicious and MUST be served with a smile. It is family style cuisine in every sense.
author: Shanna N.

description: Mmmmmmm!!!best Persian food for the price that I've encountered! The atmosphere was a little bland but I didn't notice because the food was so delicious.
author: Kat M.

description:
I cannot recommend this place enough! Everything I have tried has exceded my expectations.  With so many mediocre restaurants in North Beach this one is a diamond in the rough. 

The kabobs are amazing, so much flavor. And the hummus tastes home made with a sprinkle of love.  

And the lamb shank with eggplant is hands down the best lamb I have ever had. 

The owner is great and the service is modest but attentive.  I love this place and I love to see them busy.  Cant wait to come back.
author: Jacklyn H.

description:
This will bum out SF foodies but there are certain things that LA just does better. Persian food is clearly one of them. 

That being said, this is the best that the city has to offer from a relatively limited selection. It's been consistently good since the 80s and does a good job with the joojeh, koobideh and my favorite, Barg. 

A helpful tip: don't go into a Persian restaurant expecting good hummus. It's not really our thing. It's like being disappointed if the Miso soup you order at a Chinese restaurant isn't good. 

Also, belly dancers are never a good sign.
author: Baron C.

description: The food was good. Large portions and the free appetizers (onions, basil and pita bread) were a nice touch. Service was slow and somewhat inattentive.
author: Daniel C.

description:
I think it is the best choice of all Iranian food restaurants in San Francisco. 
Food is great and ambiance is nice.
author: Ari M.

description:
When you're adding the 381st review to a place, you have got to figure it's all been said before.

Except this: I got a linguistics, culinary, and history lesson free with our meal! Ghormeh, a style of Persian cooking, was actually something I hadn't seen on a menu before, and so I asked our waiter about it. He not only described the food, but the history of the cooking technique, and his feelings on the French taking the word "Gourmet" and calling it their own. It was really a fun an fascinating conversation.

The service was very quick on a very busy Thursday night, the food was quite outstanding -- hot pita with a roasted-garlic-laced hummus for appetizer, followed by a not-quite-too-sweet pomegranate chicken and a lamb shank in a slightly spicy spinach curry-like sauce. My partner was thrilled with her wine selection, and boy oh boy did they make me a tasty Old Fashioned.

Having just moved down from Portland, OR -- I'll note that we were probably just a little too happy with the upper-scale ambiance and white linens (not that it doesn't exist in Portland, it's just harder to find). Still, it was a great dining experience, and one that really isn't too expensive given how much food you get, the quality of the service, and the location of the restaurant.

Oh, and yes, the rice really was that good. We both walked home overfull, but happy. I'm very pleased to be living nearby.
author: Amy P.

description:
Yummy but expensive. 

I shouldn't complain expensive as its a fine dining place. All the dishes were wonderful including the desserts.

Ambiance was good with lite colors and the service was remarkable
author: Sharan N.

description:
Ghormeh sabzi is always deliciousness. Rice is fluffy and buttery. Kebab has that amazing Persian kebab taste. 

I love the neighborhood it's in too. It's a pleasant walk from the BART station and nice to walk around. Highly recommend for meeting family and friends - reliably great Persian food in a lovely setting.

EDIT: Removing  a star as unfortunately last time my family ate here on my recommendation, they told me the chicken wasn't cooked through. I have gotten take out from here dozens of times and never had an issue, but I didn't order the chicken.
author: Cynthia M.

description: The food is garbage & overpriced & the portions are small. Customer service is even worse. They're rude & nasty. If you want Persian food in SF, go to Lavash. Their food is much better & they treat you like a human being.
author: Fred F.

description:
I was very disappointed with the food quality.
Koobideh was terrible. Barg was bad too. Jujeh was uncooked. Service was ok. I wont come back to this restaurant.
author: Mahdi B.

description:
So, Maykadeh gets one star knocked off right off the bat...we weren't seated for our 7:30 PM reservation until after 8:00 PM.

The food was good, but, in general, not great. Of the three things that I tried, only the kashke bademjan was really noteworthy; the feta spread and Maykadeh kebab were just okay.

Top all that off with the fact this restaurant is far from cheap and the ambiance isn't even that great, and I'd probably tell you that I won't be going back to Maykadeh.
author: Dan F.

description:
I'm from Los Angeles, and my family and I decided to visit San Francisco for the second or third time. We looked for Persian restaurants, and we stumbled across Maykadeh. 

I ordered a koobideh. And to be completely honest, it was the worst koobideh I've ever tasted in my life. As Amir said, the koobideh was burnt, and the rice was soaked in oil. Also, the prices are very high. 

I had a better experience in Alborz.
author: Eric B.

description:
Delicious cocktails. Some of the best chicken koobideh I've had anywhere, both light and very flavorful. Excellent lamb shank braised with leek, onion and dried lime. Excellent service. 

Skip the ubiquitous Italian spots - at least occasionally - and go Persian!
author: Kevin K.

description:
Yummy food but not so kind staff :( but I would go again for the food and just disregard the help.  I sat down and was kindly given a menu and some bread and greens. About five minutes later a woman comes up to ask "What do you want?". no prelude, welcome, or introduction, but that's cool... we are cutting to the chase! I ask her about specials and for some explanation of things on the menu. Then she stands in front of me with her pen and pad again asking for my order. So I say I am still thinking/deciding. Then she stares with the pen to the pad. I say "you are rushing me. I need more time".  Per Shakespeare, she does the "exeunt".
Five mins later, she returns to take the order, and things are good. the food arrives. 
I am convinced that I think things are all off because I am/was hungry and misinterpreting things. But once I was full and asked for the check, I realized it wasn't me. She didn't look me in the eye ever again and even ignored any "thank you"s and an extra thanks for giving me extra time.  She brings my change and places it on the table again with no words or a look. I thank her again as she walks way then realize I keep saying "thank you". Anyway I feel super pissy to be upset about her demeanor but I specifically took Uber across town to go there and was celebrating some good things that happened to me the day before :)
But like I said before, the food was f'ing awesome. Understand my dilemma? I think I am going to call Dr Laura or Suze Orman to see if I am denied from going back?
author: Ardalan M.

description:
Barg Kabob was A+
If you put aside the cinnamon taste, the GHEYMEH was very good
Shishlik was very very tender and nicely cooked except that it had the lamb smell if you know what I mean !!!
Kashkebademjoon, mast mooseer and ghorme sabzi, was very very good. 
Keep in mind I am very picky and give accurate critics. Overall I think this was the best persian food in bay area as it was for the first time I actually enjoyed a persian food in the bay area/valley/san jose !!
author: Parisa V.

description:
I'd never had Persian food before, but am now a huge fan of the cuisine!  We started with cocktails (full bar) and a plate of complimentary pita, onion, radish, basil.  We got a chicken koobideh, steak, shrimp, and chicken thighs.  All were really tasty!  The basmati rice was excellent as well.  $10 valet parking in a tough parking neighborhood was appreciated.  Service was good.  

We received a gift certificate from someone for this restaurant.  There was an expiration date that only lasted 6 months.  I get that having outstanding gift certificates can be an accounting nightmare, but I would suggest they give customers at least a year to use them.  It's not easy for out-of-towners to get into the city within 6 months, so give us a little break!
author: Marie B.

description: I had the yogurt and cucumber appetizer, a side of koobideh and the chicken walnut-pomegranate stew. I would recommend everything.
author: Amin S.

description:
I have multiple things to say, so best to put it in points. 
Food is really good. I don't remember the last time I had such good long grain rice. Not to mention the lamb stew.
The quantity of food is really good, too.
Service can be sloppy at times.
The part that made me give 2 stars instead of 4, they sent two sides (a salad and a yoghurt bowl) which we never ordered. We consumed them innocently thinking they were complimentary like the bread. 
When we pointed it out, the owner went back to speak with the server. 
Here is the interesting part. The one who took away our dishes, seemed to confirm that we had consumed those dishes, which is ridiculous, if you realize what she was trying to insinuate. We DID eat that stuff but we never ordered for it specially under the impression that it is complimentary. Then, the one who took our order too confirmed that we had ACTUALLY ordered those. All of this drama where we could see them exchanging words and disapproving looks as if we were lying. 
The saving grace was that the owner took off the extra charges. I made it a point to ask him a rhetorical question, "why would we lie?" and to tell him that the food was really good.
The least you expect from a pricey place is good food and common courtesy. If you don't want to admit your mistake, fine, but don't make it seem like the customer is a thief!
Of note is the fact that when I checked a lot of "not recommended" reviews here on Yelp, they all said similar things, more or less. There being some mistake and the staff not accepting it OR the staff not having common decency. Isn't that something? And why are those genuine reviews "not recommended?" Hmmm... 
I am now wondering if mine lands there, too!
author: Saurabh C.

description:
Horrible chelo kabab barg. The worst I ever tried in my life. I was there on Friday Dec 12, 2014  for lunch. No wonder there was not a single person there. Extremely overpriced $30 comparing to other Iranian restaurant  which charge 15 to 20 dollars for barg. 

Ali
author: Ali G.

description:
Few places can make kabab koobideh taste bad and mess up joojeh kabab, this place does...
We ordered Joojeh (chicken) kababs, which ended up being undercooked and disgusting, sent it back, they managed to burn the outside of the pieces but the inside was still uncooked and disgusting. 
Also on a different day tried their Ghormeh Sabzi, terrible... One of the worst Ghormeh Sabzis i have ever had, even worse than the ghormeh sabzi i make myself.
author: Ramoun M.

description: My visit was on september 5th in this place, good food and owner was very friendly.
author: Aph Rod G.

description: The lamb tongue appetizer is incredible, the fresh hit pita bread is amazing and the service and food is impeccable. Highly recommended for a delicious meal.
author: Judy L.

description: If I could give them six stars I would. This is Persian Cuisine at its best. You can not find better food than Maykadeh's anywhere else in the world.
author: Peter J.
