description:
Mmm  Meat.  This small charming restaurant does it well here. I loved their steak and koobidehs (ground meat skewers) it's well flavoured and if you know Chicago.  i would call it a Reza's equivalent. http://www.yelp.com/biz/rezas-restaurant-chicago-2

For lovers of exotic, they have Lamb tongue, lamb head and brain.  Interesting but... I was about to get on a plane so I'll experiment on a safer day!

Great service.  Never had a moment where we needed anything.  

Note**They do tend to over cook their steaks so if you want medium, order medium rare.
author: Gina K.

description:
I love this restaurant.

I used to eat meat, and when I did I would always love to come here for the Kabobs. The Barg was my favorite. A thinly cut and perfectly seasoned cut of beef. The Soltani is also amazing, a cut of Barg with a skewer of koobideh, ground beef with delicious spices. The saffron rice is also amazing. And I love the grilled tomato on the side.

I have become a pescatarian now (only eating seafood) and have grown to love their sturgeon. Unfortunately it is an exceedingly rare dish here. I've had it only once in the last two years because they never are able to get it in the restaurant. But if you call ahead and ask they'll let you know. The fish is perfectly prepared with this absolutely amazing mustard drizzled on top.

The service is perfect. 

The bar is also great. They make great drinks for pretty good prices.

There is also valet parking which is quite useful since finding parking in North Beach is a nightmare.
author: Melba I.

description: Loved their "barg" kabob! Everything else was average. The "koobideh" kabob could have been better. Found a bug in my water btw!!. Please keep things clean! Overall, had a fairly good experience there! The taste of the "barg" overachieved my expectations.
author: Niloofar A.

description: Excellent food and service. Prices reasonable. Waitresses friendly and very accommodating. The only thing I didn't like was how difficult it was to find parking nearby.
author: Chris N.

description:
I would say, go there the first opportunity you get. Amazing food, as close to authentic Persian food as it gets.

Their portions are huge. A dish is probably enough for 2 people with medium appetites. 

I recommend the Lamb Tongue dish.

Warning : The alcohol is a little pricey.
author: Rohit M.

description: This is the only Persian food delivery in SF, which is awesome that we even have that. But I feel like the food is always a little off. For $50+ delivery I get a mediocre meal delivered and they always forget something like where are the fresh herbs or the sumac? And it takes more than an hour for the delivery. Honestly, jump in the car and get easy parking at Alborz on Van Ness, it is less stressful, with better food and more affordable. Or better yet, make a Persian friend!
author: Shannon Z.

description: The hummus didn't have any flavor but the pita was good.  The baba ganoush was really salty and didn't have any flavor.  The chicken was undercooked and the vegetables were cooked in tons of butter.  I don't generally write negative reviews but the bad service was the final straw.  For the price of dinner, I was expecting better quality.
author: Corrie C.

description: Came here for a Saturday night dinner with 3 other people.  The food was very good.  We had the Kashke Bademjan (eggplant dip), Chelo-kebab koobideh (ground beef/lamb kebab), spicy joojeh (chicken kebab), and Barg (filet mignon kebab).  Everything was really, really good, and the cheapest entree, the koobideh, might have been the best.  An appetizer and three entrees was enough to share for all four people.  The cocktail was disappointing, but overall it was a tasty, reasonably priced nice dinner.
author: Simon L.

description:
Five of us went from South bay to SF for a day out. We stopped at Meykadeh for lunch. The 1st thing that I noticed was how high the prices were. Kubideh kabab for $16 !!! I really like the stews that have a whole lamb shank in them.  Typically it is made using beef stewing meat at homes. I ordered Ghormeh-sabzi stew. We also ordered Kubideh kabab, chicken kabab and chicken breast kabab. My stew was really good. Very tasty and well prepared. Make sure you separate the fat from the lamb shank before you dig in. I also tried a piece of chicken kabab which was very moist and tasty. The ambiance was very average. I was curious as how the prices differ from Alborz Persian cuisine on Van Ness, so I looked at their menu on Yelp and their website. In average, Meykadeh is $3-$4 more expensive per meal than Alborz. Their barg and soltani kababs are $10 more than Alborz and their mast-o-moosir is almost twice the price !
I would categorize Meykadeh as a bit pricey, but the location might be the reason.
author: Sam N.

description:
I went to Maykadeh for the first time last night.  The pronunciation of this restaurant is a bit tough, but I sounded it out for you at the bottom of this review.  :D 

First Impressions:
     Valet parking for $10 - cool option
     Easy to get a table  
     Contradicting ambience

Ambience: 
       What I mean by contradicting is that it is white-tablecloth, complete with a candle and a rose on every table.  However, the lighting was pretty bright and the clientele seemed to be dressed very casual.  Yelp says it is "romantic" and "classy", but I would definitely categorize Maykadeh as casual, despite it's desperate attempt to be a "romantic" fine dining restaurant.  

Food: 
         For appetizers, we ordered the Greek salad (average) and the Baba Ghanoush (excellent!).  The Baba Ghanoush was definitely the highlight. 
         As my entree, I tried the Chelo-kebab Koobideh, which is 2 skewers of a beef/lamb mixture and a very large portion of rice.  The rice could have used some flavor, but the meat was tender and the spices were yummy! 
         For dessert, I tried both the creme caramel and the poached pears with ice cream.  I would recommend the creme caramel (unless you have had my grandfather's, which is hard to beat).  The poached pears with ice cream was definitely different, which I liked, but it didn't really stand out.  


Conclusion:
      Maykadeh won't make-ya-day or break-ya-day.
author: Juliana K.

description:
This place is great for a variety of reasons it just makes you feel good when you walk in. I love Mediterranean food and I can't say I'm a good critic of it but I know what I like and this place knows what they are doing. 

First of all there is the plate of hot pita served with mint and feta are fantastic. For the amount of food you are about to ingest, the mint really helps with digestion.

For starters we went with Hummus and Baba Ghanoush which were perfect, really well done. We also added a new favorite of Kashke Bademjan, with just the right amount of kick, its eggplant prepared like you've never tasted before. I highly recommend trying this.   

My entry was Khoresht Bademjan which I was not too thrilled with because of the lime. This dish is not for every pallet and when they say there is lime in it, you can really taste that fact. If you are a fan of the savory and sour in a very Mediterranean way then go for it, otherwise I'd go with something else. Trust me there is plenty to choose from. 

Also I was super excited for the baby eggplant since that is one of my favorite vegetables, but it had been stewed in this lime sauce that I couldn't quite get a taste for which was a bit disappointing I must admit. Still although I did not have a taste for it, the dish was cooked perfectly, everything tasted as it was supposed to and no one detail was out of place.
author: Anna B.

description: I do not recommend this place. First the food wasn't that great. The Fesenjoon was too sweet, the Gheimeh was too salty, and the Koobideh wasn't properly cooked. I am a cook myself and I do not find the food that great. Second. the customer service was really bad. They overcharged us for a stew and when I told them the manager retorted that "it is not free, you know". I am still shocked on the way the behaved towards us and that they charged us for something that they didn't tell us. And later he came to our table telling us in a condescending tone that their customers do not bother over "a few dollars", implying that we are cheap. Incredible and outrageous. I do not recommend this place. Go to other Persian restaurants like Anar. Trust me, the food isn't that great especially considering their overpriced menu.
author: Farshad G.

description:
My wife and I live down the street from a relatively new persian restaurant in the Inner Sunset (Lavash).  We have eaten there several times and enjoyed it - so we wanted to figure out if we loved persian food or we just loved Lavash.

THE SERVICE:
Valet parking ($10) at Maykadeh was very helpful given the neighborhood and its lack of parking.  We walked into the (empty) restaurant and were greeted politely and taken to 4-person table, made from two 2-top tables.  They set both our menus in front of me and then proceeded to take apart the extra table.   I wish they had just put us a a two person table to begin with and the extra 3-seconds to nicely set the menu out in front of both of us would have been appreciated.  I always feel like I'm in a diner when they bring a stack of menus and set them in front of one person.

About 10-minutes after sitting waiting (remember, restaurant is empty) we were approached and asked if we wanted anything to drink.  I requested some water (surprised it took so long) and my wife a chardonnay. 

Jumping to the end of the meal, we ordered a bahklava (sp?) and the check and never got the check.  We had to flag them down and ask for it again and then they never came to pick it up.  I finally got up and walked it to the front so we could pay our bill and leave.

So-  Service rating:  2 stars.

THE FOOD:
We had the ground meat kebab and the joojeh saltani (sp?).  The ground meat was was really nice.  I wish they had the lavash bread a bit thinner (these were more pita bread) and also if they had it underneath the dish so it could soak up the delicious juices.   

All in the all, the food was 3.5 to 4-stars.  Great flavoring.  Big portions.

Only thing I would rate 2-stars was the Bahklava.  It was really not great and when we had 1 bite of it nobody bothered to ask if it was okay or suggest they remove it from the bill.  It had caramel drooped over it and the consistency wasn't great.
author: David H.

description: dogpatch delivery...three items $fifty-fifty.six total...taking over thirty minutes to arrive...poussin, a grilled chicken, rice and vegetables priced higher at $twenty...simple boxed container for one...portions large and filling..chicken seasoned light yellow...chelo-kebab koobideh, one extra long ground meat stick and rice $fourteen.seventy-five...spice seasoned meat and rice tasty...ghorme sabzee, a braised lamb shank and beans with rice $sixteen...separate container of saucy shank...side of rice flavored well...loaded with beans and hefty portion...slight strength to the heavy seasoning and overpowering all...decent meal, but priced higher for what's given...onions, nan and extra seasoning packets provided free in dogpatch delivery...
author: Hen A.

description:
A Persian fusion restaurant in SF. nice!
The ambiance was really nice, with a good service and presentation of food. The items on the menu are not all authentic Persian dishes, but I really like the creativity of the chef in changing some of the dishes.
We ordered the creamy tongue dish and it was delicious. The kababs were not the best I had, but reasonably good.
We ordered a combination faloodeh and ice cream as dessert, but the faloodeh was completely frozen. It was not even possible to break the pieces, which was a disappointment to us. I love faloodeh and I've never had it served like this.
The items on the menu are a bit over-priced.
author: Saeideh B.

description:
Juicy kebabs and chicken, really fragrant basmati rice. Lamb was a little tough.

My brother ate almost all the lamb brains because we didn't want any and I think that was probably a bad move for his cholesterol level.
author: Letitia L.

description: Pretty authentic Persian food . Service is good too. Always book in advance as the place can get crowded . I lived tha lamb shank entree and we had appetizers of eggplant , yoghurt and grilled vegetables skewer . This place a hidden jewel of the city and will go there again
author: Vin M.

description: Everything tasted fresh and my Koobideh was juicy and flavorful.  The meat dishes were good, the rice nice and fluffy and the tomato and chopped tomato/cucumber salad yummy as well.  We'd definitely go back, three stars is AOK and it was AOK!  The atmosphere is elegant, staff was friendly & we thoroughly enjoyed our dinner.
author: Chris H.

description:
Holy shit is this place great!  Went on a double date for Valentines day and the food was great and the service was good as well.  As far as Persian restaurants go this place is nearly as good as it gets.  Not only do they have the usual fare (kabbobs and so on) but they also have a variety of the more exotic stuff...prairie oysters, tongue, etc.  They also have a great selection of gholmes (stews) that you generally won't find at a lot of lower end Persian restaurants because they are labor intensive and expensive to make in small batches.  Even the wine list is nice.  The ONLY thing that I can say needs improvement is that like most Persian places, they don't have a decent bartender and can't make use of the full bar if you ask for a cocktail.  But then again, most people that go to a Persian joint usually just have wine with dinner.  Finally...the tea was a bit weak (for Persian tea anyway) but the coffee was great.  All in all though, it's a wonderful place.


Sepand Tehrani
author: S. T.

description:
Best Persian Restaurant in the city hands down. Authentic taste, great location, great service - and they deliver!

Parking is a pain so arrive early if you have a reservation otherwise on busy nights you might lose your reservation if you arrive late.
author: Farid H.

description: Ordered via Yelp, delivered to my hotel room in SF. Very tasty food.
author: Vladimir R.

description: I was craving kebobs and basmati rice done right - this place got it straight! I ordered for delivery and everything was hot, fresh, and even arrived 15 minutes faster than I expected for my neck of the woods.
author: Caroline L.

description: Cute little place on the north side. Hot high quality pita served with fresh herbs makes it a gem of Persian restaurants these days. Quick service and delivery. Meat was a little too oily but still had great flavor. And they use basmati rice which most places don't use anymore. The shirazi salad and mast-o-musir great flavor and plentiful. The tea was fresh strong and not over cooked or watery. Love the seating by the front windows. Will be coming here again.
author: Alexander S.

description: This is my favorite Persian restaurant in Bay Area. Staff are super friendly and nice. This is where I take all my friends and outside visitors for an elegant Persian food! I love shish kabob and maykadeh soltani dishes!
author: Paris H.

description:
- Locale destination - 
It was lunch time and we were the only customers. It's a bit fancy setting but not so much. Server was attentive. 

- Gluttony expedition -
Dough: Yogurt drink. It contains lemon and tons of mint and herbs. It's not sweet at all. meh...

Mast-o-Musir: Yogurt with dried elephant garlic. It can be a dipping or eaten by itself. Unexpectedly interesting but not so exciting.

Lamb head: Cinnamon and turmeric broth. Head was quite like a liver. A bit too stinky for me. If you squeeze a lime, the smell can be eliminated a lot. It also had a lamb tongue. It's a bit chewier than a beef tongue and has a bit weird texture. 

Ghorme sabzee: Lamb shank, baby eggplant braised with tomato, suffron, sun dried lime with basmati rice. This was more edible than lamb head. The eggplant was a bit sour and tasted like the Turkish vegetable dish I've had. Not so exciting. 

Rocky mountain oysters: This is "ball" of lamb. It has a bit peculiar odor like guts but not so bad. If no one told you this was a ball, you'd eat it no problem!! Interesting.

Pita w Iranian Fetta cheese & basil: This was great!! I prefer this Fetta cheese than the one you normally see at stores. This Iranian Fetta has more flavors. The basil is the one you often see with Pho. I love this ;)

Bastani: Persian ice cream. Ice cream has a pistachio flavor. On the side of ice cream, there was a sorbet - almost like snow-corn kinda ice. It contains rice noodle like stuff in it. You also pour a cherry sauce. Ice cream and shaved ice with noodles & cherry sauce - it's very refreshing and interesting combination. Ice cream itself is boring, but with the shaved ice like sorbet, I kinda like it ;) 

- Conqueror's deduction - 
Foods I tried were just so so. My favorite was Iranian Fetta cheese & basil with a pita and bastani ;) At least I tried more than just Kabob. Brave Akiko ;)
author: Akiko I.

description:
My first boyfriend was Persian.  Longest, worst relationship ever (not that being Persian had anything to do with it).

BUT.. there was one good part about the relationship: the food.  Delicious, yummy nummy Persian food.  It was at the point where I was completely spoiled by the home-cooked goodness of kebabs and stews that I really didn't know where to get good Persian food outside of his parents' house.

Fast forward a few years, and I'm looking around SF for some good hearty Persian food.  Yelp and my part-Persian neighbor recommended Maykadeh (especially after Cello was kind of a fail), so I finally found the time to go on a Friday night after work.

At 7, the restaurant was relatively empty; we were one of two parties there.  Most of the tables are meant for 4+ people, but as more people came in around 7:30, they were mostly parties of two as well.  Service was okay - not overly friendly but courteous enough.

I chose the Zereshk Polo, which was three pieces of chicken breast cooked in a savory sauce and served with basmati rice and barberries.  Everything was good about the dish except the fact that there were just way too many barberries (think of dried cranberries) in the rice, which made it too sweet and tangy for me to enjoy the rice itself.  Boyfriend had the Breast Kebab, and the chicken was also really flavorful, with the spices that I love so much.

This place is definitely somewhere I will be coming back to, and next time I'll be trying their Koobideh Kebab.  Hopefully there will be no little green bugs in this one!
author: Tori S.

description: Very good, very fast delivery - pleasantly surprised with the Breast Kebah, Zereshk Polo, and tasty Hummus - my husband loved the Baklava!
author: Andrrs B.

description: I have been going to Maykadeh for years. It's a bit on the pricy side but it's in Northbeach SF so it's expected.   The food is consistently excellent.  The service is fantastic. From the moment you walk in to the moment you walk out the staff makes you feel great.  When the food arrives, you can smell all the yummy spices that Persian cuisine is known for.  I can brag all day about their food but really to experience it you have to try it for yourself.
author: Donatella Y.

description:
As everybody already noted, food is amazing, prices are fair and I give them solid five stars. If this wasn't half way across town, I would be going there very often. Btw, parking is hell in this part of the city so be prepared to go around in circles for a really long time.

Oh, and order the tongue appetizer!
author: Rositsa K.

description:
Having read Yelp reviews, I along with two colleagues of mine went to Maykadeh for lunch on a weekday.

We ordered a boneless chicken kabob, Koobideh (2 ground beef skewers)  and Fesenjoon (walnut and pomegranate stew) with Shirazi salad (a mix of cucumbers, tomatoes, mint, lime juice and olive oil) (4/5) and cucumber yogurt (3/5). 

The chicken kabob was okay - nothing special though - too dry.  (3/5)

Koobideh - was extremely average in quality - large portion on the positive side though! (3/5)

Walnut stew - the taste was almost right, but not the texture. (3/5)

Our serveur was very accommodating and friendly but not very attentive. (4/5)

Bottom-line - I was a bit disappointed as my higher-than-average expectations for their higher-than-average priced menu were not realized. 

I might give them a second chance next time I get to visit San Francisco, but 3 out of 5 stars overall is all I can give them for now. Until then, I will think of Maykadeh as overrated.
author: Amir T.

description:
I am THE kabob-snob, so naturally when I went to San Fransisco I had to check out this Persian restaurant. While I am partial to my family favorite in Chicago, I must say this place was great!

It's nearing lunchtime at work and I am salivating thinking about Maykadeh's Kabob Kubideh. Yeah, I'm a Kabob-Snob that only desires Kabob-Kubideh...don't hate. The Kubideh at Maykadeh was cooked to perfection. Very soft, not well done, but just right.

When I was there we also ordered the kashkebademjan and some Aash soup. If memory serves me correctly, I liked both, but they were not stand outs. In fact, the one problem with the menu is the lack of Veggie combinations for entrees. I know it is hard for Persian restaurants to have true vegetarian dishes, but they should at least try. So, if you're vegetarian you might be forced to order off of the appetizer menu. 

The location might force you to do some parallel parking, but it's worth it. I liked the atmosphere inside the restaurant just fine, but it's basically the same as any Persian restaurant. Persian restaurants try to include some of their Iranian culture, while maintaining a more American feel as well. 

I would definitely go back here if I am ever in town again. I suggest people who are interested in trying something Persian and different to come here!
author: Mona H.

description: The food is great and very delicious however I am giving a 3/5 stars due to the horrible customer service. The waitresses were very rude. No eye contact or anything.
author: Butimnotayelper D.

description:
My boyfriend and I ate here for dinner and it was great. We stopped in on a whim because we saw that it was Michelin rated. 

Great service! Will come back again.
author: Colleen E.

description:
Food was good. I was very disappointed to see that there were very few vegetarian options - several of the appetizers were vegetarian, but only two of the entrees could even be modified to be vegetarian. One of those two was just the dish cooked as usual, with the lamb shank, then the lamb is taken out just before serving! So it still has the animal broth and fats in, just no physical meat. As we do eat shellfish, we got the giant prawns entree, which was delicious. 

Service was so-so. I think we were being served by the bartender or a manager. We weren't generally offered things; we had to ask for them, like water, despite the table clearly being set with water glasses. Two of us got drinks (which were very nice,  especially the Persian Martini), but were never offered another. The fallodeh tasted lovely, but, as another reviewer said, was completely hard frozen and difficult to eat.
author: Rebecca M.

description:
The lamb shank with eggplant (Khorshet bademjan) was an absolute surprise delight and made the meal worth the trip alone.  Even my wife who does not like lamb was a fan of the dish. (+2 stars!)

The kabobs are good, par for the course.  We had both the beef/lamb combination and the chicken kabobs.  Unfortunately, I felt the chicken kabobs were superior which I didn't expect.

Service was adequate, though there was only one other party at the time for lunch.  Head waiter was more interested in his smart phone than us half the time.  No one else really smiled when serving.  Almost like they didn't really want to be there. Ah, well, I was there for the food anyhow.  (-1 star)

I can see how it could get noisy as the tables are fairly close together and the sitting area rather small.

The price was fair for the quality and quantity of food.  The decor and ambiance is good for a date or small groups.

Don't bother looking around for parking.  Just valet your vehicle in front of the restaurant.  It's $10 compared to $12 for the self park lot a block away (which is where they park your car anyhow).
author: Mark H.

description:
A fancy place with crisp white tablecloths, candles, etc. Overall what I would imagine a nice "date" place to be.  My friends and I turned this place topsy turvy with the size of our group. (It was a weekday night, and I (hopefully) don't think we ruined the ambiance of anybody's date night!)  We had initially made a group reservation.... but we way underestimated the size of the group. We ended up having about 20 people, who trickled in slowly over the span of an hour, but everyone at the restaurant was very kind and accomodating, and did keep adding tables to our group.
I am so impressed by the service from this place. And our food came out quickly too!

The food was delicious! 
[[ Lamn tongue ]] - lime juice, sour cream, and saffon - the color of the sauce was like a mustard, so I was delighted to find out it was nothing like that at all!
[[ Chelo-kebab Koobideh ]] - ground-up mix of beef and lamb
[[ Khoresht Bademjan ]] - lamb shank with eggplant
[[ Shishlik ]] - rack of 6 lamb chops - my favorite dish!
[[ Dough ]] - Minted yogurt drink. I liked it, but some people were really disturbed by the "saltiness" of the drink.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
I ended up coming to dinner here on a Saturday night because every other restaurant I wanted to go to didn't have reservations.  I am so glad that we ended up at this great restaurant!

I have only had Persian food a handful of times so I'm no connoisseur but I really enjoyed the lamb shank I got!  It came with eggplant and a great tomato sauce with a heaping plate of basmati rice.  The food here is reasonably priced (less than $20 for a huge lamb shank!).  

The next time you're in North Beach and don't want to wait for hours to eat at a touristy Italian restaurant, come to Maykadeh and enjoy some hearty Persian food!
author: Marisa G.

description: This is our favorite Persian food place! The sear they get on their meats is excellent!
author: Kevin K.

description:
The restaurant has a nice ambiance and feels a bit formal for a well priced Mediterranean restaurant.

The bread that they gave before our entrees came is a little weird, it's pita bread with some basil leafs, onions, and feta cheese? I'd rather get regular bread. For entree, I ordered poussins, which is yummy but kinda difficult to eat since the chicken parts are small and boney. The basmati rice is very flavorful.

Poached pears as dessert is yummy and didn't feel heavy. Great dessert to close dinner with.

A gem in North Beach!
author: Novalina N.

description: Love the food!! We came down from Sacramento with the family and we were hungry!! We ordered the chicken kabob, eggplant, and of course we had to have the cheese!! Still craving
author: roy p.

description:
I have been coming to this establishment since i was kid, and it still rocks.  As someone who has grown up in a Persian household, eating persian food daily, I  can honestly say that this place knows what it is doing. I've tried a few Persian restaurants in the city, but this place has remained my go-to spot for good reason. 

My favorite small dishes are the brain and the tongue. I know that that may sound gross, but believe me both are amazing. I actually brought a few friends who were a little hesistant to try both dishes, and they ended up loving them.
author: Amir K.

description: I have been to Maykadeh several times. I think they have the best Persian food in SF. Staff are very friendly and welcoming!
author: Soha H.

description: The kabob quality was really low ( koobideh and barg). Probably one my worst kabob experiences in bay area.
author: Shokoufeh A.

description:
People say that this is the best chelo-kabobi in the Bay Area... I'm not sure whether or not it is the best, but I didnt think it was the best thing I had every had. 

We came here on a Sunday with a group of 6 and ordered the chelo-kabob (ground beed kabob), kabob-barg (filet mignon kabob), joojeh kabob (chicken kabob), and the fesenjoon (a persian stew with pomegranate, walnut, and chicken). T

he kabob was a little tastless in my opinion and the barg was a little tough and chewy. The joojeh kabob was pretty good and the fesenjoon was one of the best ive had at a restaruant (my grandma's is better). 

It's definitely a cute spot located in the North Beach district of San Francisco. The prices were a little high but thats to be expected of a chelo-kabobi!
author: Camellia S.

description: For the true Iranians, from my prospective. Mast-o-Khiar, khiar was not fresh & I did not like it.  Chelo-kebab Koobideh was too dry.  Normally you get mint, but they have parsley.  For bread, they have peta & not Iranian flat bread.  There were 2 orders of kebab & we got quarter of an onion.  Over all, would not recommend or came back here.  Sorry....
author: Serg L.

description: Hands down one of my fav places to eat not just in San Francisco but in all of Northern California. Anyone reading this should know I have been working for a family run kabob restaurant. Both of my parents restaurants are highly rated on yelp. And yet I find myself often eating here every chance I get when I'm in the area. I feel like Afghan and Persian kabobs are seasoned quite differently so I embrace the difference in the flavors and can never say even after twelve years that I'm sick of eating kabob and rice. But this place. Wow. The ground beef is amazing. Packed with flavor and juicy. The rice is made perfectly every time. Together they dance in my mouth. I have had the pleasure of enjoying their food for over ten years not sure how long they have been in business but I hope forever.
author: Manija H.

description:
Not as good as I had hoped. I like Mediterranean food and have been to many places. This place did not really meet my expectation.

I  had ordered vegetarian version of Khoresht Bademjan and Hummus for lunch. Basmati rice was good; however, the sauce was too sour for my taste. Hummus was OK. Food was bit overpriced for the quality.

I would not try this place again.
author: Sid P.

description: The food is overpriced so you expect, at least ,a good service, right? WRONG ... We ordered delivery. It arrived after 1:20 min and it was wrong order. We ordered soltani which was the most expensive food and they delivered their cheapest chicken. I called and informed them, so they said they were going to send it. After another one hr, they called and said you should send back the chicken if you want the soltani. Good thing that i don 't like chicken and didn't touch it, but what a poor poor customer service. Instead of saying sorry they wanted their cold horrible chicken back? For what? Throw it to garbage or giving to other customer?
author: A M.

description:
I found myself here trying to get something great to eat before meeting up some coworkers of mine at the Bow Bow Cocktail Lounge. 

I originally thought that it would be easy to just have this to go, but walking in I noticed how nice and clean the place looked in the inside. Alas, the place was full and I was intent on having some great Persian food, so I still took it to go. 

I ordered the Chelo-Kebob Koobideh plate(Pretty much a mix of all your dark meat favorites like ground beef and lamb rolled up real thick). 

I waited a decent 15 minutes till it was done, and wow, did it smell amazing. So, to the dish:

--The Kebobs: It was moist, tender, colorful, steaming hot and filled with flavor. What can I say, it was extremely satisfying. I haven't had a good koobideh like this since I graduated college in Irvine a couple years ago. You get two per plate, and they will fill you up.  

--The Rice was regular steamed white rice. I hope you would add the following condiments though (I love adding as much as I can):
**Sumac (Pomegranate Powder)
**Onion slices
**Fresh Lemon Juice
**Possibly some butter if you don't care to be too light (This food is healthy besides the carbs)

-The Roasted Tomato that comes with the Kebobs and Rice is a great complement, but be sure you like your tomatoes! These are amazing. 

-The plate comes with extra mixed greens, Feta Cheese, onions, and other ingredients that you may want to mix in, 

Overall, I really liked it, but I have had this quality at a better price. Not in the Bay Area, but it was around 30% lower. I'm knocking it off a little for the pricing,
author: Atif K.

description:
Maykadeh is the best Persian food that I have ever had in my entire life. I personally think the quality and the taste is even better than Iran's restaurants. My favorite dish is the baby poussin and I usually go on Sundays so I can have it with fava bean rice. The fillet is AMAZING! AMAZING! 

If you're open to try new things make sure you try the lamb tongue and the lamb brain. I know, it sounds weird but trust me, as soon as you taste them you'll change your mind. 

If you're into seafood you should definitely try the salmon. 

They have an amazing and super polite and friendly staff. I think it's my favorite restaurant.
author: Siavash N.

description: Chicken in a pomegranate sauce, ground angus and lamb, rice, eggplants appetizer, hummus - everything was perfect. Quite expensive and a bit tiny but excellent quality of food.
author: Kate V.

description: Wow.  Amazing food.  This has to be my favorite restaurant in the North Beach area.  The kitchen staff did a wonderful job with our meal.  Everything was perfect.  Great job!
author: Sebastian B.

description: Really enjoyed my meal there.  Yummy lamb/beef shishkabob (kabideh), fluffy, tasty rice and lovely greek salad.  My dad loved his lamb shank.
author: Rita S.

description:
Great location 
Great quality iranian food
Great service
I yelped it and that is why I am here
author: Jack P.

description: One of the best Lamb Shanks i have ever had in US! i've been to Persian restaurants in Chicago, Minneapolis, Dallas, Boston and DC, etc and by far this is one the best Persian restaurants i've ever been.
author: Saeed M.

description:
I have developed a love for Persian cuisine and Maykadeh definitely did not disappoint. 

What we ordered:

Shirazi salad (diced cucumber, onion, tomato, olive oil, and lime juice - $6): This traditional dish is an excellent way to start the meal, all of the ingredients were fresh and light, it was prepared perfectly. 

Feta cheese spread (oven roasted tomato, basil, olive oil, and Bulgarian feta cheese - $7): One of the most delicious appetizers I've had in recent memory. The cheese is incredible on its own, but mixed with fresh basil and Persian style flat bread it is truly amazing. 

Lamb tongue (served with lime juice and a saffron sauce - $15): This was a big hit at our table, everyone loved the rich and flavorful saffron sauce. 

Lamb brain (served with lime juice and saffron sauce - $15) This is more of an acquired taste. It has the consistency of an egg omelet when you cut it with a knife, yet it acts more like an oyster inside your mouth. I actually preferred the brain to the tongue, but everyone else seem to favor the tongue. 

Cehlo-Kebab Koobideh (skewer mixture of ground beef and lamb with Persian spices and served with basmati rice - $14.75): Some of the best koobideh I've ever had. The meet was seasoned lightly to compliment, rather than overpower the natural flavors.  

The restaurant has a warm inviting atmosphere and the service is excellent. We arrived as a party of ten and they had our table ready and provided excellent service throughout the meal.
author: Tom L.

description: We visited while in San Fran and had a good experience. The koobideh kababs were delicious, a little greasy, but good. The rice was flavorful, but slightly overdone. The server wasn't very friendly, but she was efficient. We will definitely return if we're in the area gain.
author: Chris N.

description:
OVERALL:3.3  FOOD:4   SERVICE:2   AMBIANCE:3   VALUE:4
I'd been here once 5 years ago, and though the food still tastes like Heather Locklear (keepin it classy!), the staff & ambiance had me seeing flashes of Lindsey Lohan (whoaa, how do her parents let her get away with this..?).

The stew dishes (gormeh sabzi, fesunjoon, etc) are enjoyable though a bit heavy-handed on the pucker factor for my taste.  Where it's really at? The grilled meats & appetizers: joojeh kabob, koobideh, mastokhiar, kashke bademjoon....all gut-splittingly addictive!  Oh, and don't forget the saffron & dill rice!

Décor is traditionally boring & host(ess) + staff are slackers. Wish I could divorce them and just enjoy the food.....oh wait, I CAN -- they deliver, too!
author: Amy K.

description:
Best Persian food!!!! They delivery, I really don't want to give this away but they do. Oh its so goooooood. I get lamb/beef kebab which a nice chard tomato and rice.  

I've order this to go 2 times last week. Delicious, amazing!
author: Jess O.

description: I have been here Meny time ,if your looking to some thing different in your mouth you should try here
author: Alex B.

description:
I grew up in a household that barbeques Kabobs on a weekly basis. I have eaten at many Persian restaurants with the mentality that the food will never taste as good as it does at home.

Maykadah has proven me wrong! The food was delicious and the service was awesome! 

Another added bonus, they have valet!
author: Tania D.

description:
I am giving it 5 STARS for the chicken koobideh ALONE!!!
Overall experience I'd say is 4 stars....

I was told that this place has the BEST chicken koobideh and it is only served on MONDAYS... So I must go on a Monday to try it...

So the verdict is.... Yes, it REALLY is the Most juiciest, tender, and deliciously prepared chicken koobideh I have EVER HAD.... 
 
Simply put, they serve the "filet mignons" of chicken koobideh..

Better than ANY OTHER persian restaurant soooo far... 

I did try their Beef koobideh which is also very juicy, BUT the chicken koobideh really impressed me.. I thought I knew good chicken koobideh, until yesterday, I was schooled.

So I can't say much for anything else except to come here for the chicken koobideh on Mondays!!

fyi Maustokhiar and the tea were good too.
author: Naomi Y.

description:
The food was 5 stars - and I'm a girl who was raised with some high quality Persian cooking (though I'm sure everyone says their mom is the best cook).  Anyway, the food tastes like my mom's home cooking and the atmosphere is relaxed yet classy.  

I am removing a star however because they made us wait 30 min to be seated for our reservation that I had made on opentable several days earlier.  The host seemed a bit frazzled and I'm sure they were hit with a lot of groups wanting to be seated at once, but still, when you have a reservation, 30 min is far too long to wait.  

Outside of the wait time, wrt food, I recommend the fesenjoon, the moste mousir, the kaske bademjan - and anything that comes with their basmati rice - it is so delicious and fragrant, you can smell it arriving before it even gets to your table.  All this reviewing is making me hungry...
author: Nakissa G.

description: Me and my bf decided to try this place out. We didn't mind the cost of valet because it's worth it in a city that is so hard to find parking. It was convenient.  Now the customer service was excellent.  The food was very delicious.  The meat was cooked perfectly.  Nice and tender and juicy. It makes my mouth water as i write this review.  At the end of the meal my bf decided to get a third pomegranate martini and i a tea. The waiter which i also assume may be related to the owner gave us the last drinks on the house. A good tip goes a long way. We will definitely be returning.
author: M G.

description:
My mom had heard so many people say how good Maykadeh was that for Mother's Day this is the resturant she choose to go have dinner at. I honestly don't know how other persian people can claim that this place has such great food. The food was too fatty and compared to other Persian resturants they definately were cheap with thier portions. When you go to a Persian restaurant, it is customary to leave with a full and happy belly, as well as an extra box filled with your yummy leftovers for later. That was not the case for me or my family tonight. 

The service was bad, the restaurant was small and lacked ambiance, and the food was nothing to rave about. If you want good Persian food I would suggest going to Walnut Creek or San Jose. Stay away from Maykadeh you taste buds and wallet will thank you.
author: Nava N.

description:
This place is okay. I remember it being better in the past. Unfortunately, there's not a lot of Persian restaurant options in San Francisco, so I can only think of one place I like better than this, and one that is about the same level. 

I typically get ghormeh sabzi, but here it's just okay. I'll admit I've been spoiled by home cooked Persian food by very good cooks.
author: Ken L.

description:
So we walk in on a Friday afternoon for lunch, expecting, well Persian food really.  What did we get ... Persian food!  I'm not being sarcastic I'm being funny, LOL!

I'm assuming the curly-haired guy is the owner/manager of the place because he was very friendly and hospitable towards us - rare for a Persian restaurant not to have a nosy staff, but since I don't like to surrender my identity to my fellow countrymen, I think he obliged and was thoughtful to speak English back to me!

The food is tasty, I had the kabob barg which is my favorite Persian kabob dish, my husband had the kabob koobideh.  We both ordered salad and skipped on the rice (pahleasssssssssssssssssse anymore carbs on my ass and it's straight to Biggest Loser jail I go), and the salad was tasty, actually tasty, shocking, no seriously shocking because most Persian restaurants don't do tasty salads with kabobs because they get pissed you don't do it the traditional way and have rice with your kabob, but this place surpassed my happy zone!

Okay so all in all, you have to try this place out, if not for the food, then go check out the decor and the location, very cool, but not touristy!
author: Yekta A.

description: I love persian food! This place was quite disappointing. Nothing exceeded me expectations & this the first persian restaurant i have been to that served pita bread & not lavash.The service was ok, people kind of lagged. The food didn't have much flavor to me. If you know what you're eating and have had persian food before, you would understand.
author: Alham I.

description:
Food was good, server was mean.  

Doesn't accept Amex?!  Definitely over priced and left more to be desired.
author: Elijah N.

description: Great food! The marination is different if you order boneless chicken thighs than if you get chicken breast. I liked the chicken breast better cause they were more chunky and more sour than the softer flat thighs. They use so much saffron on everything. Well, we think it's saffron. It could be gole rang which is a flower with gives off yellow colour and cheaper. Overall a pleasant experience. Oh and their kashke bademjan and mast mousir is delicious too!
author: Shannon W.

description:
Everything was ok, but nothing was spectacular. Price is pretty high for one lamb kebab (30) with not a lot of meat.

probably won't go back
author: Danielle A.

description:
The appetizer selection was good but wasn't the best tasting I felt. Ordered the baba ganoush but it was slightly bitter I felt. 

The entrees though were great. Wife and I shared a lamb stew (with eggplant) and a chicken kabaab and both were really good.
author: Sab E.

description: always good! koobideh, joojeh, the lamb shank with the stew on the rice... sooo good! the lamb tongue and lamb feet were excellent also!  never lets me down...
author: howard c.

description:
Maykadeh is my favorite Persian restaurant in the city, which locates in the heart on North Beach neighborhood. I have been a customer in this place around three years now. I come here at least ones in two weeks. It has warm atmosphere and extremely friendly staff, but also incredibly delicious food.
    This restaurant has a big variety of good quality Persian food. I love  their appetizers as "Lamb tongue", "Brain" and of course "Rocky mountain oysters". Try one of this dishes and you will not regret it! Talking about entrees you should definitely try the dish calls "Khorest Fesenjoon", which is chicken with sweet and sour pomegranate sauce. It has reach pomegranate taste with a little touch of walnuts and spices. All the ingredients together create perfect combination. For dessert order "Bastani" (Persian ice-cream). This ice-cream has whole pistachios and rose water. The flavor is something really unique and extremely good, it is hard to describe it. This is something to die for! 
    Honestly all the dishes ( I've tried them all) have nice combinations of flavors, which will transfer you to the Middle Eastern culture.
    One more tip about this place, it has valet parking, which is really convenient and it is only $10. 
    Definitely will be back to Maykadeh, again and strongly recommend to everyone who is open to experience new flavors.
author: Julia T.

description: I love you meykadeh for making me feel better! Best gheimeh and best ash took me less than 5 min to finish all! We order onljne and the food comes hot and great:-)
author: Sahar J.

description: My family and I drove an hour to try this place out. In short this place wasn't worth it especially for the prices that they charge. Upon arrival their valet costs 10 dollars. Which is ridiculous because most places are free, and they literally just reverse back and parked the car right in front of their restaurant. So you basically throw away 10 dollars on that plus some tip. The environment was basic, it was tight inside and the design of the place was mediocre and looked old. We got seated and the menu was given to us (there was 5 of us). You would think that they would ask us quickly what we wanted to drink, but after awhile, nothing. Finally after 10 minutes the waiter asked us what wanted to drink, and good thing we were ready to order too. The food took 35 minutes to get to us which seemed fine since there was 5 of us, however at least three other families that went in after us got their food quickly. After getting the food the staff wouldn't ask how the food was, in fact we were ignored. Not only that we would see the waiter go around talking to the other people who came in. It makes the customer feel awkward because you don't know why they won't come up to us. Now, onto their food. It was really disappointing. My family enjoyed the lamb tongue, however my girlfriend and I didn't like the joojeh kabob (chicken thighs). It was bland, not well seasoned, and it was dry. My dad ordered the lamb (shishlik), and he said it was unseasoned, while the outside was burned and dry, and inside was completely raw. Their kabob koobideh was dry and burned, and it seemed like there was a lot of fillers in it and not enough meat. I've eaten a lot of kabob and this was one of the worst. In one word to describe this place: disappointment. I can't believe it's a 4 star place. I will not be an advocate for this restaurant. Too bad.
author: Justin P.

description: I took my friends here because a few years ago when we came here I really liked the food but this time the food (soltani, chicken kabob, and poussin) was so bad that none of us could even finish our food and it's not easy to mess up koobideh this much! Everything was burnt outside and raw inside! Very disappointed!
author: Pat M.

description:
I was so annoyed by our server (who is not Persian) that I complained to the manager and we got our whole meal for free. She was so rude I lost my appetite. So I couldn't even enjoy our free meal. 
It is not often that i think that some one has a problem with me because I am black.  It was obvious that she had a problem with it. She acted as  if she was going to catch black if she got to close to us. She was uncomfortable, rude and acted as if she just wanted us to get out. 
I felt like I was in a corner store where the owner is following me because they think I am going to steal.
I don't understand minorities who treat other minorities like they are disgusting. 
The last place I expected that was at a Persian restaurant. I find Persian culture to not be prejudiced and to be warm and inviting. But like I said, our server was not Persian.
author: Yayne A.

description:
Once you enter the restaurant, you perceive the atmosphere different than other restaurants, the servers are extremely friendly and service oriented. The food is top quality! I been coming here long time, they keep the standard high.

They speak Farsi at this Persian restaurant.  dishes on the menu, likeJojeh kebab (a rich chicken dish ) and gormeh sabzee (a stew featuring herbs, beef, kidney beans, and sun-dried limes). But their kebabs are moist and delicious--like ground beef, chicken, or filet mignon--grilled over an open flame. Squeeze a lime over your kebab for a taste explosion. For dessert, there are a bunch of Persian delights.

 I love their rice (basmatti), tadig (the bottom of the pot of rice, its crispy) And with the Stew (Khoresht) on top it, is an amazing Starter.
author: Carlo K.

description: I've been coming to this place for a year now and can't figure out why there is never a wait. Food is fantastic. We always start with the feta and basil. Delish! Had a Barbera- Sangiovese blend that was superb. Finish with the filet beef. This place always hits the spot.
author: Samantha C.

description: I have been to this place three times. I took a friend of mine that came from Seattle to a conference and to visit me a couple of years ago. They have some of the most traditional stuff from Iran. The quality of the food is very good but it is very pricy. There was a guy who took $10 or $15 from us just to park in the street in front of the restaurant. He seemed to be affiliated or working with the restaurant. They way he asked was rude and unfriendly though. They waiter was also rude when we asked to get salad instead rice saying the salad was $7.5 as if we asked him for he's sisters hand for marriage. We get that all the time in South Bay restaurants. We also did not think the quality was outstanding. It is above average but they need to be more friendly specially with those prices.
author: Ali B.

description: Hands down best Persian restaurant in the City.  The chicken koobideh is to die for.  The masta moosier is great to. I suggest this place hands down! Wonderful atmosphere and service as well.
author: Kavon M.

description: Delicious food in an unassuming environment. He chicken kabob was divine. Iranian friends assured me that this was the first choice and we were not disappointed. $10 valet parking shared with the Italian place next door.
author: Philip R.

description:
Best Persian restaurant in San Francisco by far. Great decor and setting - casual yet classy in an intimate setting.

 It comes down to the details here - the presentation of each dish is meticulous, plus the food is always fresh and the meat juicy and tender. My personal fav is the Barg.
author: Robert K.

description: Food was awesome. We had the Chelo-kebab Koobideh (ground beef/lamb) and the chicken breast kabobs. Plates were huge and tasty. Service was not awesome. It took longer to actually order, and then to get our check than the time to eat our food. Often when we asked for something they forgot (ex. straws, butter). Note that it was not busy.
author: Hanna A.

description: Sadly, I was not impressed. We ordered in and the food was bland. I wanted to love the $30 Soltani but it wasn't awesome. The shirazi salad was really good though. And the doogh was not Abali (not sparkling) but it was good.
author: Maryam M.

description:
I have ordered from this place for a very long time and now all of a sudden they "changed their delivery area".  So now I am out of the area that they deliver to.  I am very disappointed to this new change.  I live in SF and they say that its to far away.  

Food is good but its super convenient to have delivery.
author: Ally D.

description: I am half Persian and this place is exceptionally amazing! I got the Ghormeh Sabzi (my personal favorite) and it was pretty on point! It was great that they serve you fresh basil with onion and bread (classic iranian side-they eat everything that looks like grass (no offense) but it's amazing. Normally there's a plate full of green onion, tarragon, basil, parsley, ect). Table was a little too small but the food was yummy. Glad we went there!
author: Natalie M.

description:
I can't believe I've lived in the Bay Area for 20 years and never before visited Maykadeh. In recent years, a number of Persian friends mentioned their favorite Persian restaurant in North Beach, so I finally scoped it out. Although I'm not Persian, I lived in Tehran as a child, so I have strong childhood attachment to certain authentic flavors and dishes. 

I can say that on first tasting the Gormeh Sabsi and the Tadig (rice cooked 'til crispy in the bottom of the pan), I was immediately transported back to my youth. There were also platters of roasted, skewered meats--tender and aromatic--and perfectly cooked lamb chops, a cucumber salad with briny feta and honeyed desserts to die for. I wish I could be more specific about each dish we ordered, but I was with a larger party and the platters just kept coming. Despite eating my fill in the first few courses, I couldn't stop tasting, it was that delectable. 

Also, the service was warm and friendly, including a bartender who happily obliged my request for a cold season hot toddy, despite it not being part of his standard repertoire. All in all, Maykadeh was a wonderful experience, and one I can't wait to repeat. Plus, there's valet parking, which makes all the difference when deciding whether to brave the North Beach crowds or not. Two thumbs up!
author: Jamie J.

description: What you eat here is the fantom of Persian food. Clearly the chef does not know Iranian food. End of story.
author: Maryam N.

description: Food quality was good! We ordered soltani kabobs. But, it was rather pricy!! It was much more expensive than the top Persian restaurants in LA even!
author: Sarah K.

description:
Very good Persian food in SF bay area. Their chicken is moist, juicy and full of flavor. You can taste the saffron in the chicken as well as the rice. 

They give you bulgarian feta cheese, walnuts and thin lavash bread in this dish called "panir and gerdo" and its really quite tasty.

The portions are pretty  big, not as large as other persian places but still very large. You can taste the quality and preparation that goes into the food here. However, its a bit pricier than other persian places since its in the city.

This is a great place to go for couples or a romantic dinner for two. I always try to eat here whenever I am visiting San Francisco.

Maykadeh is probably the best persian place in all of SF
author: Sam N.

description: The food is really good and the whole environment of this place is quiet and peaceful. the Personnels are friendly and polite. i really recommend this place for everyone. the parking is not easy but other than that everything else is great.
author: Hani S.

description: Te feta cheese platter appetizer was really good. The lamb shank was too sour. The service was average.
author: Madushanka S.

description: Always delicious and good service in a nice atmosphere. Great selection of authentic dishes. This review is long overdue - we've been coming for a few years now. As a matter of fact, my mouth is watering as I write this... I need to go back soon!  Enjoy.
author: Mark W.

description: I LOVE this place, Maykadeh is really nice, classy, relaxing and cozy; impressed by the whole ambiance, food, drinks, service...and I admit, I am not easy to impress by a restaurant. I will definitely go back   next  time I am in   San Francisco
author: Lucero M.

description:
My date brought me here for Valentine's Day dinner and the valet attendant was friendly. The street was narrow and a lot of traffic during a busy night so a lot of honking drivers lol
My experience here was awesome due to the wonderful waitress. She is Persian and speaks Farsi.
We had the eggplant appetizer with bread and butter and onions...
My date ordered the ground beef kabob and rice, he ordered me the lamb shank but it had beans and some type of mushed spinach or greens all over my lamb shank... I hate beans and I didn't like the dish... I only took one bite and the waitress asked me was it ok and I said I should've ordered the Baby Chicken dish... She said she can change the plate for me immediately! At no charge!
I was so happy and relieved!
She made my night!
Definitely would come back!
I also had Persian tea, which was pretty good.
And a yogurt drink... Forgot what it was called.
Their food is amazing, nicely proportioned and excellent service!!
I made my date overtip her because he messed up by ordering me something I didn't want in the first place and SHE had to fix HIS mistake!
She saved HIS ass. Lol.
As we were leaving, the valet was fast with our vehicle and the car was in the same condition as it was. Had to give him a good tip also. Lol. Valet parking is $10.
author: Viv W.

description:
I just ordered from these guys... they made a mistake on my order which was a bit annoying (but these things happen from time to time).

However, I just called them up and they were VERY apologetic and nice and gave me a rebate correcting the issue... 

TOTALLY satisfied even though my order wasn't perfect.  

Good job guys.
author: Kevin B.

description: Great food, service and ambiance. The Koobideh is fantastic. The pita bread was so delicious and we had this eggplant appetizer that wasn't baba ganush and it was memorable. Perfect Friday night dining experience. Will definitely be back again.
author: Kaushick N.

description:
Great food, and yes, I'm Persian. I liked that the bread, cheese, and sabzi were brought to the table gratis, because, well, that's just Persian hospitality. It's not right to charge for them. 

I'm a little irked by how pricey Persian food is at this point, because I know most of it is not costly to prepare, but I can't blame them for going at a price point they know they can get. 

The barg was great - tender, flavorful, and plentiful. My fiance was in kebab heaven. We had PLENTY for leftovers the next day, so it was nice to get two meals out of one for the price. The kashk-e bademjan was good, too!
author: Courtney W.

description:
Loved this food! Hubby got the lamb kebab and I got the breast (chicken) kebab. The meat was tender, delicious! The rice was perfect and the asparagus, grilled vegs were all tasty. The cucumber and yogurt and hummus were great and I love the hot sauce!! Portions are large. And they deliver!!
But warning, if you use eat24.com don't forget to special request utensils or you get NOTHING and like it!
author: Piper W.

description: Best Persian food in the city. Consistent quality, authentic and tasty. I've been coming here for years. Get the koobideh, amazing.
author: lior t.

description: we went there with a large group and ate family style  I got to try half the menu. the kabobs and khoreshts (stews) were all made with high quality meat cooked to perfection, the rice was fluffy and amazing, and the tadeeg was off the hook. the  thing I wasn't thrilled with was the fesenjoon which was fresh and quality but not as flavourful as it should be. It seemed like jah nayoftaadeh (it hadnt set). love this place though. Highly recommend.
author: Mmm M.

description: The most amazing persian food! It was almost comparable to my persian boyfriend's mom's cooking! Must go!
author: Ursula K.

description: Their Koobideh kabob was great! The service was awesome too! Definitely recommend it!
author: Ali S.

description: I ordered for a group of 4 from Eat24. 2 of us ordered the Lamb Shish Kebab and were food poisoned. I will not be ordering from this restaurant again.
author: Konish D.

description: Parking in SF can be challenging!  But, I'm glad we found this little gem.  They have some harder to find dishes like rocky mountain oysters :) and sheep feet.  It was nice to experience some good Persian food while in this area.
author: Anne P.

description: Just had a diner here . You have to try the prawns with basmati rice.  Not only is healthy is very delicious. Don't waste your time to find parking; And if you tip them they can keep your car right there.
author: MOREY D.

description: Hard to find an Iranian restaurant that makes good fessenjoon. This place makes FANTASTIC fessenjoon. Great food.
author: Sara B.

description: I love their food, I don't like their price. Also their parking is a pain. I go there every 2-4 years. They should lower their price and provide free parking.
author: Nelly G.

description: The spicy joojeh chicken is amazing here. Comes with a huge plate of flavorful basmati rice...a bit more than I can handle but perfect for sharing. I managed to get reservations for a party of 6+ without a lot of hassle on multiple occasions though parking in the area is a pain.
author: Parag M.

description:
I'm open to trying them again but I was a little disappointed to find part of my breast kebab was almost raw.  

The good: loved the eggplant, pita and toppings.  I usually don't eat rice, but the rice here is perfect - smelled great and tasted even better.  The chicken was seasoned well, and very tasty.  To close the meal, I had a super fragrant Persian baklava that was sooooo yummy. 

The bad:  I'm not someone who won't eat meat that is slightly undercooked but one section of my kebab was inedible as was.  Luckily, I was home and could pop it in the oven.  Also, the driver didn't ask if I want change but assumed that I was tipping him 20+% on delivery.  He literally said thanks and ran down my stairs with money in hand.
author: Rayna A.

description: I have been here twice. I know Mediterranean food very well and I had high expectations. The free apetizer was fresh mint leaves with persian bread. Bread was delicious but the leaves plate did not look good. We ordered kobedeeh as an apetizer and compared the other places and the way that they presented was not good. Main entree plates are very large if you are into rice pilaf. Lamb racks were delicious but baby chicken was hard to eat. The atmosphere looked and smelled mildy. The decoration is old. They need to improve how to present the food plates. The prices were reasonable.
author: Emel M.

description:
Without a doubt this is my favorite Persian restaurant in the Bay Area. I have been here many times and tried many things on the menu. 

My go to at any Persian place is the koobideh kabob. It is the standard kabob made from ground beef. Maykadeh makes the best koobideh around. It is perfectly cooked every time, moist, and extremely flavorful. I have never been disappointed with this dish. The saffron rice it comes with is always perfect too. And with a generous helping of two skewers (the standard) you will be sure to not go hungry. 

The sturgeon (seasonal) is utterly amazing here. It is a fish not often seen in cuisine but it is executed exquisitely here. The spices and sauces they use create a burst of flavor in every bite. A dish you must try. 

Now lets get a bit more...adventurous. The lamb tongue in saffron sauce was a great dish. The texture of the tongue is a bit odd but once you get passed that the actual flavor is amazing. In a party of 6 nearly everyone absolutely loved the tongue. (one girl apparently didn't get the memo of what it was before trying it and was less than amused when she found out later on during the meal)

Lamb brain has to be the most interesting and hard to describe foods I have ever had. When I started eating it the texture was somewhat like an omelette. Then when I tried to describe the taste I was tongue tied. I knew it tasted like something but could not decipher what it was. My friend had the same issue. After a brief discussion he said it tastes like oysters. To this day I think there is a closer flavor that can be used to describe it but I have no clue what it is. So you be the judge, try this delicious meal and tell me what you think it tastes like. 

The service here is excellent. All the waiters are very nice and accommodating. We even added two to our reservation and they didn't just added a table without another word. 

The bar is also chalk full of great drinks and has an extensive menu. 

This place is a definite must.
author: Eli Y.

description:
Great food great service I was here for lunch
Also came back for dinner unbelievable food
author: Payman P.

description: Nice location, it's wedged between 2 residential houses. Service was cosy. Try the chicken koobideh and breast together. Super delicious!
author: Reza Z.

description:
Took us almost a year to come here and I feel bad to say that it was all because the other 2 places we had in mind didn't work out...BUT it turned out to be a good thing so a win-win for all.  

The place is bright with large glass partitions but tightly packed with tables with little room to move around.  We were lead to the bench seats behind the bar with a party of 2 on either side.  The place was very warm to a point of stuffy and we were dressed in winter gear...while I down iced water (I don't normally drink water), hubby asked if they can turn on the fans.  Guess the fans don't really work but they did get the AC going...

While we were debating what to order, the couple sitting to our left was very friendly and told us the lamb tongue we were considering is very good.  They were having this thick layer of crispy rice with gravy over it.  It really looked good and we shall try next time.  

To start, I got the Rotari - it's an individual sized bottle of sparkling wine.  So cute and perfect for one.  I need to find it and get myself a case at home!  Hubby got a glass of chardonnay.  We ordered:

Lamb tongue with lime juice, sour cream and saffron - $14 - it tasted like curry but a little tart.  The tongue was so tender and flavorful.  It was not gamey at all.

Skewered mixture of Certified Angus Beef and leg of lamb, ground daily, onion, Persian spices, Basmati rice - $14.75 - huge oval plate of basmati rice with a grilled tomato and 2 long skewers of tasty meat with juices oozing out.  Hubby liked it a lot and had half of the dish even though it was mine!

Lamb shank, baby eggplant braised with tomato, saffron, sun dried lime, Basmati rice - $16 - the meat falls off the bone.  It was tender and very flavorful.

I added a glass of syrah with dinner.  As mentioned by other yelpers, you are served with warm flat bread and a plate filled with a chunk of feta cheese, sprigs of basil and radish.  There were also couple cubes of butter.  

We thoroughly enjoyed dinner and look forward to returning soon.
author: Gloria H.

description:
Persian cuisine in North Beach.  What that means is that parking is hell.  But look long enough and look far enough away and eventually a place to park opens up.  

The restaurant itself has an up-scale look; a bit fancy schmancy.  The service was perfunctory.  Once ordered the food came at once. One plate immediately followed the other.  I felt badly rushed.  

But it's the food that matters most.  And the food was, well, OK.  Good.

Shirazi salad was a bowl of diced cucumbers, tomatoes and onions in a sea of a lime-based dressing.  Once ordered, it arrived so quickly that it had to have been prepared in advance.   I was thinking of the deli in the neighborhood supermarket.  But it was better than than.  It was OK.  Good.

Koobideh, kebobs of beef and lamb, followed hard on the heels of the salad.  The plate was not beautifully composed.  The rice wasn't well arranged.  And the skewers were OK.  Good.   

So if you want an OK, even a good meal of persian food in North Beach then this place is for you.
author: David D.

description: Have I told you lately that I love you? Yes! The food here is delicious and I know my Persian food.  I have never been disappointed. and the cook isn't even Persian. Surprise surprise!  The amount of food is ample, you don't leave hungry.  You get enough to know how things taste. a bit exp, but what isn't? Only problem is parking. There isn't any on the street parking in this neighborhood. I think they have valet but like most I'd rather park my own car and eat at my liesure.  I would give this a two thumbs up and a click and definitely it is worth checking out.
author: Rabi'a M.

description:
Without a doubt the best Persian restaurant I've been to in the city (or the Bay Area for that matter).

If you're new here, be sure to start out with the "Kashke Bademjoon" for your appetizer. For drinks I really like the Persian Lady. I tried making it at home but it never comes out as good as they make it here.

For the main course you absolutely MUST try the Shishlik (if you're like me you should get it medium or medium rare). It's very tender and juicy. Of course there are plenty of other options too..."shisk kebab", "koobideh", and "Ghormeh Sabzi" are all very good options. 

The only negative thing (and it really has little to do with the restaurant itself) is that every time I've come here, it's always been impossible to find parking around here. You gotta do valet like it or not so that's an extra $15-$20 you gotta spend.
author: Ali A.

description: Took a party of 10 for lunch on Friday with prior reservation. Not a good place to take your vegetarian friends.Veg choices are very limited. Service was below average. We were not even asked if we wanted water (the entire time). Food tasted good. But not great.
author: Nariman R.

description: A- for food. C- for service. Between the bad service and hell that is north beach parking, I would come back only if I was really craving Persian food which is more often than not. I like that they aren't shy with their seasoning but seriously. You guys need to get your stuff together when it comes to service and checking on customers.
author: M C.

description: Very nice Persian restaurant in North Beach area. The only problem is parking. I tried their eggplant stew and fesenjaan. Both had good quality, not super special. The service was very good and professional, playing Persian music in the background which is probably not ear appeasing to everyone. Overall a good experience.
author: Sasan A.

description:
I had high hopes for the place before going. I had never had Persian food and was excited to try it! I think with a few adjustments this place could easily be a 4-star place. The service wasn't great - at least for us. There were many Persians there who seemed to get better service than us. Since we had never had this type of food before, we asked for recommendations from the server. He was very unhelpful. He just said "everything is good". How is that helpful? 

We ordered the lamb and the pomegranate chicken. The chicken was much better!

We may try this place again but I will likely try to find another Persian restaurant to try first.
author: Cheyenne C.

description:
There's a reason why a Persian restaurant, off the beaten track, has been around for over 25 years, has received numerous awards, and keep regulars coming back!

Consistently GREAT food, fast service, comfortable seating, no tourists, no pretense, yet professional and YUMMY!

A MUST!
author: Ted K.

description:
I brought my family back to Maykadeh last night and they loved it and could not stop raving about the food. I had the sweet & sour sauce chicken again which is absolutely sinful. The Persian martini was also delish! So I will keep my 5 star reviews but have to say...

I'm not so sure about those desserts! We tried the Persian ice cream and another dessert with a strange name. When we asked the server what it was before ordering it, he said it was like shaved ice with rose water and noodles. I'm not sure why we still braved ordering it... yes, it was refreshing but SO strange. I guess I have to develop my taste for Persian desserts a bit more but until then will stick to the apps and mains...
author: Meghan P.

description:
On my first trip here, I was not too impressed with this place, but upon this second visit, I am sold. Standard Persian restaurant décor and menu.

I love me some Persian food, and this is the FIRST place that is suggested when I ask local Persians, however I am usually inclined to Alborz on Van Ness.

Downsides: Parking in North Beach, and Chicken Koobideh is only available on Mondays for some reason. Also a little pricier than Alborz.

Upsides: Chicken Fessenjoon was excellent. Koobideh was solid, but not excellent.
author: Raza M.

description: Amazing... Everything from the tea to the salad ( basil, radish, onion ) was authentic. The hummus was okay, it wasn't bad however I like hummus a little stronger. The lamb and meat plate was so tasty that I almost ordered another one. This place is on point.
author: Sandy N.

description: The food is not cheap but it is excellent. I have both dined at the restaurant and got tons of deliverys. The delivery covers most of SF. I would recommend the lamb tong and tah dig can't go wrong with anything on these Guys menu.
author: vahid r.

description: Unique menu, fair prices, incredible flavors, great service. The lamb tongue was worth traveling for. I didn't tell the family what I ordered as they would never had tried it. We all agreed that it was one of the dest dishes we ever had. The mountain oyster (balls) were o.k., had to try them once. The rack of lamb excellent and the filtet/lamb combo superb. They did overcook the lamb shank (hard to do) otherwise the food would have had 5 stars. This is a great restaurant, especially if you want to try some different things rarely seen in the U.S. 3 of us had 3 appetizers, 3 meals, 5 cocktails and a nice bottle of Syrah and spent $200+ tip. We couldn't finish all the food. Will be back
author: scott s.

description:
I ordered dinner from Maykadeh Restaurant last week, and it was delicious.  My boyfriend and I been ordering from them once in a while for the past year and a half, and they have never disappointed.  As far as I can tell, all their stuff is good, especially the filet mignon and lamb.  I get the same lamb entree (Shish-Kebab) every single time.

The restaurant itself seems to be a nice, classy place with efficient, courteous staff, but we've never eaten in it because most of the time we're lazy as fuck and would rather pick up our food and eat it at home, naked and watching TV, than take the effort of looking presentable while eating in public.  Either way, I highly recommend stopping by Maykadeh if you find yourself hungry in North Beach.
author: Niya Y.

description: I am a big fan of Persian food and this food is one of the best i have tasted. I had the ground beef and lamb kabob and it was excellent.
author: Mario J.

description:
Excellent excellent and excellent! 

I am Arabic and I think we're supposed to dislike Persians for some reason. 

That being said, I would love any culture when it serves food as good as this place does! Not an overstatement but fact to which I challenge current and prospective haters of Iranian cuisine to validate themselves. 

I love you guys at Maykadeh, and it's where I intend on proposing, no joke! So don't make me look bad if you see some sorry patron on his knee one night *love*
author: F A.

description: This place is great! Loooooove the kebabs here. All of the sides are amazing. Service is great. If you are looking for delicious persian food, you have to go here!!!
author: Cheryl M.

description: The food is always great, especially their Ghorme Sabzi! Make sure you try it. Kubideh is great too. I think the price is not expensive in comparison with what you get...
author: Ryan R.

description:
Best Persian Restaurant in the city ( & Bay Area).... and that's coming from a Persian. ;) 

Went there last night with 3 french friends (all their first time having persian food) and...they loved everything!

I'm pretty sure, we ordered pretty much the entire menu ( or so it seemed), we had 2 of the Eggplant Appetizers,  Yogurt with shalot, the Tah Deeg with fesenjan stew over it ( this was is off the menu so you have to know to request it) the tongue & brains in saffron,  for appetizers....and a variety of all the kabobs for main. Everything was absolutely delicious!  I had the lamb shishkabob, it was juicey and tender.  Service was fast, friendly and efficient. Overall a wonderful experience. Highly recommend it.
author: Shirin O.

description: I've tried a lot of Persian food, and the food here was amazing!  This place is one of the best Persian restaurants in California.  The eggplant dip (Kashk Bademjoon) was the best, and I love the other appetizers; vegetables and dips Mast o Musir, and Mast o Kiar (tasted like sour cream and onion).  Most importantly, the meats were very tasty.  I would definitely recommend it for quality and service.  The only minor gripe; I wish the place had some degree of traditional Persian decor, as the ambiance makes the experience more enjoyable.
author: Jeremy B.

description: I took my team at work here for a lunch and was hoping the reviews were accurate since I'd never been. After a trek up the Coit Tower steps with much complaining, we arrived at the restaurant. They all really liked it and I left satisfied with the experience. I don't usually eat at Persian restaurants since I have Persian food at home and THAT is the real deal. Our party was pretty big-around 12 people. Our waitress was very friendly and accommodating. The food was great and portions were huge (accurate to Persian-style). We tried the koobideh, mast-o-khier (plain yogurt with dill and cucumbers), ghormeh sabzi, ghayme, and joojeh (chicken) kebab. I would definitely come back even though it obviously can't compare to mom's home-cooking.
author: Salma R.

description: Fine Persian dining in North Beach.  Was surprised by the the upscaleness of the place upon walking in.  Surprised again by the apps of basil, feta, onion, radish (Were these garnish or should I eat this?  Being that I have food babies all the time, the answer is always a resounding EAT it!) served up with pita bread - simple, but the flavors of each item jumps out at you and is enhanced by the others. For the main course, we ordered the shish kebab and the chicken breast kebab (see pic).  Loved all the flavors together.  Wonderful basmati rice, grilled veggies - tomatoes, onions, etc. Chicken was lightly flavorful.  Lamb more gamey.  Delightful meal.
author: Peg S.

description: Ok Persian restaurant in North Beach.  Cool Mongolian hostess.  It's rare that you see a woman with Asian features and colored eyes.  Most Asian women that have colored eyes have colored contact lenses.  Don't be fooled by fake jewels but I digress.  I still like Al Borz in Berkeley the best for Persian food.
author: Laurence H.

description:
