Great place to have persian food... The atmosphere was intimate and you could actually carry on a conversation. The tadiq and kebab was very flavorful, as was the saffron rice with barberry.  I even liked the Persian Lady, which was vodka and pomegranate juice! Yum.

The only weird thing was that the sign out front was for an italian restaurant, so we were a little confused and not sure we were at the right place. Plus, the jewelry shop two doors down didn't even know there was a persian restaurant nearby.

The restaurant is nicely located near lots of bars, so it is a good place to go for dinner with drinks afterwards.
author: Trish s.

description: Solid persian restaurant in San Francisco!  My go-to place for a good kabob.  :)
author: Fontane L.

description: I enjoyed the food here, although it was a little more upscale than I expected. The prices were perhaps a tiny bit higher than I think were warranted, but then again, I left more than satisfied and I really enjoyed my meal. I'm definiately heading back.
author: Ken F.

description:
as old as the pyramids. I had not been there in years and ate there a few weeks ago since no one else could seat us. 
The food was at best average.
author: No O.

description: First of all the  price in menu not correct also they add Tips by thim self thst make service weak.
author: Raed A.

description: Recently on 8/23/15, my family and I ( 5 of us.)  went to this place for lunch. What a mistake and disappointment. I'm just wondering how this place is getting all 4 stars, if I could,I would have given them 0 star.Overall food were tasteless, the chicken kabobs were burnt and dry, the Koobiedeh with lots of fillers and my Shishlik ( lamb Kabob.) burnt outside and totally raw inside. What a shame, for the prices they are charging people,at least they can provide some decent food. Please save your money for real Persian food and restaurant. This restaurant did't get our vote. I don't  recommend this place at all.
author: Amir P.

description:
I don't normally go out of my way for Persian food, but a buddy of mine recommended this place and to my surprise the food was very good.  But I really didn't go all out for the normal Persian cuisines, My friends and I decided to order the 2 different Steaks on the Menu.  One is Rib-Eye, the other Filet Mignon.  Both are absolutely wonderful!  If you prefer the typical rib-eye, this one here is full of flavor and is broiled to perfection and is very filling.  It gets the job done.  The Filet Mignon is also amazing.  It is of course one of the softest meats and they broil it and add an excellent stroganoff sauce to it that just makes it mouth watery!  

The atmosphere is very classy looking, but you roll in casual.  The seating is a bit close together, but it's not a huge place so it's understandable.  The parking isn't the best cause it is in the Telegraph/North Beach area where parking is a mess, but they do valet.  Depending on the time the valet may be your best bet.  But all in all, this place is wonderful and would come back for the Steak alone!
author: Jeremaine R.

description:
This place is great!! I've never been to the actual restaurant, but their delivery is amazing. Every time I order delivery (about once a month), they say it will take 40-50min, but they ALWAYS come within 25minutes! 

The food is delicious and always delivered hot. I highly recommend the kashke-bodemjoon and khoresht-ghormeh sabzi.
author: Roxana S.

description:
Overall 3.5 stars

Things I liked:
- friendly waiter (great discussion on the current world cup standings) 
- eggplant and mint garlic sauce appetizer (aka Kashke Bademjan)
- running into an old friend

Things I thought were ok:
- ambiance - a bit on the loud side 
- chicken kebab and basmati rice with berries (aka Zereshk Polo)
- marinated chicken thighs (aka Joojeh Kebab)

I still prefer Chelokababi in Sunnyvale and Molana in Boston.
author: Helen Y.

description: Been going to Maykadeh for several years, and they never disappoint. Service and quality of the food is consistently excellent.
author: Andrea N.

description: The only ONLY imperfection? Bright lighting. Otherwise, stone cold perfection- from the sabzee and paneer, to the Chelo- kebab koobideh and valet parking in a challenging 'hood...
author: Adrienne P.

description: I found this restaurant on yelp and we went there last night. We had no reservation. The owner warmly greeted us and sat us right away. The service was great. The food was amazing!!! I had the prawns and my husband had the rack of lamb. While we were waiting for our bill, the owner came over and asked us to move to another table as he needed our table for a large party and we told him we were done and ok to leave just waiting for our bill. The owner insisted we take the new table where he had graciously provided 4 desserts and another glass of the wine I was drinking, all complimentary. I would absolutely recommend this restaurant for the lovely ambiance, cute North Beach vibe, the food and the service.
author: Marian W.

description:
this is my first time trying persian food and so many iranians i know highly recommended this place so i decided to give this place a go. if iranian people from iran love the place, it's gotta be good right? 

hell yea, it was! i practically devoured my chelo-kebab koobideh in 3 mins because that's how sumptulicious it was! the only reason this isn't a 4 star review is because the appetizers weren't amazing and i am a huge appetizer snob. everything appetizer-y is a cheese spread of a variety mix thereof or a salad but then again, it is the main dishes that you will fall in love with. kebab lovers, look no further!

next time i am here, i really want to order the boiled brain topped with lime and saffron. no one in my group said they wanted to try it so i decided not to order it- i suppose they were just watching their bloodwork (at 100% cholestrol, i guess its an artery blocker).
author: The Hangry Chef O.

description: Every one I bring here loves the food. High quality and great service.
author: Sammy D.

description: It was Sat night and decide to go Maykadeh persian Cuisine I think I got attracted by name Maykadeh which is used in urdu and persian poetry oftenly. We called for reservation but they said reservation not needed but when we got there they said you have to wait which is ok but then this place has no waiting area so we waited outside on the street in cold windy night. Parking was another issue and we have to have for Valet parking because there was only person who was trying his best to do his job. Feel sorry for him because this is hilly street and its not easy.  Finally got inside the restaurant and it is cute little cozy place. Tables were very close to each other so you can see who order what or what are they talking about :). Order appetizer and it was wrong order, Ask for water with lemon few time but she keep forgetting to bring the water. I didn't give up and keep asking her. Food was good but not very authentic persian food may be because of neighborhood or I Don't know. Ask for mint but keep getting parsley leaves. So they sure need to take care of their service skills. It was bit pricy but not bad. Now should I go back and try one more time that I don't know.... may be :)
author: Annie A.

description: Delicious and authentic Persian cuisine and experience. I had the lamb, eggplant and tomato dish which was delicious. Hidden gem in North Beach with a lovely ambience--definitely check it out!
author: Tracy H.

description: All around good food. Good service. However, the vegetarian dishes are nothing more than the normal dishes without the meat (and are subsequently relatively boring). Meat eaters rejoice, but veggies beware.
author: Dan F.

description:
These stormy evenings have been giving us more reasons to try out restaurants who offer delivery services.  So last night, we tried Maykadeh.  When we found them on Eat24, we were very excited to try their food, especially since my partner enjoyed Persian food very much but has not had them for a while.  We ordered their lamb tongue appetizer, their chicken kebab (Joojeh) and their lamb shank (Ghorrme Sabzee).  The tongue was the best of the lot!  They were utterly tender and have so much flavor.  The sauce that they came with were also perfect for soaking up either the enormous amount of pita bread or the equally generous amount of basmati rice the orders came with.  The kebabs were our next favorite, with big, moist hunks of chicken and grilled vegetables included.  The lamb shank was not as sought after because the green sauce (we thought it was spinach but there was no mention of that ingredient on their online menu) was too 'grassy' tasting.  My partner, however, was optimistic that it will be more to our liking the next day, when the dish spent a night in the fridge.  Well, she was right of course.  We shared it for lunch today and the dish was better integrated and was thoroughly enjoyable.  

The delivery service was quite excellent.  Eat24 gave us a delivery estimate of 45-60 mins. and they arrived in about 40 minutes.  The portions were quite large with the aforementioned carbs.  Yes, we liked!
author: Yvette F.

description:
How have i not reviewed Maykadeh!!!???

I have been coming here for years, I definitely consider it one of the better persian restaurants in northern CA. (you just cant compare persian cuisine to socal...its way better there). But maykadeh can hold its own for sure. 

The atmosphere is clean and cozy and quiet. It is located off of broadway in north beach and parking is a huge hassle, but thankfully they have valet and their valet has a lot near by so they arent parking ur car on the street and moving it around constantly. 

I always get some kind of kabab, and they are all very good. Their tadig has good and bad days and their khoroshts are average. But no one really goes to persian resto's to eat khorosh, so no biggie.  We've had the same server for the last 15 years and the service has been the same, boring and angry... but no one is there to mingle with the server and none of us need any explanation on what to eat so again, no biggie, but if you are non-persian, the service might be an issue.

They bring about a pound of warm bread out before your meal it goes great with their very delicious mast -o -mousir mmmm, but go easy on the bread because portions are huge!
author: Shadi N.

description:
I finally made it to Maykadeh and I was impressed!  Earlier this year I spent three weeks in Iran so I have been hesitating on eating Persian food because I was afraid of disappointment, Maykadeh did not disappoint.  I ordered the chicken fesanjoon, oh my, my mouth was in heaven.  It tasted as good as I had in Iran.  The noon (naan) was fresh and warm, the rice was delicious; I have to stop typing my mouth is watering...

Update: I have been back a handful of times since my first review and every time I have been very satisfied.  The service I had was excellent and the food, as always, was delicious.  One thing to remember is that this is a Persian restaurant, not an American restaurant that serves Persian food.  The servings are identical to what I had in Iran.
author: Michael M.

description: On my last trip to San Francisco, I've visited Maykadeh restaurant for a cupel of time. Although I heard there are a lot of great Persian/Iranian restaurant in the nearby area, but I could not keep myself going to Maykadeh. No regret. It couldn't be better. Everything was the same as before. For the first time, I ordered a Chicken Poussin and I was amazed with the first bite. Also, I tried some other Kabob dishes. Juicy, tender, and outstanding. Just a friendly advise Maykadeh; You really need a good bartender for your restaurant, but don't get me wrong. Drinks are OK and could be better. Good job "Maykadeh."
author: Amir A.

description:
This restaurant is a rip off. THEY HAVE A AWFUL CUSTOMER SERVICE. They are rude and very unprofessional. They charge for refills and the food was bad quality. I would not recommend to go there. They do not bother to ask what do you need.
The prices wooooooooooooooooooow.
author: Lida S.

description: Lousy Persian food. the place is nice and the service is good but i would not recommend this place for Persian food.
author: Siroos H.

description:
Yes the food is good (the rice isn't great though for a Persian restaurant) and the price point works too. 
What doesn't work is the pace. We simply don't like when the food arrives so fast and the whole dinner lasts exactly 1 hour (including appetizer course) instead of 2. Feels flat for a date night. 
We end up coming here once every other year which is about what it takes for the memory loss.
author: Elsa T.

description: Unbelievably delicious food you will not find anywhere else in the area. Whether you're a meat eater or Vegetarian you will not find more exotically delicious flavours. Try the eggplant stew. Yummmy.  Or the Saffron and lime marinated chicken kabob. You can't go wrong.  Try the persian Saffron icecream. wow out of this world taste. I have taken sophisticated guests there from all over the world and they all fell in love with the food.
author: Dee B.

description: I came here looking for some Persian food since I love Persian food. I always judge a Persian restaurant by their rice . The rice quality used here was not basmati and I think that is the best rice. It was also not fully flavored by saffron, they had used saffron sparingly. The food was just average so I will give it 3 stars.
author: Fahad N.

description:
The food is still great at this place. The chicken is cooked perfectly & seasoned just right. The rice is great & the portions are just fine. 


The service, well we don't go to restaurants for good service, do we?
author: A. B.

description: Best Persian in the city. You can't go wrong with the Kabab koobideh and the Ghormeh Sabzi.  Excellent service, and they even deliver and always arrives fresh!
author: Sebastian R.

description: Incredible, delicious food! Including for a vegetarian like me. The staff is super friendly and gives good advice on what to choose. I can't wait to go back!
author: Sara N.

description:
Tucked away in the heart of North Beach, right up the street from all the hustle and bustle is where you will stumble upon Maykadeh. Maykadeh serves up a large menu of Persian appetizers, entrees, and desserts.

The interior is larger than expected, making it an ideal spot for groups and special celebrations. The food is good and they have specials on Mondays and Sundays (see on-line menu).

I recommend ordering numerous appetizers like the yogurt with elephant garlic and the Shirazi salad. This seems to be a strong point and with offerings like hummus, baked feta spread, and roasted vegetables there are many more small dishes I would like to try. 

The entrees are plentiful, but I was really hoping for a grilled vegetable kebab. There are two entrees that have a vegetarian option. I will probably go back, as well as continue trying new Persian spots.
author: Theresa T.

description: Excellent food, excellent service, excellent location. I live in the northeast but sometimes crave the food from Maykadeh. Definitely one of my all time favorite restaurants.
author: Me G.

description:
The food was quite nice. We ordered the kashke bademjan (eggplant) and beef/lamb sausage for appetizers. Then we shared the ghorme sabzee and another eggplant dish. All were tasty, well seasoned and had a nice hint of tartness from the lime. The standout was definitely the kashke bademjan appetizer. It was creamy, well-seasoned and perfectly paired with the flatbread and basil provided. The rest of the dishes were good, but not particularly different from what I've eaten before. 

Some negatives about this restaurant are that the service is not particularly hospitable, attentive nor timely. No rude behavior occurred but there was a general indifference. I also expect high quality or house made feta with my radishes, not butter. Similarly, the rice was over-cooked and was not infused with any type of aromatic. Overall it was an average dining out experience. My search for excellent Persian food continues.
author: Ele C.

description:
This is a pretty solid Persian restaurant in the heart of North Beach. I've been here twice, once with a foodie friend and then last night. I had the Maykadeh Kebab last night, it was excellent. 

Several years ago I remember distinctly having the curried sheep brain appetizer and not liking the texture. It was my first brain sampling - since then, I have discovered that Maykadeh's brains were overcooked. Everything else seems to be superior here, but I recommend against the brains.
author: Darren M.

description: the food was not as good as I expected. I got the kabab which wasn't that great but we got Fesenjoon and that was good. the service was good. it was right by little Italy which was good.
author: M M.

description:
Do you LOVE generous portions of delicious Persian food? Does a feta cheese spread, koobideh, or the thought of hummus make your mouth water? If so, make a reservation, and head over to Maykadeh.

My parents picked this place, and I was QUITE content. The ambiance is nice, but the tables are arranged in a way that makes it difficult to traverse around the restaurant. But, the food totally makes up for the discomfort of bumping chairs with your neighbor. 

We ordered: a bottle of the Cambria pinot (delish, $20 more than market price), hummus, feta spread, and 4 orders of the kebab koobideh. There was plenty of food leftover. They also give you complimentary pita bread, and a plate of onions/cheese/basil...interesting. For dessert we had 2 orders of the poached pears with rosewater ice cream--TDF!

I WILL be back.
author: Misha F.

description: Elegant and sophisticated tasting food.  I love the fresh basil leaves.  Nice spices.  Too bad more Persian places cannot be found.
author: Abigail J. M. M.

description: I can not believe I have lived in North Beach for 15 years and have never been here before...well actually I still have not been to the restaurant. I ordered delivery via EAT24. The food is excellent, delivery was quick, food was hot,  fresh and tasty.
author: Renee E.

description: Came back with my bf and my fam for Persian new year and I really wasn't too happy. The food didn't taste fresh and my koobideh wasn't good. I'm a little shocked that people love this place so much.
author: Sheeva G.

description:
I am Iranian and very foody!,  The food was generally good but cooked in not healthy way. The "Khoresht Bademjan" or Eggplant Stew was fake and cooked by some shortcuts and cheating. The "Kobideh Kabad" was full of oil. compare to north cal other restaurant it is good but not outstanding at all.
I also think they are a little sneaky on your bill!
author: K Z.

description:
Oh so yummy... yes yes yes! I love saffron and cucumber and mint and basil and yogurt and rice and lamb and beef and chicken and everything else I had. 
I don't know the names, all I know is that we've ordered catering for work from this place 2x and each time I am impressed by the freshness, the spices and the flavor. 
Outstanding.
author: Edi B.

description: This place is good for Americans who want to try Persian food. The food was a joke and they charge for basic Persian food staples like onion, sabzi, etc. Small portions and unnecessarily pricey. Def not a Persian restaurant. Lavash in inner sunset blows this place away!
author: Rouz E.

description: I finally got to try this place as it was on my list, and it's really, really very good.  We stuffed ourselves -- our waitperson, BB (who is lovely) didn't steer us wrong.  The Kashe Bademjan (eggplant w/mint garlic sauce) was really flavorful and warm dish. Of the entrees, the grilled stuff was a standout--lamb Shishlik and the grilled giant Prawns were succulent.  We also had traditional Khoresht Fesenjoonsweet and Sour Sauce (chicken thighs with a ground walnut pomegranate sauce) and Zereshk Polo (chicken with barberry saffron rice) that were equally fantastic.  I 've always loved the different Persian rice pilafs and can't get enough of it.  Needless to say, we rolled out of the place stuffed.
author: Nancy H.

description: I am rating this bad restaurant ZERO star I swear I hate it so much and it is a fake arabian restaurant I was wondering how the over all rating is 4 stars. I strongly regretted when I ate there
author: Yaz M.

description:
Went here with some co-workers and it was pretty good! 
The inside is really cute and cozy.  It was pretty empty when we got there, but maybe it was because it was the afternoon?  I ordered the lamb kebab, lentil soup & the dough drink (it sounded really interesting and I decided to be adventurous and try it).

The food was delicious, although I'm not sure I would get dough again.  It was an experience to say the least!  Portions are HUGE! I could only finish about half of my kebab. The service was good too.
author: Kei H.

description: Fantastic food. I've been here a few times and each time we've ordered as many things from the menu as we could. Amazing flavors and great friendly service. If you get a chance try the saffron fries they are incredible.
author: MacKenzie S.

description:
It pains me to give Maykadeh less-than-stellar marks, but I have my reasons.

1. Portion size: When you order kabob koobideh at other restaurants, you have no hope of finishing what's on your plate. At Maykadeh, you pay more and get less on your plate. The quality is no better than that of any other Persian restaurant in Sacramento or Los Angeles.

2. Refills: Soda is overpriced here, and refills cost full price. If you're big on beverages, like me, this is a sore spot.

3. Parking: A $10 valet service doesn't put me in the mood to eat. I understand parking is scare in the big city, but that's why you invest in a lot and make your customers feel welcome with free parking. Other restaurants do it.

The restaurant does show great customer service in its packaging of to-go orders. Mine had separate containers for the khoresht and rice. And greens were packed in yet another box for snacking. Well done.
author: Kiarash Z.

description:
If I could give less than one star I would.  

Here's why:   

We met with Sasha of Maykadeh Persian Restaurant and catering on July 1st to see if they would be a good fit for our wedding in September.  At first glance, the website and catering pictures were beautiful.  I am persian, and so we wanted to have persian food- in particular- we wanted the persian presentation of food.  Sahsa met with us, promised that he would be able to cater our wedding.  He said that he would come up with a menu and let us know by July 5th.  We exchanged e-mail and phone numbers.

Two weeks went by,  no word.  I had written him on July 5th- just a friendly "we can't wait to see the menu".  We called,  he said he had sent the menu - but would resend it in 45 minutes.  I checked our spam folders, junk mail, no menu.  no message.  We called his restaurant for over a week- and still NO RESPONSE.  He never called the second time to see if we had gotten his e-mail he claimed to be sending.

It seems like something else came up - or he had another plan/ event.  Either that or he is just VERY DISORGANIZED.  

All in all, it turned out to be everything we feared in going with Persian food for our wedding - lots of empty promises and no follow through.  I mean,  It has now been a month, and we haven't heard a thing from him despite all our messages.  Isn't the polite thing to do - to write an e-mail to say " sorry, something else came up"?  or give some explanation.

It's sad - because we are persian and would love to have delicious persian food at our wedding.  But, why are we as a people so UNRELIABLE?  Why can't we get with the program and do what we say?  Is it too much to ask to be able to rely on having your culture's food at your wedding?

Instead we have found a great caterer, elsewhere.  But, it's not persian food.

so disappointed.
author: PS M.

description:
Not that good for Persian Cuisine. The meat isn't that great and the service is not good either. 

I don't recommend this to anyone who wants to try Persian food for the first time...

and I've got some insider information about the way they manage their kitchen....you won't want to eat there!

Try Shalizar instead! or Alborz.... 
Shalizar goes first!
author: T I.

description:
Yeah, I'm Persian...so I have to do a rating of all my favorite Persian spots in the bay. Don't let my rating fool you, their food is 4.5 star quality.

But man, the service sucks here...and the prices are way too high compared to some other places. I guess it's SF, so whatever, but still...

If you go here, and you are not Persian (you would know what to order), I recommend:

Kabob Koobideh (ground beef)
Kabob Barg (steak kabob)
Soltani (one of each)

Or if you prefer chicken, get the Joojeh kabob.
These are the things we usually order when we go to a Persian restaurant.

The things I like to eat at home that they serve here:
Ghormeh Sabzi
Fesenjoon (Chicken w/ Pomegranate sauce -- Americans like this)
and on Sundays: Baghali Polo with Lamb Shank (really good!)

Overall, the best Persian restaurant in SF, but definitely not the best in the bay area.
author: AC M.

description: Amazing food, service, and atmosphere.  Prices are very reasonable, big portions, and good selection.  Meat and veggies are very good quality and they also have organic selection.  We were visiting San Francisco for 3 days and ate in this restaurant twice just because their food is really really good.
author: Anna S.

description:
This place has it all. Not only is the food to die for, the service is amazing as well. We were a party of 6 and after the waiter messed up one of my son's orders the manager fixed the mistake (which was incredibly small, but you know how picky children are) , and gave all 6 of us complimentary dessert! 

For sure going back in the future!
author: Emiliano T.

description: Excellent food. Had the soltani kebab and it was one of the best. Dining room is crowded and where we sat was uncomfortable (front of dining room near the window). No chairs, just a pillow on a wood bench with no back support. Table was very low as a result. But it wasn't too bad. My wife says it's her favorite Persian food now so that's all I need to know.
author: Bary P.

description:
I went here with a couple of friends and was blown away by everything we ordered. The food was fresh and bursting with flavor. Our favorite appetizers were a eggplant purée with mint, the homemade yogurt with cucumber, and the dish with crispy rice on the bottom (I can't remember the name but it's worth inquiring about...so amazing).

For entrees we shared the ground beef and lamb kabob, baby chicken, lamb shanks and filet of beef with saffron rice and pomegranate rice. It's difficult to describe how moist and flavorful each dish was. Everything was succulent and savory without being cooked or too salty. I thought I'd mastered roasting chicken (via Alice Waters' recipe) but I've got nothing on Maykadeh's baby chicken.

For dessert, we shared the unique and delicious Persian ice cream (rose water and pistachio), creme caramel (similar to creme brulee mixed or flan) and the homemade baklava. Everyone had a different favorite dish they insisted was the best they'd ever tried; mine was the Baklava.

The service was also remarkable. I've never had my water and wine glasses filled so often or in such an unassuming and quiet way. I highly recommend this restaurant to any foodie looking for a great ambiance and culinary experience. I'll be heading back to Maykadeh as often as possible.
author: Lauren L.

description:
Having been coming here for over 20 years.  My favorite Persian restaurant. Period.
Always consistent tasty authentic Persian food.
author: Arya M.

description: One of the best jooneh kababs I've had. It's certainly not the typical saffron flavoured we Persians are used to, but the delicately infused  oriental flavour given to the very moist and well marinated chicken breast chunks makes it that much more delicious and succulent. I loved the fact that you get a small box of complimentary sabzee with your take away order. Try it out.
author: Natalie B.

description:
Going here for good Persian food is like going to Taco Bell for authentic Mexican food. 1 star for the good service and 1 star for ambiance. 

The polo (rice) tasted like they used food coloring instead of saffron. It was also soggy and overcooked. The koobideh was "eeh" at best. 

If you want good Persian food this place is not it.
author: Henri G.

description:
Oh my! I go loco and keep craving for this restaurant. I love love love their koobideh! The best! And when I say the best, I mean it. Because I live in eastcoast and one day I craved for that koobideh so I searched nonstop for a restaurant in new york that offerskoobideh in beef and lamb. The verdict : I was so disappointed. Plus the tomato was not sweet.

Maykadeh- the flavor is consistent and also their tomato is the best! Sweet! And I have triedmseveral times here and never tasted different. That is why whenever I go to san francisco, I dont mind taking home more foods from this place.
author: A J.

description: Was there AGAIN recently and still providing great service and delicious persian cuisines. They deserve 5 starts.
author: Kajal P.

description:
This was the first time I've had Persian food, and it was quite good. I went with one other person; we got there at around 6 pm on a Saturday and didn't have too much trouble getting a table, but I'd recommend getting a reservation just in case.

They started us off with pita bread that we could put butter, basil leaves, radishes, and onions on, along with some kind of spice I couldn't identify. I usually never eat food like this, so I enjoyed it.

I ordered a Breast Kebab (chicken) while my friend ordered Khoresht Bademjan (lamb). Mine came with a lot of extra vegetables, including asparagus, tomato, and onions. The chicken was a bit dry, but adding lemon helped and overall it was pretty delicious and filled me up. The lamb was extremely tender and well done, though the only problem to me was that the entire dish seemed to be one texture and got to be a bit much. Overall, it was a delicious and unique experience.

The service was also very commendable. Though this was our first time, the servers were prompt in asking us how we liked our food, refilling our water, etc. I also saw them interact with returning customers and talk with them like old friends.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Unbelievable Persian food!!! Absolutely delicious!!! I would go back any day, the place is a bit small, but very nice and very clean, great service, best Persian food in SF, bar none!!!
author: Rob L.

description: Whats good about this place?  The quality of the meat (tender and delicious) and the perfectly spiced stews.  I found that the chicken kabob and lamb stew make a perfect combination with the rice and cooked tomato.  Never been disappointed with this one, fine dining in north beach.  A bit pricey but definitely worth it.  I would suggest valet parking, north beach can be rough.
author: Prakhar S.

description: We had a fabulous dinner family style for our family of four.  We started out with red wine, Kashke Bademjan - eggplant, mint garlic sauce lentil and vegetable soup, and calf brain (yeah, calf brain, it was good).  We also had two dinners:  Poussin (Baby chicken with all the bones marinated in onion, saffron, lime juice, vegetables and Basmati rice) and Baghali Polo (fava beans, dill, rice, served with lamb shank in a glazed onion saffron sauce).  The portions are large, there was plenty of food.  The quality of the food is very good.  Every dish was fresh, flavorful and well balanced.  The restaurant is in a good location, close enough to the heart of North Beach's vibrant Columbus Ave, without being in the middle of the chaos that comes with being on Columbus.  The staff was very attentive and helpful.  We all enjoyed this dinner.
author: t d.

description: Best Persian food in SF! Amazing! Chicken Kebabs, shrirazi salad and rice all out of this world! Not to mention--- they deliver. :)
author: Lacey L.

description:
The food here is fair but the wait staff was horrible (to us- my husband and I, a quiet, friendly couple).  The host was quite happy to see us enter the restaurant this weekend, but the service was down hill from there.  The host/server #1 and additional female server #2 seemed to be quite devoted to the three other tables occupied (did they all order a $200 bottle of wine or something?), so I hope they were compensated accordingly.

I'm from LA and my best friend is Persian (with a mom who cooks the BEST, freshest food) , so to anyone with a similar background- skip this restaurant.
author: yvette l.

description: Descent persian food, a bit pricy but good. Their Soltani is great !
author: Monica R B.

description:
Thank you Maykadeh, for a lovely evening with great food and great service!

My lamb was wonderful (not fatty like lamb in Utah, where I am) and delicately spiced, and the amount of saffron on the rice was just right for me.  I very much liked having sumac at the table, as well as the continuous supply of wonderfully warm bread.  The tea was very good too, and my fiance (who lived in Saudi Arabia for a few years) said it is was just as good as he had there.  The hummus was also excellent, and very plentiful for the price.

The service was attentive, but not annoying.  Our waiter (a young man with glasses) had an excellent demeanor as well and was very quick to get drinks, our food, etc.  I did not expect such speedy service, but I got it!

The real stand-out (though the whole meal was incredible) was the dessert.  We had the poached pears in a Shiraz reduction with the rose ice cream.   It was utterly wonderful!  If you are going there, definitely get dessert!  

I also appreciated the calm, romantic (but still lively) vibe to the place, especially given than just a block down was choked with obnoxious drunks looking for pizza, haha.  

Next time I am in SF, I will definitely be going back to Maykadeh!
author: Sarah C.

description: Love this place. Since we live just a block away and often get tired of eating Italian, this is one of our go-to places in North Beach. Great for nicer sit-down dinners when we have friends visiting, plenty of options for vegetarians, and they do an excellent job with their takeout items (they'll even make sure you get the onion/basil that they usually serve with the pita). Friendly staff and great service.
author: Alison S.

description:
Life doesn't get much better than great food with great friends. About 20 of us celebrated my belated birthday last night here on the recommendation of one of my friends who happens to be Persian. I fully trusted her recommendation, and I'm so glad I did!

We started with the brain, which was good, as well as the Kashke Bademjan, Shirazi salad, and Mast-o-Khier. All were perfect with the yummy flat bread. Many ordered the Koobideh since it's the specialty. I ordered the Saltani, which came with a skewer of Koobideh, too. Both skewers were delish, as was the basmati rice it came with. Another friend ordered the Khoresht Fesenjoon, which I tried and loved. And someone else ordered the Shishlik, which was also really good. 

Of course, I had to have Bastani for dessert, and we shared Pallodeh as well. Everything was really good. 

Some of my fellow yelpers have noted that this place is expensive, but I completely disagree. I think that the prices are very reasonable for both the quality of the food and the location of the restaurant. And no one in my group had a problem with substituting veggies for the rice. 

My only concern, which resulted in the loss of a star, is the lack of quality vegetarian options on the menu. There are a couple of dishes that can be made vegetarian, but then all your getting essentially is the rice, and for almost the same price. 

The staff was also very nice and very helpful in making the reservation and estimated head counts with me. Apparently, the service isn't known for being great to non-Persian customers. I didn't really have a problem, although one of my friends was Persian, and by coincidence, a friend of hers who happened to be in town for a conference and was eating alone joined us, and he was Persian as well. So, who knows. All I know is that I will definitely go back to try some of the other dishes!
author: Amy B.

description:
Yum.

The service was prompt and respectful (despite us having a party of 10). The baba ganoush was delicious. Between the ten of us, we tried nearly every chicken and lamb dish (excepting the tongue and brain) and they were perfectly seasoned and cooked. Everything tasted good. The portions are large enough to share two between three people.

Also, re: the onion, radish, and basil that are on the table. The onion is for flavoring dishes if you want to change them up. The basil is a palate cleanser if you want one. I forget what the radish is for.
author: Alice A.

description:
Food:
Awesome! We were hungry, so we skipped the appetizers, and jumped straight to the main course. The lamb is to die for. I ordered Shishlik - medium done. Not only was it tender, but it was juicy as well. The rice that it comes with is delicious too, but for the fact that u can tell it was cooked in a pool of butter! 
My friends ordered the Joojeh Kebab, and the Breast Kebab, and the samples I tried were yum! A lot of preparation went into the meat, and you can tell. 

Drinks:
Couple of my friends ordered drinks, and it seems the Maître d' isnt the best at mixing drinks. 

Service:
Not the best in the business. When you go to restaurants in the city enough, you get used to the fussing over to ensur everything is OK. That didnt happen here. We were basically left to ourselves once we placed our orders. After the bill arrived, it almost felt like we were being thrown out of the place. The music is too loud for a restaurant, making it hard for any meaningful conversation with the anyone at the table. 

So, if you dont mind eating a meal listening to some Arabic music, and just watching your friends enjoy their meal, the food definitely makes this place worth it.
author: Gurpreet S.

description:
Only beautiful people seem to set their foot here, but the food is simply not up to the standard. Neither is it good value for money.

An excellent valet service is located right outside the restaurant at $10.
author: Martin V.

description: Very small portions for the price. 1 lamb skewer with 4 pieces of lamb (small pieces) for 26 bucks?! I went here before with a party and I remembered it was pretty good.Not anymore. They really cut back. They used to serve bread with feta to start with. Now they do not. It appears they cut way back. I say i am cutting back and NEVER going again and will NEVER recommend.
author: S. G.

description: Had the rack of lamb, it was amazing. Nice place for a family meal if you're out celebrating. Pricy, but cheaper options that are just as good. The rice is some of the best Persian rice I've ever had (not quite as good as my Grandma's, but even she thought it was delicious). I agree on the service comments, it's not the "best" in the world, but if you thought you were going to get happy-go-lucky service from a Persian, ha.
author: Josh I.

description: We ordered Koobideh kabab. It was very fatty and didn't taste good. Their customer service was not that great as well. They didn't check on us till we finished our food, and we had to ask to refill the water pitcher ourselves. Also, they were't friendly which is very unfortunate. I think as a Persian restaurant they could have tried to decorate the restaurant accordingly which they didn't. Our favorite is Chelokababi in Sunnyvale which is by far better in every aspect compared to this restaurant and it is also less expensive.
author: Ma W.

description:
This place has GREAT Persian food!.  

I love Zereskh (barberries) Polo, but I decided to change it up one day and replaced my chicken with Koobedeh (ground beef skewer).  Since then, that has become my one and only dish there. :) SOOO YUM.  I have tried others meals, and they are all great as well.  But that Zereskh, man oh man, none like it! 

The only down side is taking left overs home... PEEEEE-U! That is all I have to say about it... To be fair to Maykadeh, it is not their issue, seems like most Persian kabob left overs STINK.  

The staff, very nice - especially Sasha (I think that is his name).
Try it out, you wont be disappointed.   

I have been there at least 6 times this year and the great food is consistent.
author: Belina G.

description: AS GOOD AS IT GETS !!! Really good place to have dinner with your family and friends..... Service is really good !!! Every time we in city and want a good shish kebob this is the place to go and nice full bar !!! We will see u really soon !!!
author: Boris M.

description:
I'm Persian ancestrally and grew up on this stuff, but Maykadeh knows how to cook up a mean Persian meal.  Let's start with the staple, basmati rice.  The rice was slightly overcooked and didn't have the wonderful, rich flavoring that many other Persian restaurants in California bring to the table, but the portions were hearty.  

The fesenjan was simply delicious.  The tartness of the pomegranate distinguished the Maykadeh recipe, though I would have liked to have some more bite from the walnuts.  The chicken was cooked to perfection.  Still on the bone, it fell off easily and nearly melted in my mouth.  

The ash was tasty.  It had a wonderful texture that wasn't too runny or too saturated with beans.  As ashes go, it was mild and bland but a perfect complement to the meal.

I ordered gorme sabzi as well, but that will be my lunch at work tomorrow!  

Finally, the doogh.  Not bad for home-made doogh.  As a personal preference, I like doogh with carbonation (call it my Americo-centric, cabonation-happy existence) but the mint, spices and yogurt more than made up for the lack and provided just the right amount of bitterness to make it drinkable.  

All in all, a fine job.  

The price....well, let's leave that for another day!
author: cashburton A.

description:
A friend from work introduced me to Maykadeh.  Everything she ordered was great.  I recommend the following:

Mast-O-Khiar and Kashke Bademajan as appetizers
Maykadeh Sltani (koobidah and skewered filet mignon)
Khoresht Fesenjoon (dry roasted walnuts, pomegranate juice, chicken thighs, Basmati rice).

They have very large protions, there were 4 of us and we shared everything.  It is very quite at lunchtime.  They also serve take-out.
author: Dionne M.

description: This is one of the best Persian restaurants in the Bay Area.  I have been coming here with my husband for the past 13 years.  The service is great and the food is outstanding.  I especially love their signature cocktail, "The Persian Lady."
author: Shila F.

description: Great flavors, its a authentic when 75% of the patrons are Persian. Persians are stubborn so as long as the food is that par ill be back.
author: Seth B.

description:
I've had Maykadeh bookmarked for awhile partly because Vicky L. recommended it and partly because I love Persian food. I met up with my Grandma last night in North Beach and took her here because she loves lamb and is always down to try new things! She's just awesome like that. The restaurant was quiet on a Monday night which was perfect. I didn't want to take her somewhere very loud. We both really liked what we ordered and ended up sharing. We had:
-Khoresht ghaymeh: like a persian chili. small chunks of lamb with lentils, peas. etc. Very filling!
-Khoresht bademjan: the lamb shank was very meaty and the eggplant was cooked to perfection. 
-Persian tea: holy caffeine! i put sugar and mint in mine but couldn't drink more than 2 glasses. they will keep filling your glass if you leave it empty!
-Feta cheese: or fetid as my mother would say...theirs is super fresh and therefore super delicious!!
author: Sara P.

description:
There is a huge hype going on about Maykadeh, and honestly I don't know what the big deal is! Some say that this is the best Persian restaurant in SF, but I don't agree. The food is ok, nothing special about it. The taste of kabobs and stews do not come close to the standard that I as a Persian gauge the food to, but overall the food is ok here (stews are on the salty side).

Here is the not so pleasant part of the experience. We decided to have lunch at Maykadeh one week after we were there with a large group of friends. Being part of a large group we got taken care of pretty good and servers and the manager were very polite and friendly. BUT one week after when we visited the same place (my wife and I) we did not receive much service! The manager was serving some tables himself, and was pretty busy with a table where a couple of girls were sitting at. We had to wait a long time to get our food and even longer to receive the check. We even had to walk right up to the manager's counter to pay the bill and he still was busy with the girls.

All in all, I think the food deserve 3 stars and their service 2 stars at the best.
author: O N.

description:
Walked in the door on Sunday evening with my date to a half full Maykadeh greeted by a smile and "welcome, how may I help you?" As I began to respond, the host, without excusing himself takes a phone call while I was still talking to him. 
Walked out. Found my way to North Beach Restaurant. They put much more emphasis on service. 
Note: had to wait a few days to cool off before writing this review so that it would be appropriate for this site.
Maykadeh,
    I've enjoyed your food in the past. And would like to enjoy it again sometime soon.
author: Coco M.

description:
I'd never been to a Persian restaurant before.  My knowledge of Persian food consisted of home-cooked meals at friends' houses in high school (so their food was  legit, but my knowledge of it was certainly still quite rudimentary), but Maykadeh impressed me because it felt like I was eating a home-cooked meal.  Is it cheesy to say that the atmosphere (though table-clothed and sophisticated) made it feel like a family affair?

First of all they bring out a plate with fresh basil, feta cheese, raw onion and bread.  Being completely unsure of what to do, I pretty much just went for it.  A little cheese and basil on the bread.  Then a little onion with the cheese on the bread.  endless combos.  Funny though, being on a date, I had to think twice about digging into the raw onion, but i figured if we were both eating it then our onion breath would cancel out.  

we got some eggplant based appetizer which I thought was incredibly delicious.  I then got the ground beef and lamb kebab which was also very flavorful.  I wish I had been hungrier to begin the meal because I couldn't finish my dinner, but it was all so good.  

I really should go back and educate myself more on Persian cuisine. In terms of the food, ambiance, and service, it was a lovely experience.
author: Anne Marie B.

description: Ordered Maykadeh off of Gurbhub since we were getting sick of the usual offerings from Grubhub (Indian, Chinese, Thai, Sushi, etc.) The reviews were a mixed bag, however the food arrived within 30 minutes, it was still warm and amazing. We ordered the Breast Kabob (chicken), Chelo-Kabob Koobideh (ground lamb and beef), Shirazi Salad. When the food arrived I was stunned how great the preparation was and really felt like Maykadeh took pride in the product they sent out for deivery. The best part of it all was the servings were so large that we now have lunch for the following day. I will definitely check this place out again soon.
author: Deepak K.

description: Good food, great service. one suggestion, get a good set of steak knives. One of my party asked for one and it looked a little old and worn, otherwise a perfect night. Particularly impressed with the server. Very considerate and knowledgable. E.g. offered to give a sample of the yoghurt drink before we ordered oen which is just as well since after tasting it my friend did not like it and ordered a sprite instead. :)
author: Sean M.

description:
It was ok. I usually don't like kabobs and theirs was ok--I'm sure a kabob-eater would've enjoyed it.
The sweet/sour chicken dish was waay too sweet, otherwise the sauce would've been great.
The goat (or was it lamb?) dish was also good, although more/larger pieces of lamb would've been nice (it looked like beans).
The cheese served was fresh and nice.
Waiter was generally nice and accommodating, except he kept putting our unused dish on top of the leftover free appetizer greens...wtf?
overall, nothing exciting for the price.
author: Xue H.

description: The food seemed pretty authentic as it tasted similar to food I've had in Persian homes. The portions are large and their cocktail selection interesting. Veg entree option are limited, but overall a decent place for dinner. I was expecting something a little better (Persian just sounds exotic)!
author: Anna J.

description:
Excellent - try the lamb tongue.  I'm not kidding.  It's decadent.  

Great service.  Love this place.  If you like meat, you will like it here.
author: Tapedeck B.

description: Worst Persian food I've ever had. Barely edible lamb and beef skewers. The lamb stew looked like canned dog food and probably tasted worse (not that I've ever tried dog food). Total rip off considering the low quality food they offer, which seems devoid of any real passion.
author: Seymour B.

description: Take this from a Persian:  Best Persian restaurant I've ever been to! The barg kabab melts in your mouth :D
author: Shirin E.

description:
Fabulous dining experience! My friends introduced me to this Northbeach gem a few years ago and we love it. The service is friendly, food amazing. The prawns and lamb chops are my favorites. Just visited last weekend and the food and service remain excellent. Such a treat!
Thank you Maykadeh for wonderful Persian food in SF!
author: Michele P.

description: Not knowing much about Persian food I didn't really know what to expect. I was pleasantly surprised. While I didn't get too adventurous, what I ordered  (chicken kebabs) was very tasty! Will definitely return!
author: Des R.

description:
To start I must say this review could be considered semi-biased considering I am an Iranian who was lucky enough to be raised on some of the best Persian food you could imagine (thank you Grandma), making me pickier than the average reviewer...
I was really hoping this place would be as amazing as the Yelp and **former** Michelin star rating (its no wonder they were taken off the list this year around) suggest given it's one of the unfortunately few Persian restaurants in the area. Went in with high expectations, came out thinking it was just OK (especially when considering the pricing)...
Ordered: 
Soltani Kabab- my usual at Persian restaurants, thin layer of filet mignon (barg) and a skewer of ground beef/lamb (koobideh) served with basmati rice. My dad always says the best way to judge a Persian eatery is by their koobideh and in this case I wasn't too impressed, simply decent
Kashko Bademjan- eggplant with mint garlic sauce. Good appetizer. 
Atmosphere and service: 
Not a fan of the decor, could be either a little more traditional or modern, that and the service were once again OK.
And to that my quest to find a good Persian restaurant in the area continues :/ way to set the bar high for me grandma....
author: Mahsa K.

description: Very good service, since we were the 2nd only other table during our meal time. The place is a bit a ways out and maybe that was why business was slow. The plating was nice. The taste was pretty ok. Was a little disappointed that the kabobs did not seem to be real chunks of separate pieces of chicken. The bread was good and atmosphere was elegant. The people seemed busy prepping the place for the upcoming dinner, it seemed. I guess it makes better business at dinnertime then.
author: Felecia W.

description: I came here for a birthday dinner and our waitress was prompt with our 15+ party. Parking was difficult, we ended up parking about 5 blocks away. The restaurant does have parking for $10. We started out with the complimentary pita bread and plate of basil, cheese, and butter. I ordered the ghorme sabzee and my bf had the khoresht bademjan. My lamb shank was ok, slightly dry. My bf seemed to enjoy his food. He also tried the rocky mountain oysters and said it was good.
author: Tran N.

description: The food is good by the service is nothing to brag about. They tend to hire cheap servers that barely speak English and have no training to serve in a restaurant in this price range. Trying to maximize your profit by reducing the service quality is not a good business decision for a restaurant!
author: T V.

description: I went there before and I gotta' say that I don't like the food in there at all. I mean, the shrimp thing is OK, but the rest...bleh, forget about it! Oh, and even the Creme Caramel tasted just as awful. Sorry, Maykadeh, but you deserve only one star.
author: Roxanne P.

description:
Honestly, I think this place gets way more credit than is due. I'm pretty sure most of that credit is because it's the only 'real' Persian restaurant in San Francisco. 

Sure there are places in Berkeley and even farther east, but we all know Persians love to get dressed up in head-to-toe black leather, drenched in Chanel No 5, hop into their black Mercedes' (not before donning their Chanel sunglasses, no matter what time of day or night) and drive to The City, only to arrive en masse, to dinner at 11:45pm (which happens to be precisely 3 hours past the time agreed on by all participating parties). Plus, nobody will be impressed if you went to dinner in Danville.

Anyways, the food here is decent - not great, not bad, just decent. Add to the equation that the dishes are grossly overpriced, and it brings it down to just 'okay' for me.

And yes, the waiters talk smack about the customers in front of them, but we're Persians here - that's normal. In fact, if you're NOT being talked about, then you should worry.

As Jason R. says, befriend a Persian and try some real food. Who decided that kabob was the national food of Iran anyways??? I nominate tahdig. If you don't like it, wash off your Drakkar Noir and get thee to a post office to have your 'Persian' card revoked.

3 stars. If you are desperate for Persian food and have no Persian friends, go to Saks and hang out in the Gucci section for a while and make some new Irooni friends, or give up!

Note: Beware of the bathroom - it's all black porcelain, which makes it seem like you might fall in at any moment and get flushed away into an abyss....
author: Ahu S.

description:
This place is definitely for a meat lover!

I loved the upscale environment, the lovely flat bread and goodies for appetizers and their tasty hummus too.

I got the filet mignon and the meat was so tender and juicy.  Their ground lamb straight melted in my mouth.

Service itself was kinda slow, which I didn't have a problem with since we were there to visit with good friends.  They also didn't have a problem itemizing stuff out the bill and using multiple credit cards.

Also be warned, parking sucks here, but they can valet your car for you  for $10. 

Definitely not a cheap spot, I wouldn't ever pick this place on my own because there are definitely better places closer to home, but if ever invited out here again, I wouldn't mind going again.
author: Jaime P.

description: The wine menu is deliccccious and so is the food, I recommend joojeh or kabob barg uuuuhh sooo good white wine okay I need to stop this review my mouths watering reminiscing the food/wine
author: Shabnam A.

description:
My love affair with Persian food started when I lived in Long Beach many years ago. There's quite a Persian population down south, so finding a Persian restaurant wasn't too hard. So my experience with the cuisine encompasses a number of establishments. 

I've dined at Maykadeh quite a few times over the years, and it's on par with what I like in Persian cuisine. My mom's not Persian (surprise!)  so I have no idea what is truly authentic. But my Persian friends say this place is one of best...I have to say, I like it better than Alborz (on Van Ness) and Darya (Costa Mesa), both of which have a loyal following. 

Most notable differences between this place and others is that their meats are tender, flavorful and moist. Many places tend to overcook the chicken and the ground meats are a bit on the dry side. The koobideh (ground meat) is excellent whether you choose lamb or beef. The lamb dishes are definitely recommended and are not gamey. Filet Mignon proved tasty and tender. And the rice had the right texture, flavored with the usual saffron. One of my favorites is their little baby chicken...I don't know if it's really a baby chicken, but that's what I call it. It's served whole and is definitely worth having.

I did have dessert tonight, which I usually skip, because I'm usually stuffed from the sizeable dishes offered here. Both the flan and rosewater poached pears and ice cream proved themselves worth the calories. 

Maykadeh's atmosphere invites a bit of lingering after dinner. Modern Persian music plays in the background, and as the sun goes down, the lights strewn around the trees outside cast a nice ambiant light into the comfortable dining area....nice place for our girls night out, the birthday party next to us, and the kissy kissy couple in the corner.
author: Virg Y.

description:
Don't let these white folks fool you. 

Maykadeh is just as average as every other Persian restaurant around, but with a tidy North Beach mark-up. 

Do this instead: Make yourself a Persian friend and get invited to their crib. I promise they'll feed you better than this or any other Persian dump.
author: Jason R.

description:
I love it, it's so fun to stuff my face with Persian food. The lamb is always delicious, and the Basmati rice is addicting. I'm not usually big on rice, but when it comes to Basmati rice prepared Persian style all fluffy and buttery, I wolf it all down. Send me some insulin, I feel my blood glucose spiking. 

Maykadeh defeinitely does it all the way I like it. I had the lamb chop with Basmati rice. My friend had the Koobideh with Basmati rice. Both dishes were great, but my chops were slightly overcooked. 

I think the food is great, but what does a Chinese guy know about Persian food. So I looked around and saw that half the patrons there were Persian. Very good sign. I'll be back for more!
author: Al L.

description: I'm Persian and I used to think this was the best Kabob in the Bay Area but things have changed :/ Quality of food has gone down and the service is definitely not what it used to be. The prices are ridiculous too. I would go to Alborz instead.
author: Anita H.

description:
A good friend of mine, we'll call her "Lauren Breuning" works for the Ritz Carlton and gets these insane hook-ups within the service industry. It's pretty bitchin'. So, when LaurBreu posits the question, "Wanna get free Persian food?" I'm like, "Did the Iranian Shah get ousted by a military coup in the 1950's? Tchya!" And off to Maykadeh we go.
So, as part of our VIP "This-Broad-Works-at-the-freakin'-Ritz" treatment, we had a prearranged menu that featured, oh, everything. If it baahed, mooed, clucked, or just um, hummused, we ate it. 
Basically, my only critique was that the "rosewater sherbet" meant to cleanse the palate did an all-too-thorough job, cause it tasted exactly like, well, bath.
author: Anna K.

description: Good food, service and atmosphere.  The chicken skewer was delicious.  The lentil soup was hot and tasty.  Would definitely revisit.
author: Elaine F.

description: I have never had Persian cuisine prior to Maykadeh.  I never post on this site, but I wanted to make a point to give this place some love.  Not going to write a paragraph, getting straight to the point.  This place is soooooo damn good.  I love Mexican food, but Persian food is quickly climbing the ladder because of how bomb Maykadeh is.  Absolutely love it.
author: Gino L.

description:
If you have to choose any Middle Eastern or "Mediterranean" food, this would be the best one to choose. Best Persian food you can get in the bay area. I recommend the Tongue and the Barg kabob. You can take a date here to get exotic food while maintaining the ambiance of a nice restaurant and polite waiters. 

If you're sick of Italian restaurants in North Beach, try this out.
author: Daria H.

description:
I thought mixing it up and trying a new restaurant and food would be a really good idea. I was wrong, with a capital W. Maykadeh was pretty busy when I arrived and usually this is a good sign. Since my friend and I were new to Persian food we wanted to try a lot of different plates.

All the dishes we tried were vegetarian (maybe that is where we went wrong).  The waiter also seemed to rush us out of there. Instead of helping us with the menu or suggesting anything, he just rushed around and quickly took our order. I didn't think the food was very fresh. The prices were very cheap however.
author: Natalie N.

description:
Very nice food, but our experience with the staff was terrible.  Our server, who was nice, was confused about a menu item, which resulted in us paying twice what we'd expected.  When we saw the bill and explained what happened to the manager, he proceeded to raise his voice to my wife and then dismissed himself, saying he wasn't there to hear what the server said initially.  They refused to adjust the price or remove the MANDATORY tip added into the bill. 

If you're a first time visitor here, just make sure you and the server are crystal clear on any questions you have, and double check the response.  Don't expect even common courtesy from management.
author: C B.

description:
My husband and I enjoyed an early dinner here on 7/19/09.  We left very happy!

Pita bread, along with a plate of onions, basil leaves, and chunks of the softest, most mild feta cheese I've ever tasted were left on our table top shortly after we sat down. My only complaint for the whole meal would have been that we were not given an explanation as how to eat this wonderful combo of ingredients. Since the bread was still warm, I opened mine up and smeared some feta and a basil leaf inside, pressed it together and enjoyed!

I had the Zereshk Pollo: four or five tender chicken thighs flavored with a saffron sauce. The red barberries sprinkled through the dish added a sweet tanginess to the chicken and the just-right basmati rice.

My husband, being a lamb lover, had the Khoresht Ghaymeh...which I even enjoyed. It was such tender lamb without any gamey flavor to it; it melted in our mouths! 

We'd already nibbled on cookies from an Italian bakery so we skipped dessert.

Definitely a restaurant we'd come back to next time we're in San Francisco.
author: Lisa R.

description:
On a side street, calmer location but still hard to find parking.

The staff is very nice and on top of things.

The food was very good.  We ordered the eggplant appetizer, the beef/lamb/chicken kebabs.

I would go back!
author: Sailing A.

description:
I would have given this place 5 stars if it wasn't for the extremely long wait that we endured.  We arrived at 7:30pm, didn't get our appetizer until about 8:10.  Our entrees FINALLY arrived after almost an hour of waiting.  We ordered:

Kashke Bademjan 
$8.00 
Eggplant, mint garlic sauce

Pickles 
$6.00 
Baby cucumber

Chelo-kebab Koobideh
$13.75
Skewered mixture of ground beef and lamb, onion, Persian spices, 
Basmati rice

Shishlik
$24.00
Rack of lamb chops marinated with basil, garlic, onion, lime juice, vegetables, Basmati rice

The eggplant was very good...the flavors kind of dance around your taste buds, but not overpowering.  The consistency might be a little mushy for some, but compared to other places, it's way better.

The Pickles were fresh and SOUR.  But cleans out your pallet.  

The Koobideh was excellent.  Best I've had so far at any restaurant.  Not too salty, not dried out at all...grilled to perfection.  I highly recommend this dish if this is your first expedition to a Persian restaurant.

The rack of lamb was good as well.  It was, however, a bit overdone.  It would have been perfect if they kept it a little more on the rare side.  Ours came out medium to medium well.  It came in three pieces and all three did not have the same consistency in terms of tenderness because of the different thickness in each piece.  Flavor wise, it's just enough of everything.
author: Selene K.

description: I love you Maykadeh! Your tahdig makes me want to cry! So yum!!!!!!
author: Mrs S.

description:
Kind of expensive. Good environment, OK food.
I ordered chicken kebab and it was awful! I ordered well done and it was every thing but well done!
author: Mojtaba N.

description:
Mmmmmmm...Maykedah makes mouths happy.

This place may be a little random and is often empty, but it is a nice change from the typical Italian fare found in North Beach.  Delicious Persian cuisine including your typical kebabs, dips, etc. and fun cocktails.  The pomegranate martini is quite tasty.
author: Erica G.

description: I'm a snob when it comes to Persian food. I love this place, a little pricey but honestly what good Persian food isn't? All the meat is tender, and the stews and soups are fresh. I think this is the best Persian spot that I've tried in San Francisco. Most of the time when I'm craving Persian, I head out to the East Bay and eat my family's home cooking. But when I'm feeling saucy, I come here. It's great.
author: Natasha S.

description:
Incredibly delicious - absolutely superb!

A friend of mine took me here last night to show me his native cuisine and introduce me to Persian food, and it was so good, I was craving it again today! 

We started off and sampled the mint leaves, wrapped in the naan-like bread (apologies for not knowing the Persian word), with feta. Then we ordered the fabulously delicious Mast-o-Khier (homemade yogurt and cucumber), that went well with most everything. My friend also ordered us another appetizer that he loved - which was essentially "crunchy rice" with stew atop. I wasn't such a fan of the "crunchy rice" part, but he loved it, and I did enjoy the stew. (I think this is a local favourite... not even sure if it's on the menu...) ;)

For our main course, we ordered the Poussin, the Shish Kebab (lamb), and I think the Maykadeh Kebab (filet mignon). We put all this atop the Basmati Rice, along with the roasted tomatoes and green peppers. Everything was delicious!

We were treated to a dessert of Baklava and Bastani (Persian ice cream - rose water and pistachio, maybe? very yummy!), as well as some tea. Even though I thought we had no room for dessert, I was royally impressed with this heavenly dessert! And today I'm craving for more...

I'm so looking forward to our next visit to Maykadeh, as I now adore Persian food!
author: Sally M.

description: Great lamb beef skewers - the bread was delicious as well - waitress was super helpful and friendly - only thing I didn't like was the parking around the area
author: Herman L.

description:
Succulent is the best way for me to describe this place. The ground lamb/beef kabob cannot be missed and if you're into lamb the lamb shank dish was tender and flavorful. 

Maykadeh looks like a nice date place, but when we walked in, we were pleasantly surprised how many middle eastern families were eating there - a good sign that the food is top notch.
author: A B.

description: The lamb brain, the juicy barg kebab, they were all prepared carefully and cooked just the right amount.
author: Mohsen R.

description:
Maykadeh is one of the few Persian places in the city. It is a fantastic date place. The service is good, the selection of food is limited, but that makes it real easy to choose. I love Persian food - its so very simple. Rice, meat, mint leaves, onions, that's it really. Love it.

I've had the lamb chops here both times (I'm just obsessed with lamb chops). The hummus doesn't quite taste authentic. The meat was cooked to (my) perfection and was extremely tender. 

Good stuff, yo.
author: Anand I.

description:
Maykadeh was recommended to me by a Persian.  They said it was the best Persian restaurant in the area.  So on a cold rainy February night I made my way out to San Fran to try it for myself.  The restaurant is very comfortable.  They have cozy booth seating next to the windows, as well as tables throughout the rest of the restaurant for groups.  A platter full of herbs, and cheese is served to you along with flat bread before your meal.  The tea that they serve is black and delicious.  It is a must if you go.  The food is amazing.  My boyfriend had the Khorest Fesenjoon, which is chicken in a pomegranate nut sauce, and I had the Sunday special, Bagalhi Polo, which is lamb shank with dill and Lima bean rice.  

If you are looking to try something new, or if you are just want something savory, this place is for you.  It would be perfect for a date, or an adventurous family outing.
author: Michele F.

description: The cholokabab koobideh does not taste like a real one, the Barg which is pricy among the rest of the menu also tasteless which means you should not trust your waiter's recommendation however the polo(rice) is really good and tasty, dough ( yogurt drink) is good so at the end forget about ordering main course of meat just go ahead with plain rice and drink lol
author: Az A.

description: This persian princess says it's one of the best, I've had in Cali. It doesn't compare to my dad's cooking but it's close.  The parking is horrendous, the waitstaff is somewhat nonchalant and eager to turn over tables, and prepare to wait an hour to get your car back from the valet on a weekend night, but once you have some of that  rice and fesenjoon, it's all good.  The Kashke Bademjan is the best appetizer there. Not a big fan of the fact they use dark meat chicken for all their chicken recipes though.
author: Sahar R.

description: Always a place we go to in San Francisco. They have friendly waiters, who are persian, like us. Whenever we get take out the nice waiter brings us tea (which tastes just like it is back home)- for free. The food is delicious, and at a reasonable price for persian cuisine. The iced tea is amazing also. At a good location also. My dad can never seem to find parking though haha. And it tastes just like the real stuff back home guys, it's not just another chain restarunt. Highly recommend!!
author: Nafeseh R.

description:
This is my  Dad's favorite restaurant, We come here quite often with him and my stepmom (who is persian)
I always get the Soltani which is marinated filet pounded out really thin, and a koobideh kebab. Both of the meats are like butter. 
I order mine with the zeresk polow because I love the tartness of the barberries.
I also love the feta, basil and onion appetizer they give you, good combination of flavors.
The portions are huge, so if you come for lunch, you will definately have enough for dinner later.
author: Karlee D.

description:
If I had to pick a word to describe Maykadeh, it'd pick "reliable."  I've been several times and everytime it's right on.  There's nothing outstandingly special about it, it's just a very good Persian restaurant.  Anyone who enjoys Mediterreanean cuise will enjoy Persian food as well.  I had the shish kabob, which was juicy and tender.  The rice was good too (even I ate it and I view rice as a waste of space usually).  I especially appreciate the herbs, pita, and feta they serve at the beginning, much more interesting than bread and butter.  I promise to take a bite of the onion next time too! :)

The decor is simple and conservative enough to bring the fam, but no one who will be disappointed.  

Also, don't even bother looking for parking in NB, the valet is very worth it in this neighborhood.
author: Aristocles P.

description:
Yes, yes, yes...this is THE place to go.

I have nothing bad to say about the +5 times that I've come here for great food. EVERY time has been great.
author: Me Y.

description:
Very bad service. Over priced and the food isn't that good. Rude owner & waitresses. I made a comment about the food to the waitress, she didn't even care and didn't come back to our table and told the boss lady to finish our table. 
I complained to the manager when we were walking out and as I was talking to him, the owner charged us, swearing and screaming violently and told us not to go back to his restaurant. It's a shame to see that in the persian community. Iranians don't take criticisms very well that's why so many persians don't say anything but tell everyone they know not to go back to a place and that will be the end of that business. Avoid this place. It's gone downhill over the years and the price has gone uphill. Alborz restaurant has better food and better prices.
author: Foroozan H.

description:
The service is pretty good, the food is tasty but a tad pricey for some meat and rice.  I have only had the kabob, it was lovely.  

The decor is nice, very Persian restaurant-y...they all seem to be similar, but the restaurant is laid out a bit weird...the tables are at these odd angles that I find uncomfortable for some reason, but its no big deal, once you sit, it is pleasant. They play melodic Persian music which made me all nostalgic. I only come here with family or out of town Persian tourists and everyone seems to like this place.  I guess if you are hankering for some Iranian food, this is the place for it in San Francisco. Parking is a bitch in north beach, beware.
author: Nilu r.

description:
When R suggested taking us to the best Persian restaurant in the Bay Area, we jumped at the invitation.  It took us a while to find where Maykadeh was tucked away in the North Beach area -- luckily we were saved from another 30 minutes of wandering about by a very handsome French-speaking gentleman... ^_^

Maykadeh is well appointed and its clientele were hip (the young man at the next table had the new iPhone) and well dressed.  The wait staff was attentive -- our water glasses were kept filled -- and our silverware and plates replaced after each course.  Our waiter caught our eye on the first attempt, so every need was met promptly and efficiently.

We started with pita bread onto which we spread feta cheese and butter, and inserted basil leaves and sweet onion.  Now, if you told K, here, eat this basil leaf and a slice of raw onion, she would have slugged you.  But the atmosphere must have tamed her because she ate the pita wraps, and she liked it enough to go for thirds.  We sampled Kashke Bademjan, a warm spread made out of eggplant, and Ghorme sabzee, lamb cooked in onions, chives and lentils, over crispy rice.

We were so full after our Breast Kebab, Sirloin Kebabs and Ground meat Kebabs -- which were well seasoned with a hint of citrus -- that we didn't have room for dessert.  Ah well.  R. showed us how to rock to Iranian music.

Four stars because parking in the area sucks.
author: Yoshiko M.

description:
I'm a fan of Persian food, and this is one of the best places I have ever been to. They are located in North Beach, provide valet parking (yet, I always opt to look for my own!). 

I have only been here twice, and both times, have ordered the braised lamb shank, which is slow-cooked with beans and spices. Unfortunately, I can't remember the name of it, and I think is slightly different than the one posted on the online menu. It's really good, and the meat falls off the bone, which of course is the best part, and where all the flavor is. It goes well with the rice that is so infused with flavor that you know it's been cooked well, and cooked slow!

I also tried the baby chicken (poissin) which my mother ordered, and was really tender and moist. Even better and more moist was the Joojeh Kebab (boneless chicken thighs marinated in saffron, onion and lime juice). Both the chicken entrees came with vegetables - in addition to the basmati rice.

The ambience is typical San Franciscan - intimate, and with candles. You can't beat that!

The service was just OK - with the generic yet obligatory and emotionless, "How is everything?" ten minutes into the meal.
 
The complimentary flat bread leaves something to be desired and I could do without it. It's kind of like lke-warm cardboard.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
I had my first Persian Food at Maykadeh on Tuesday and just can't stop thinking about it!  The eggplant is the best eggplant ever!  It's soft, tender, flavorful and simply addictive.  I also finished my meal with a cup of Persian coffee that has a strong aroma with herbal and floral hints.

I've already made plan to go back on this Sunday bringing another eggplant maniac like me.  Almost forget to mention the atmosphere and crowds, they were classy.  Well, at least it was like that on a Tuesday night.
author: Vivian H.

description: Wonderful atmosphere, great service and good food. I will be back. Parking is tricky !
author: S M.

description: Flavor was excellent... from the Aash to the joojeh kabob. Staff was attentive and kind! When I return to SF I will be back!
author: M R.

description: I my view this is the best persian restaurant in bay area! For last 10 years that I have been going to Maykadeh, the food and service quality has not change a bit... I love their food! everything is great... my favorates are soltani and lamb tongue.
author: Arash H.

description: This place is honestly a 3.5, but considering its my favorite food I gave it a 4. I mean, the food is delicious, I have no doubt. But you can get the exact same dishes for a MUCH cheaper price if you know where to go. Yes, you wont be in north beach. But you'll save money. But if you want to spend a little then its a good place. We got some appetizers that were good. And I got the big filet mignon and beef kebab, I can't complain it tasted great. ll bad I didn't try the dessert.
author: Nikita K.

description:
halal pretty restaurant - bonus
halal food and super clean - double bonus
yummy goodness - triple bonus

parking - awful

Omg but the food is spiced perfectly, not over done and definitely yummy enough to go back. The salads are fresh, chicken kabob and beef koobideh, to die for.
author: Muneera M.

description: Had an amazing meal there Saturday night.  The place was packed as you would expect on a Saturday at 9pm - the M'aitre d' was very accommodating and even moved our party to another table due to the cold blast of air from the front door.  Very good wine list, and the wine was well presented.  The food was absolutely top notch!  I'm so happy I found this place, as I was just lamenting about the lack of good Persian food options in SF.
author: J D.

description: First time eating this type of food, but very quite and Romantic setting.  candle light dinner.  We had Lamb and more lamb.  I forgot the name but both types was awesome!!!
author: Mark U.

description:
Maykadeh is a great persian restaurant. All of the food is fresh and always tastes good. I was there last Saturday for the first time in a while, and I was surprised it wasnt packed.
