I like going to persian restaurants to order food in farsi as I don't have many friends who speak farsi. I was a bit dissapointed that the severs where not Iranian, but no big deal. I guess they could have been better in serving us too, but again, no big deal. The food was good. Ordered joojeh kabob, most moosir, kashke bodemjoon, and salad shirazi. All was very tasty and not overly pricy... will try to make it back here soon. 

hopefully I can speak farsi to my server next time. =)
author: Bahram M.

description:
Persian eats in North Beach?

I was pleasantly surprised by this place.  Truthfully, I tend to associate North Beach with Italian restaurants, strip clubs, and pubs - and not much else (except maybe Citizen Thai and the Monkey).  However, now, much to my surprise, I've learned there is an excellent Persian restaurant in the hood too. 

So here is all you really need to know about the place: 

The interior is posh looking.  You'll look around and start to worry that maybe entrees will run you $30+ a pop - but you'd be wrong.  From my memory all the entrees here ranged between $13 for a delicious meat/lamb combo to $27 for an excellent steak.  From my perspective, these are reasonable prices for a "nice" meal out.  

Speaking of the food - it is excellent.  I tried the lamb/combo dish that I previously mentioned, and it was delicious.  I also had a little of the chicken skewers, and can tell you that they were also great.  Additionally, though I can't say I've tried it myself, I've been told that the baby chicken receives the highest recommendations.  

Another reason to check this place out for dinner is because they serve you a basket full of delicious pita bread with onion, feta, and basil with your dinner.  

Finally, the staff here was super friendly.  Not only was the wait staff attentive, but the host (who may have been a manager or owner actually - and I believe his name was John) was very, very friendly and checked with us from time to tim to see how we were doing.  

Summary: high end (but casual) ambiance, moderate prices, excellent staff together makes this a great place to bring your family when they visit or a nice place to impress a date.
author: Matthew H.

description:
Good kebabs, but not a great overall experience for the price. Don't get a salad. We also had the chicken breast and lamb/beef kebabs, both very flavorful. Would reccomend both. Also, better basmati rice than we've ever had, sort of nutty and buttery, mmm. Serving sizes were large -- I'm a girl, but I was stuffed after eating less than half of my lamb/beef kabob. Too bad we were just visiting, or it would've made good leftovers.   

We went here for lunch. Service was somewhat slow, considering there were only three other parties dining at the time. Ambience was decent -- cozy benches!
author: Theresa Z.

description: Overall 3.5 stars. Maykadeh is nice and clean. I liked the Joojeh Kabob, which was the boneless chicken thighs with Basmati rice, and we got to add the beef kabob for a few dollars more. I was also excited about trying the Khoresht Fesenjoon, which is the pomegranate chicken, but the waitress thought that we ordered the Khoresht Bademjan, which is the lamb shank with eggplant and tomato. The sauce was tasty except I don't like the gamey taste of lamb; luckily the waitress was nice enough to change our order. However, the thick pomegranate sauce for the chicken ended up tasting like sweet jam which was a bit overpoweringly sweet but palatable with complimentary basil, feta and pita bread.
author: Diana B.

description:
UPDATE:  This place really knows how to serve their clientele.  After numerous reservations mistakes on our part, our party trickling in and out and in and out, and changing numbers by the minute, they GRACIOUSLY handled our needs and changing numbers!  The food is excellent, the service unrushed and pleasant.  I highly recommend the trad'l food and gracious service for any number party.

DO call ahead for a table as the place is busy all night long!  

The ONLY place for Persian food in the entire Bay Area.  Again, have to compare it to LaLa Land where Persian food is as plentiful on the Westside as Micky-Dees.  I love the open, casual feel to Maykadeh, located in North Beach.  You can park there which is a plus and the food is good.  I would definitely go back.
author: A W.

description:
Outstanding meat. Had delicious lamb tongue, koobideh, and filet mignon. Sabzi served complimentary. Cucum/Tomato salad was great.

I like the sabzi at Shalizaar better but the Filet Mignon is better at Maykadeh. Koobideh are comparable at the two; they use different spices but I think Shalizaar's flavor is a little better. My favorite at Shalizaar is the lamb so I will try that next time at Maykadeh. The pita was better at Maykadeh.

Valet parking available for $10, which is awesome because it's impossible to park there. Service was very friendly.

Update: Went again and again, the waiter was very nice. The lamb was very good but I think it's better at Shalizaar. I will definitely return here whenever I'm in the mood for meat!! (Drooling already...)
author: Marina N.

description: I have to admit.... this is my one and only point of reference for Persian food, but damn is it a good reference! I've ordered delivery from them three times, and the quality has been consistent and the quantity is ample- borderline excessive! You defintely get your money's worth with this place. I had a coupon for a free appetizer and ordered hummus. We got a huge tub of freshly made garlic hummus with a whole box full of pita bread. I really like the lamb pieces with split peas and saffron, the lamb shank in leeks/chives/herbs, and the ground beef/lamb chelo-kebab koobideh. The chicken kebab koobideh is only okay. They give you a huge box of rice to go with each one of the dishes. My one real complaint is that they always say it will take 45 minutes to deliver when it really takes an hour or so. It's worth the wait, so I will just have to adjust my expectations!
author: Tina S.

description:
While i would not call it a gem in any sense, the food was quite delicious, the service more than adequate.  I wanted to sit next to window, but found the people next to us to be too noisy. The host was gracious to allow us to move (as I would expect) and pick our own seating (as I did not expect).  Everything worked out wonderfully.  In fact, I just finished the left overs today.
We enjoyed the lamb and eggplant dished.  Seasoned wonderfully, quite tasty.  Give it a try.
Thanks for dinner.
author: Bill W.

description: Went to Maykadeh this weekend for my brother's birthday... We had brought a cake with us, the host quickly took the cake w/o me asking, explaining, nada... he knew exactly what I wanted.  Despite not having reservations, we were immediately seated.  We received quick, friendly service and great food.  At the end, our cake came with the candles I had put on it and the decoration I had on top of the cake box.  I was very happy with the dinner itself and the experience.  I also appreciated how they have valet parking b/c it's hard to find parking there.  Thanks Maykadeh! :)
author: nasim n.

description:
I love trying new cuisine, but only when I have an idea of what is good to order. Sure, I could order a kabob somewhere else, but I recruited Cyrus to this place because he eats it on the daily. I think he was impressed and it sparked conversation about the culture, which made the meal even better (He's half persian and thought he should tell me every phrase he knows in farsi, which used to be called parsi but someone took the 'p' sound out of the language and replaced it with 'f'. FYI now parsi just means persian) 

Beautiful photographs on the walls of Iran and its people. Nice staff, seems like families and older couples enjoy eating here.

I had the lamb casserole with beans and potato sticks accompanied with rice. I really couldn't tell what was going on with the flavors inside my mouth; they went through at least three different phases until it was decided which one was most pleasurable to the buds. He mentioned the dish could take hours and was astonished at how fast it came out. I loved the cucumber and tomato salad, with the minty yogurt to dip your bread or mix in rice.  The Persian Delight cocktail was much like a vodka cranberry, except with pomegranate juice and I wouldn't recommend it. Water refills were a bit sluggish. Overall, my experience here was satisfying and I might return to try the pistachio persian ice cream. Beware, this food is bound to fill you up and possibly make you drowsy for a couple of hours if eaten in a hurried fashion.
author: Kim G.

description:
Down home cooking that I love, drool over, and incessantly crave.  Everything on the menu is delightful, authentic, and sure to please. 

Extra Bonus: one of the best looking waiters in town.
author: Alicia J.

description:
K...another Persian throwing their two cents in.
I brought a group of post law-school friends here and my significant other (Irish and Italian) so I was the virtual "tour guide." 
The Persian Martini was very un-Persian (yes except I suppose for the Pomegranate juice), but it was very tasty!
The Kashk-e-Bademjan was nice and smoky and the Salad Shirazi was decent.  
We mostly all ordered the Sultani except for a splattering of Chicken Kabob and a Vegetarian Khoresht.  It all looked great, but I can only speak for the Barg and Koobideh.  Barg was juicy and tender and the Koobideh was decent, but a leeetle overdone.  Otherwise good.  
I still can't give it a five star given the LA and Vancouver Persian bar has been set much higher.  But great given the "Persian" food I have eaten at other establishments in the Bay Area.
author: Sheila Y.

description:
What's good:
1. location/valet parking
2. chicken with pomegranet sauce, eggplant appetizer
3. atmosphere
4. cocktails

What's not so good:
1. sketchy service: one minute super attentive, next minute no where to be found. The waiter was a bit stand-off-ish and not so helpful for vegetarians. BTW, NOT a place for vegetarians
2. Club music
3. Wine list
author: Michelle S.

description:
Food good.. 

waiter sucked... 

I would recommend the place for the food without a doubt, but you are taking your chances with the wait staff... best of luck to you.
author: Tom C.

description:
I can't really comment on the food, because I'm on a stupid wedding diet - may as well be called hell.  I ended up having a greek salad, lentil soup (yum) and the yogurt dip with the elephant garlic (don't get this). 

But what I can comment on is the service.  The host was so nice and placed my friend's stroller in the back and provided a corner seat so the baby can sleep properly.  Our server was totally unassuming too.  When we asked what the "dough" drink was, she came back and brought us a sample, provided recommendations and was just so pleasant. 

4 stars for now, probably 5 stars when I go back here post wedding starvation.
author: Bhumika K.

description:
Pretty much, hands down, the best Persian food in the city...Alborz isn't bad but portions are smaller and service is inconsistent, IMHO.

Maykadeh suffers from the poorly conceived parking blackhole aka North Beach location but valet service is a big plus.

If you've never had Persian cuisine before, realize from the getgo that food comes in large portions-Cheesecake Factory style...Also, if you are not a vegetarian, you MUST try Barg once in your lifetime...Best kabob going...If you are a vegetarian, realize that Persian food has a lot of great veggie dishes too...Eggplant dishes are a signature of Persian food.

I still can't figure out why the Ruby Skye music is pumping through the speakers but the atmosphere is pretty tolerable if not oddly paired.

For the true Persian enthusiasts, this is as good as it gets in the city...Not quite LA-Raffi's standard or some down in the peninsula, but quite good...A bit overpriced, IMHO, as well.

Dishes to try:  Zeresht pollo, Geymeh, Barg, Fesenjoon, Mosto Khiar and any of the other kabobs.
author: Barca F.

description:
Once again fellow Yelpers...you always come through. 

So it was my turn to pick a place to eat so I refer to my trusty Yelp. 

I wanted something good but different. So I decided to go to Maykadeh. I had never been to a Persian restaurant before so I had no clue what I was getting into. 

I don't even know the name of what I ordered, it was the special and some kind of ground chicken. It had to be the best ground chicken whatchamacallit I have ever had. It was moist and tasty. If all Persian food is this good I need to take a trip cause they are doing it right.
author: Nikki L.

description:
I had the lamb shank here too; very very flavorful and fell right off the bone. YUMMY!
Huge portions (i think it's family style) an if you can't finish it, pack up the leftovers; they're as good as they were when you first ate them!
author: Jocelyn L.

description: I'm persian and I can definitely distinguish between a good persian food and just OK. Food here is just normal. Nothing special about it! And I can't say anything good about their service. Sucks! The waiter couldn't wait to get rid of us. Won't waste my time and my money here again!!
author: parviz d.

description: Very slow service that wasn't so great even when it was there. Food was ok but overpriced when we finally got the bill.  It's a mystery why anyone would decide to dine here.
author: Toben G.

description: This restaurant is nice, the staff is friendly and well knowledge of the cuisine they serve. However I feel the place is way over priced, the Sulatani which is the most expensive kebab and also the best on the menu. Go there for the ambiance shared glass of wine because you can get the same quality of food at a different place for  alot less.
author: Bebe D'hala D.

description:
If you want delicious, mouthwatering, authentic Persian cuisine, check out Maykadeh! I've been there more than 4 times now and keep going back cuz I LOVE IT!!!!!!!!!!!!! 
inexpensive vallet, great Persian martinis....maybe I'm a little biased since I'm Persian...but I would recommend this place to all my friends..Go there tonight!
author: Azine D.

description:
Ok, so I have to admit that we heard about this place on one of those cheesy in-hotel info videos*.  The owner said on the video that if you couldn't cut the filet with a fork, you shouldn't pay for it...and for the carnivore that is my boyfriend, that was good enough for us.  He had the kabob barg and I had the chicken breast kabob and mine was totally better than his (upon tasting he said it was exploding with flavor, which I'd have to agree with.)  Everything about my dish was great and he liked his beef too, although he couldn't cut it with a fork (and he tried) hence the minus 1 star.

*disclosure: we did go to the apple store to use the internet to yelp Maykadeh before blindly trusting the video.  Don't hate.
author: Jenna D.

description: Dining at Maykadeh was my first time at a nice Persian restaurant and I was not disappointed. Service was stellar, ambiance was perfect! We had a late dinner here on a Tuesday night and nothing was lacking. Our food came out promptly and the taste/quality was amazing! Portions were huge too. I had the joojeh kabob and the mast o khiar (my favorite) and it was delicious. Maykadeh has an excellent wine selection as well! Yummy all around!
author: Katie D.

description: I went into San Francisco looking for something different to eat and found this gem. I tried the lambs head which was flavored with cinnamon and turmeric. The meat was soft and flavorful, it reminded me a bit of ox tail soup falling off the bone. I also had the eggplant, Baba Ghanoush, and a Shirazi Salad, which was like a greek salad without the lettuce. The bread was similar to an indian nan bread served piping hot. Quite delicious. Overall, I am looking forward to returning to try some of the other items on the menu.
author: Ron C.

description:
I had never had Persian food before and I absolutely love it. The mix of both Mediterranean and Asian influences was delicious.  I enjoyed that  for dinner they brought out complimentary feta cheese, basil, & onion paired with Pita bread. 
For dinner I got the lamb shank with basil, onion, and vegetables. It was served like a curry/stew (with rice) which I was  pleasantly surprised by. The lamb was incredibly tender (falling off the bone). My boyfriend got lamb and beef  sausage esque thing which was very good and reminded me of Tunisian merguez. The friend we were also had a lamb dish that was delicious.

all the food they served to tables around us smelled great. 

Though service was not perfect the food was great and the room was inviting. (Though not the hippest decor). I would definitely recommend this place especially for the cold summer days.
author: Courtney R.

description:
Hands down my favorite Persian restaurant in SF (and really the only one). The food here is excellent and hits the spot every single time I step foot in the place.

If you're in San Mateo, you can head over to Shalizaar.... excellent as well.
author: melissa g.

description:
I'm going to start off with the cliche "I am Persian and know good Persian food when I taste it." This place is expensive, butttttt you do get what you pay for. This is the best Persian food in all the bay area with Shalizaar in Belmont coming in second. Actually in all of California, this place may be the best Persian restaurant. The only competition I see is Darya down south in Orange County.

Anyway, onto the food. Both the kubide(ground beef kabab) and barg(filet) are amazing, juicy and perfect. I always get the soltani combo and have never gone wrong doing so. Portions are huge, so you can easily share a combo with a friend. Service can be slow at times, since they usually only have one server, but it's worth it for the food.

Only other downside besides the price is the valet parking charge(since parking in the area sucks).
author: Cameron S.

description: The quality of the food at Maykadeh is as good as it gets....I've eaten there for the past 20 years....both delivered and in the restaurant.... I will say that you will enjoy the food much better if eaten with somebody who knows how to order and combined the dishes correctly....(A Persian friend)
author: chris c.

description:
there's not many persian restaurants in the city. this persian restaurant has some damn good bread.

their dishes were served quite beautifully. and the food had good flavors. 

the ambiance is a bit stale, as is most persian places. table cloths and mirrors.
author: Ameer N.

description: Always tasty with great service. Thank you for awesome persian food in the city,,
author: Brian b.

description:
Went here on a Saturday night and parking was horrendeous.  We paid $10 for valet.  Walked in the restaurant and I saw the waiter taking sips of wine behind the counter.  We were seated to our table and when I looked back I saw another waiter sipping wine behind the counter.  They looked like lushes, that was a turn off.  This is the first time I have encountered that  at a restaurant and I must say that it is very unprofessional.  

We ordered the chicken breast and lamb and both dishes were okay, I've had better persian food.  I would probably not come back to this restaurant again because of the difficult parking and the lush waiters.
author: Amanda N.

description: This place is considered the best Persian Restaurant in SF, so we gave it a try.  Valet service is available and you should take the offer as North Beach Parking can be a nightmare.  I was a rookie to Persian cuisine at the time and knew nothing about it.  I would have gave it 3 stars but the table didn't think it was that great compared to the normal restaurants in  Tehrangeles or Orange County.  If this was the best SF had to offer than it was mediocre at best because it didn't live up to the hype.   We ordered shish Kebab, Joojeh Kebab, Khoresht Fesenjoon, and dough.  I'll take her word into consideration, so 2 stars it is.
author: S F.

description: Great Persian food, a bit hard to find at night in the dark. Had the ribeye steak (massive amount) medium rare done, very juicy and flavourful. Will come again.
author: Dee D.

description: This is easily one of my ten most favorite restaurants of all time.  Everything, from service to ambiance to the food is a ten.  I have dined at many Persian restaurants and this is the absolute best and most authentic.  My mouth is watering now, just thinking about their food.  It is a great date venue.  You would not be out of place dining in black tie or in processional casual attire.  It is one of the few restaurants I frequent that is just as good a place for lunch as it is for dinner.  It is a real destination place, not just a place to grab a meal before doing something else.  Years ago, I used to have the food picked up by taxi and brought home, if I wanted a great meal in.  There is no better food available on the planet.
author: Storm J.

description: Good service and food came out quick.  I don't eat this type of food often, but thought it was good.  We got the baby chicken and rack of lamb.  Both were good but a little salty.  The lamb tongue app was alright, but rich and heavy.  Overall decent food and good service.
author: Jeff T.

description:
Excellent food and nice decor

Portions are generous,  so go there w/ an appetite

Order Zereshk Polo and the eggplant appetizer

mmmm...........
author: M M.

description: I am persian and I LOVE good persian food, and I love this place! they have great authentic persian food, their food tastes like my mothers cooking which is amazing! The people who work there are great, very friendly  and accommodating.  This place is my favorite persian restaurant in bay area, if you like persian food you should definately try this place!
author: Sayeh I.

description:
Great kabobs.....delicious stews.....amazing zaboon......great service....
expensive like 40 pp
author: Kasra V.

description:
One of the greatest persian food Ive ever taken and I am saying this in comparison to REAL persian restaurants in Iran not one of these mom-cooking kebabs which even my grandma in iran could cook better than them and of course with minimum wage hired waiters who can not speak english !
Great food , great appetizers , great service (with one waiter) , great enviroment , great wine .
I really enjoyed my time there so I think its fantastic. try it at least once!
author: Sahba A.

description:
Living in SF where there are always new restaurants to discover, there are not many places I want to go to on a regular basis. Maykadeh is an exception, I could go there every week. 
I strongly recommend the Koobideh and the Kashke Bademjan; very unique.
author: Rose K.

description:
this was my first experience with persian food ever, and it was a very pleasant experience.

Saturday night, no reservations, party of 2, we walked right in to an incredibly busy restaurant, and were seated immediately.  

not knowing what to order, we had the Kashke Bademjan (eggplant + mint garlic sauce), Chelo-kebab Koobideh (beef/lamb skewer over basmati rice) and the Poussin (baby chicken over basmati rice).  both meats were very tender, moist, and flavorful.  the pita's were very good (i'm sure there's a healthy dosage of butter in there, but nonetheless very good)

needless to say, i would definitely come back, if i'm having the craving for persian food.  i haven't had the wait-experiences as other reviewers had (like i said, saturday night 8pm no wait).  plus it's just up the street from where i live.
author: Jason J.

description: The kabob is delicious. Food is excellent. Highly recommend.
author: asdf d.

description: I've heard great things about this restaurant and it is the best Persian food in the city. They have valet right out front, so you don't have to worry about the impossible parking situation in North Beach.  The prices are around $20 - $25 for their dishes and the sizes are HUGE! My friend and I shared a dish the phesanjoon (pomegranate sauce with tender chicken) and it was plenty for us both. The eggplant appetizer and the feta with tomatoes appetizers were yummy. Service is good as well.
author: Natalie S.

description:
If you're a lamb fanatic like I am, this is THE place for you. I ordered "Khoresht Bademjan" (Lamb shank, baby eggplant braised with tomato, saffron, sun dried lime, Basmati rice) for lunch and it was absolutely fabulous! After having tried it out, I would rate it as one of the 2 best places in the Bay Area for braised lamb shank (the other being Silk Road @ Walnut Creek). $16 is a fairly reasonable price to pay for a good lamb shank, but what made it really worth it is the quality of the dish and the complimentary plate of basil leaves with some very good goat cheese. It really made my day! My girlfriend ordered some vegetarian dish - probably "Kashke Bademjan" - and that was pretty delicious too.

I see there're a lot of other lamb dishes on the menu, so my first visit to this restaurant was certainly not the last :)
author: Dan C.

description: The hubby and I went to Maykadeh for our anniversary dinner.  It was simply fantastic!  Probably one of the best kabobs/meats I've had in a long time.  We started with the yogurt cucumber dip and the hummus, along with the feta cheese/basil/onion plate they give each table.  All were tasty.  I had the lamb chops which were cooked perfectly while my husband had a chicken kabob and ground meat kabob.  The spices are excellent and the rice was tasty too.  Great service and an all around wonderful meal.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Julie P.

description: Total satisfaction here. Food was great and so was the  service. The lamb's tongue was like butter. Say hello to Maykadeh's newest fan.
author: Chris M.

description:
Located in North Beach on Green Street, I was reluctant to go, because of the insane parking around that area. However, this place offers Valet Parking for $8, which is worth every penny to me, especially when the car was out front when we were done!

We arrived with no reservation around 8:30-9:00 and were immediately seated at a table that featured a corner booth covered in Persian pillows. We were then brought some pita bread with Feta Cheese, a Half Onion and Basil. Now this may seem strange, but trust me, making little sandwiches with these ingredients was fantastic, and really could be considered an appetizer!

We started out with a bottle of wine that was brought promptly and my glass never got empty. In fact, the waiter paced the meal perfectly so the wine ended when the meal ended, a feat not so easily done, and usually never even attempted at most places. We only noticed because larger parties were coming in after us and getting their food before us, so the waiter came over and told us that he was pacing us. Very Cool.

We started out with the Kashke Bademjan - Eggplant with mint garlic sauce - $6.50. It was an average appetizer that I would not get again. We wish we had gotten then Mat-o-Khiar - Homemade Yogurt and Cucumber.

For dinner I got the Shish - Kebab - Fillet of Lamb marinated in lime juice, saffron, onion, olive oil, vegetables and Basmati rice. - $21.00. While it was good, it was not spectacular.

I liked the restaurant, I like the service, and the food was good. I would recommended it, but I am in no rush to return anytime soon.
author: Pele N.

description:
Decent Persian. Not great Persian. Try Shalizar in San Mateo on 25th for better. If you are really into Persian, nothing beats the place in the Gas Lamp in San Diego...the name escapes me tonight. Look it up...Gas :Lamp Dist in downtown. 

The service at Maykadeh is pretentious, food is 6/10.
author: Gomerio G.

description: really good food, nice clean place with white table cloths, waitress was nice, little bit reserved, still polite. the eggplant stew (vegetarian style) is amazing.  the koobideh (if you like meat) is the best koobideh that i've had. will go back.
author: Mark S.

description:
Sorry to buck the trend, but we came here recently and found the experience a little less than ordinary. While we waited for our friends to arrive they seated us at bar - I ordered pomegranate martini and hubby ordered a regular martini. Both were very dissapointing - weak. 

When we found out when our friends were arriving, we wanted to be moved to our table. It took me asking the main guy number of times before this happened. Infact I had to get the attention of someone in the kitchen to help us. 

The appetisers were good. The main food was O-k, I had lamb cutlets, it was a bit dry and the rice was fairly oily. My hubby had lamb fillets and he said he enjoyed that. 

The service at the table was generally good, they came around and topped up our water etc. 

I would probably not bother with the dessert, baklava was sickly sweeter than any baklava I've had and this is coming from having eaten it in many countries including Australia and countries in the middle eat itself. The persian icecream was quite interesting, I personally liked it. 

Overall, I'll try the many other restaurants in the neighbourhood before going back to this one.
author: isis n.

description: Restaurant is nice. Service is very good.  My chicken was cooked really badly and the rice was underdone.  We couldn't finish our meals which cost $60 for two.  I was excited by the menu but disappointed with the food.
author: L. W.

description: Had a delicious lunch/dinner with my family (persian, visiting california from the UK)...it was in the middle of a street festival, which was loud and made me wonder if we had picked the right day to try Maykadeh, yet it turned out to be perfectly quiet and peaceful once we got inside the restaurant.  I believe I had chicken kabob and ghormeh sabzi...will definitely return :D
author: Dreamer K.

description: Our entrees were very good. Filet & Chicken. The appetizers were just okay. Still good, but nothing special. I would still come back here if I am craving Persian, yet I will probably try a couple of other Persian restaurants first.
author: Tiffany B.

description: My persian boyfriend and I love this place. The food is always fresh and on point. Thank you for the great meals!
author: Sara S.

description: I had never had persian food but loved it as I went with my co-workers for a drug rep dinner and then we went back about 1-2 months later. One of the waiters was hitting on my friend and it was so funny as they were both Persian.
author: Laura K.

description:
just coming back from dinner there.

its a nice place, the crowd was good.
good music,
in short good ambience.
they also have a small bar, but not such a huge variety.


when you go there, you would want to order persian wine and drinks and not the regular wines. its a bit pricey , but you can definitely experiment and that is my main aim.

I tried the persian delight which the server recommended. it was ok.

joojah kebab had rice but it was dry, I do not know how can someone eat rice with dry kebab, I was expecting the dish to have some sauce.

in the end a good evening. but it could definitely have been better,
author: Utsav M.

description: Tasty food, I would recommend Kabobs in this place. They are fresh and been one of the top ones I have had in US so far, comparable with good ones in Iran. Parking is a hassle.
author: Ehsan N.

description:
Truly delicious!  Get the soltani, its filet mignon and some kind of grilled lamb and beef kebab....juicy tender delicious...garli cyogurt is good with the pita, raw onion, and feta they bring to your table to start....oh and the eggplant appetizer, its blended into a past dand truly delicious.  

salads were unimpressive, everything else  great!
author: cab k.

description:
is just great! Sasha is very gentleman and the food i had there.............one of the most fullfilling food ever in the city!
I will never forget all those courses....still in the back of my mind.
thank you for that experience. was great food ever!
author: Lydia S.

description: Maykadeh has the best Persian food I have ever had.  Whenever I visit San Francisco, I cannot fail to have dinner there at least once.  I was there three or four times last year, and each time was absolutely amazing.  I just love the flavors and the way the meats are cooked.  I've taken my family and friends, and they love it too.  Don't ask me to name the dishes I ordered, because I can't remember the Persian names.  All I know is that everything I've ever tried there rocked!  The wine list is pretty thoughtful as well -- a nice added surprise.
author: Canon B.

description: Food is good but service is awful.   They screwed up my order and then tried to blame me for it when I brought it to their attention.  I would never dine there again.
author: Ramin B.

description: Truly enjoyed the food and it was served very very quickly.  Portions seemed a bit small for the price you pay.  At my table we got the lamb shank and another lamb dish, both had amazing flavors, so I would certainly go again, but with the idea to get an app or something beforehand.  Wait staff was incredibly attentive and the maître d' was very nice!
author: Adrienne B.

description: The BEST!  We drive in from Alameda and take our kids!  The food is delicious and the staff is very friendly.  We always order the Koobideh (AMAZING) and the Poussin (baby chicken).  The flavors of the food are out of this world!  When ordering dessert, my son (8 years old) asked for another order of the Poussin!  He brought it to school for lunch!  This is a great place to eat!
author: Karin F.

description:
4 of us had been there for dinner. The restaurant was comfortable and there were several large groups of people enjoying themselves. The waiter was very enthusiastic in suggesting recommendations. The eggplant appetizer was excellent and thats something that I would definitely recommend that you try. We tried out a pomegranate based dish for the main course which was too sweet and were a bit disappointed with it.
     Overall, a wonderful restaurant.
author: SS G.

description:
Let me start with the positive comments: the food is absolutely incredible! We got the chicken breast kebab, as well as the lamb/beef kebab and the hummus. All were amazing, fresh and delicious.

That being said, it was extremely pricey ($9 hummus...really?) and while the food was quite good, it wasn't THAT much better than a place like Kan Zaman, which has a fun, playful atmosphere and incredible service. Which brings me to my next point...

The service was awful. The host/server we had was rude and short with us from the first moment and we are pretty easy-going diners. They were not at all helpful and were out of all fish and all vegetarian dishes. Not an issue for my fiance and me, but for the other couple we were with, this posed a problem. They ended up bringing them a soggy plate of sauteed zucchini with no apology.

All in all, incredible food but I'd rather go somewhere that I can get just really good food in addition to outstanding service and environment.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
The last time I came here was for my friend's birthday dinner. Overall I had a great time! 

The food is excellent...definitely a meat lovers' dream come true. So far I've only tried two dishes...a chicken dish which was really tasty....and I decided to try a vegetarian eggplant dish which was different but in a good way. I don't really think you can go wrong with any dish you choose here. Since it was my friend's birthday we also requested a special dessert.  The waiter made up his own sampler dessert plate...it was very impressive and was so good nothing was left at the end.

The service was friendly and efficient...they checked on us frequently to make sure we were doing fine. We didn't have to keep calling them over which was surprising since they were super busy.

This place is great for small or large occasions...they seem to handle both very well. The ambiance may seem expensive, but its truly very worth it.
author: Jess B.

description: NOlan, grace and I, along with Manisha and her two boys really enjoyed this.  The food is very flavorable., however the service was not very friendly, despite our children being very polite.    I couldn't get enough of the little dish of spices...put it on nearly everything.  Fantastic.
author: Karen E.

description: Amazing tasty food. I had the zereshk polo which made me feel like Remy the little rat from the film Ratatouille who sees fireworks as he is savoring the flavors of different foods. Probably one of the best restaurants I have been to in a while. I can't wait to go back!
author: Priscilla L.

description:
If you're Iranian and you give Maykadeh 2 stars and Alborz 5 stars you are either not Iranian or you're Alborz's nephew.  

Hands Down, Best Persian Food in the Bay.
author: Sina A.

description:
So mix a Persian restaurant with 4 women, one from Northern VA, one from Westchester NY, one from Colorado Springs, and one from Melbourne AU and what is the consensus - fabulous!

We shared 2 appetizers and 2 entrees, a bottle of wine and desserts. Totally agreed it was all top rate. Only minor criticism was the waiter was not too patient with menu questions. 

I would return, food was so well prepared. I will say I would give this 3 stars for price, not 2, but close enough.
author: Kathleen W.

description: this is unfortunate.  i think on its own, maykedah would deserve 4 stars.  however, with local competition there has to be some separation to identify what's awesome and what's just ok.  the food here is well-cooked, fresh, etc.  our to-go was packed accurately and effectively.  the food simply was not memorable enough for me to crave it.  i will order the same entrees from a certain persian restaurant all the way across town without hesitation, because it triggers that crack-like craving whose itch we all love to scratch.
author: eshwar k.

description: Great spot...everything tasted like it had been slow cooked for two days. Great mix of spices and flavors.  Really enjoyed the meal here.
author: Chris V.

description: This is the best Persian food ever! For appetizer you should get the Kashke and MastoKhier. The Lamb Koobideh and Poussin (baby chicken) are my personal favorites for entrees. So tasty! And if you have someone in the group that just wants a good steak they have an insanely good Ribeye and Filet Mignon with Saffron Fries that would rival any high-end steak restaurant. I love this place. Great wine selection too. I have been going here for years and years and they always deliver a consistently great meal that is great for groups or something more intimate.
author: Alex C.

description: Little intro bout myself im a young iranian/persian man who knows his culture and food like the back of my hand when i want good persian food (other than moms house)I go to Maykadeh they are hands down the best and take the crown in these parts for persian food i go once to twice a week i go so much i know the staff from the owner to the bus boy if your looking for some of the best food in the world (meaning persian food) come check out this little treasure tucked away in North Beach. Jeez typing about this place is making me want to go see you there.
author: Nader F.

description:
Parking around here just sucks, it took us about 30min to find a spot due to the fact that my sister would never valet her baby.(her car that is)

The service good, they are very nice, but it took us about 30min to get our food, that is quite a long wait, by the time our food came we were already full off of bread and water. My sister got the pomegranate/walnut chicken which was way too sweet to our liking and the rice wasn't as fluffy as other persian places we have been. We have a very complex palette when it comes to food, so we are quite picky. 

Overall I don't think I would come back, nothing stood out to me.
author: muhdee h.

description:
This is one of those places that makes me wish there was an option to give 2.5 stars.  Not really two but not quite up to three stars.  The place is decorated nicely and has quite authentic Persian foods but good luck getting there.  Everything people say about the parking pains and service is pretty much true.  Wear comfortable shoes because chances are you're going to trek up a few hills to get back to your car.  You could risk giving it to the shady valet but thats your choice.

Ok, so the parking situation is not their fault so I'm not basing my overall rating on it.  What really bugs me about Maykadeh is that it seems as if they've let their success go to their head.  When I first dined here back in 2003 it was great.  But the food and service has gone down hill.  The food is now mediocre at best and is pretty pricey to boot.

If you're looking for good Persian food in the city, I suggest going to Alborz.  Its a classier setup with better food, better service and reliable parking.
author: Bani S.

description: We had a fabulous dinner here.  I'm not usually a huge fan of eggplant, but the eggplant appetizer was incredible.  As was the feta.  Our meat entrees (baby chicken, lamb, beef) were all flavorful and cooked to perfection.  Top all that off with tasty wine and baklava for dessert, and it was deliciousness all around!  I will definitely be coming back.
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
Let me preface this review that most of the star deduction is based on service rather than food quality and I will address each.

SERVICE:  My girlfriend was running late and they were actually okay with me just sitting down and waiting as the place wasn't that busy.  As soon as I sat down, the waiter was in my face asking for a drink order.  After I told him that water would be fine and I would like to look at the wine list, he appeared snobbish and left.  After I actually had time to _look_ at the wine list, I ordered my glass of wine.  After my date arrived, she then ordered a glass of wine and never got it.  Luckily, they do pour their glasses fairly full so we were able to share.  The food came out so quickly I was wondering if it was pre-made.  After we ate, we waited patiently (about 30 minutes) for the waiter to get back to us.  He was in and out of the restaurant talking to a cab driver.  I didn't understand that at all, but it wasn't just that.  He was serving other tables just fine, just not ours.  We were patient and didn't speak up.  I thought he may be busy, which is fine...but oh wait.  There he goes again, outside to speak to a cab driver.   I didn't know this restaurant did drive-thru.  I gave him a 15% tip.  I'm WAY too nice sometimes.

FOOD:  Granted, I've never had Persian/Iranian food before, but my Fillet Mignon was WAY too dry.  There was no sauce.  The description said it was to be cut in thin slices.  It looked as thought the chef quickly ran his knife, dull edge down, along the top of the well done (I asked for medium) piece of meat.  Fairly unacceptable for $24.  My date's lamb shank with eggplant was very tender, and the sauce was wonderful.  If it weren't for that, this review would have been one star.

CONCLUSION:  I rarely give bad reviews.  You REALLY have to screw up.  I just felt as though I was ignored, served leftovers, and pushed aside for priority service to a drive-thru.  If that were the case, I guess I could have gone to In-N-Out Burger.  I might have gotten a better piece of beef.
author: Chris M.

description: This has become a standby when:  1. one of my best friends from London Natasha is in town and 2. it's SD's bday.  Why?  1.  Pomegranate & vodka 2. Feta & Basil opener 3. Eggplant & Mint Garlic Sauce 4. Crispy rice & Ghorme Sabzee 5. Chicken & Lamb Kebabs and 6.  Khoresht Fesenjoon.  Accessible.  Valet Parking in NORTH BEACH.
author: Natasha S.

description:
Ok, so this review isn't really for the restaurant, but it's for Maykadeh's catering.  They did all the catering for my cousin's wedding last night, and not only was the food good, but these guys busted their ass to make sure everything ran smoothly.  Even the supervisor did his share of work, including serving ice cream, instead of just delegating work to his employees.  
Appetizsers I tried were the Salad Shirazi, Salad Olovieh, Kashk-e-bademjoon, lamb with pepper, chicken kubideh, and mast-o-khiar.  They even made a few dishes that weren't persian, but were good.....like a korean noodle salad. 
Main Courses that I tried were Shirin Polo w/ Chicken, gheymeh, bademjoon, kubideh, and two types of chicken kabab.  The things that stood out for me were the koobideh, green salad (w/ feta cheese), and a salmon dish that I hadn't had before, but it was salmon, spinach, and cheese in a pastry bread.....at least i think it was....but i was drunk by the time the meal was served.  I didn't try the ghorme-sabzi because of the dangerous aftersmell the chambalileh leaves in your pores.  
Only thing that I thing is that they didn't have cream for the coffee they served.  I'm not a coffee drinker, but my gf  had to settle for coffee w/o cream, she did say their coffee served was very good though.  
As far as the desert goes, i'm not big on sweets, especially persian sweets, so I left the faludeh, bastani, and pastries alone. 
Best persian wedding catering I've seen so far, and I've been to a lot of weddings.
author: Ocee D.

description: Very good restaurant to get some fresh, authentic Persian cuisine. Compared to other Persian restaurants, this place tends to be pricier. Its always seems busy, which is a good testament to the quality of the food.
author: Bhakti D.

description: It's a little weird and initially feels out of place, but you'll get used to the high energy trance coming from Maykadeh's stereo. After a glass of wine, it seems to compliment the wonderful Persian flavors coming from the kitchen. Not quite fancy, but still white linens, valet parking at this busy corner in North Beach is a plus.
author: Philip M.

description:
EXCELLENT FOOD & SERVICE. EXCEEDED OUR EXPECTATIONS.
We had a great experience at Maykadeh last month (August 2009). We had a lunch and a dinner.  The variety, quality, quantity and service were more than satisfactory. Prices were on the high side but worth every penny of it. The interior is elegant but a little cramped. Parking was Valet at the time of our visit. There was also some metered street parking.
author: Dar M.

description: The setting of the place is great for friends getting together for a bithday party or something. For the food it was ok, not the greatest persian food, but good to enough. The dessert on the other hand was horrible had vanilla ice cream, infused with something, tasted like lotion. uhhhhgggg!! On the good note, It was still cool to be with friends though.LOL
author: Denis M.

description: Eh. It's alright. Not all that's cracked up to be. Lavash has a nicer atmosphere, and I think the food is a bit bland here.
author: eric a.

description: Ive never seen a middle eastern restaraunt that had valet parking.  It was very convenient as you all know the hells of parking in north beach.  However, it was quite awkward as the valet guy kept moving the car around - I think to put the nicer ones up front.  But it was still awkward.  As for the food - this was a more expensive middle eastern restaurant, something you dont see too often.  The food I thought was very good and the place was nice and crowded.   I still fancy the koobideh which is always my favorite.    Tip: Get a side of the cucumber yogurt sauce and put it on top of EVERYTHING.
author: Tiffany L.

description: I really like their food.  Its the best tasting Persian food in SF and in the Bay.  I really wish there are some hole-in-wall places in SF, anyone know of any?  In LA, there are MANY!!  They all seem to be dine-in white-table cloth places.  For my budget, I really like Rose Market in Mountain View.
author: Demanding T.

description: If you're not persian or have never been to a persian restaurant you might think this place is pretty good. But once you have to compare it to other persian food, you might change your mind. I'm persian and can say that Maykadeh is mediocre persian food, which to some may be enough, but  there are WAY BETTER persian restaurants in the sf area, east bay, and especially south bay. So I'd skip it and go to one of the other places that not only has better food but better value.
author: eastbaygrl o.

description: I love Maykadeh, especially their kabobs.  Excellent service and valet parking in North Beach is great.  I personally prefer Alborz for ghorme sabri and gheymeh.  As a Persian girl who grew up gorging on kabob, I'm picky, and Maykadeh does it well.
author: Noelle Q.

description: First things first, I was totally surprised when I ran into a Persian restaurant in North Beach. The restaurant came highly recommended by a friend so I decided to give it a shot. I was pleasantly surprised. Their kababs are to die for! I tried a "chicken breast" kabab that was served with basmati rice and it was scrumptious, to say the least. Service was so-so, our waiter was a bit standoffish, but overall worth a shot.
author: Matin N.

description:
when a friend, who had a strong craving for "persian food", called and said we were headed out to north beach, my response was "what? why?!" it was cold out, and I really didn't want to look for parking in that area. but i was sold on the "fragrant spices, and buttery saffron rice" description i received. luckily they have valet ($10), and the restaurant was warm and comfortable inside. even though it was late, around 9pm, there were still quite a few diners out and we were seated promptly.

previous to my dining experience here, i just expected something similar to mediterranean/greek food. i ended up really liking the dishes we ordered- the breast kebab was really flavorful, served with the mentioned buttery saffron rice, and the cucumber mint yogurt appetizer which was so good w/the pita bread.

the service was good, our waiter was patient as he described the differences b/t the dishes, and made recommendations as requested. he did not rush us even though we were one of the last diners in the restaurant. most likely i'll return as i'll develop a craving for the "buttery saffron rice" as well.
author: helen l.

description:
This place used to be just expensive, now it is expensive and bad.
I giving two-stars because I have had decent (not great) experiences in the past but my last visit I would say was more like one-star.  
I strongly recommend Lavash or Shalizaar over Maykadeh for persian food.

In our last visit, the chicken kabob seemed to have pesto on it (not even sure where you find that in an iranian kitchen) and the zereshk polo was wet and sweet -- not good.
author: Thomas B.

description: It's pretty good. It can't beat what you get in the South Bay, but since it's the best option in SF, it will have to do.
author: Riz N.

description: Very good place for Iranian food.  My family has been going here for years, and the meals are always delicious, the service friendly and fast.   Right next to Bocce, which is a good place to get drinks before dinner.
author: J T.

description:
The best persian food in San Francisco, East Bay and North Bay area.
Bring your appetiate because the portions are big and you will leave satisfied! Maybe it was the wine messing my head, but the filet kabob was out of this world!
author: Bess T.

description: SHORT & SWEET; Dependably solid Persian cuisine; was once an upscale, intimate dining spot; now, a frenetic and crowded place for locals and party-goers fueling up for a late night; long wait times; limited parking (not their fault, North Beach in general); inconsistent but pleasant service (don't expect drinks to come out quickly); the owner (host) seems to feel that eating at his establishment is akin to winning the lottery; overall, worth a try if you are looking for a quick, relatively inexpensive meal other than Italian in North Beach.
author: Corey S.

description:
It has been a while since i last had Persian food so I was really looking forward eating there. The restaurant is located in residential/ commercial neighborhood so parking is a hassle. I drove around with hope of finding a parking but that effort was futile. Eventually i ended up using their valet service which costs $10. 
the restaurant had nice decor and great sitting arrangements. The host was friendly and seated us right away. Must say reservation is really not necessary there. The menu has tons of lamb, chicken and beef entrees initially making my carnivorous stomach very happy. 
Being clueless as to what lamb entree to eat, i asked the server for recommendation and landed with Shishlek (lamp chops) 
They serve a house appetizer which includes raw onion, mint leave and Feta cheese with bread. I have never eaten raw onion and mint leaves in appetizer but i am not a Persian either. The food was avg. The lamb was mildly spiced, tender and juicy. It was definitely cooked to perfection as it is really easy to over cook lamb. I enjoyed eating the lamb but I didn't eat much of the sides ( veges and rice) as they weren't too flavorful or appealing. Veges had the soogy overcooked look. 
The server forgot about the table after serving food. No follow up on how the food was or if we need any thign else until we were and i had to pay the bill on my way out. Actually the funny thing is they would have let me walk out for free If i hadn't ask for the bill. Yes, the staff really lost it in the end. 
All in all, I found the restaurant pricey.
author: Hasham Y.

description: Went for the second time with a Persian, ordered better stuff and shocker, like it more now.  The eggplant appetizer is amazing and the pomegranate and walnut entree (with halal chicken) was mind blowing.  The beefy kofta like thing was good too, but would have alone kept these guys at the same rating.  The fun Persian music in the background is even better when you are with someone who once it's brought to his attention cringes at how ridiculously bad the lyrics are.  Such fun!
author: Cara J.

description: Yay, Persian food in a convenient location! Maykadeh doesn't quite live up to The Persian Room's (Scottsdale, AZ) standards but is pretty good. Actually I went here because there was a thread on Yelp talk about finding hot Persian girls and someone said they go here. Well, can't vouch for that... hot Persian girls were scarce. Food was good and the restaurant was pretty though. Solid 3 stars!
author: Will A.

description: Great food, great service.  I love coming here.  Definitely get the Soltani if you're hungry.  All the food options are good though.
author: Ava G.

description:
Went there on Saturday, Jan 2 2010, with a group of six.  The food is GREAT, I had Maykadeh Soltani (Skewered thin slices of filet mignon marinated in lime juice and onion), my husband ordered Breast Kebab (Marinated boneless breast of chicken,
in onion, basil, lime juice, vegetables, Basmati rice), filet was good, but chicken breast was to DIE for! Other people ordered lamb and like it a lot too.  Decor is average, service is unnoticeable (food was served very fast, waiters were not us annoying with "how is everything?")  Over all a great experience!  Can't wait to go back.
author: Kristina I.

description:
My favorite Persian restaurant in the bay area!  As an Iranian-American, I always take my non-Iranian friends there to introduce them to Persian food.

The kebabs are extremely well marinated and full of flavor.  You need to order a couple of appetizers to get in the groove before the main course, so I recommend the mast-e-khiar (yogurt with cucumber) and the grilled eggplant.

I always order the kebabs for the main, simply because I already enjoy the stews at home.  The fillet Mignon is delicious.  You can also ask to order family style, and they will bring out different skewers for you to share.

The valet parking is also a huge plus!
author: Armin A.

description:
coming from a persian, this persian food is pretty delicious. the kashk is one of the best i've ever had. 
pretty pricey though!!
author: Samantha S.

description:
Great food, nice ambiance, good service. Free corkage with the "secret yelp password" (although, not sure that was required). We had the Kashke Bademjan and Lamb's tongue (that was a first for all 5 of us). Both were great. I took the waitress's advice and had the lamb shank entree which didn't disappoint. My fiance had the chicken breast kebob and it was tasty as well.

Quite a few hot Persian girls in the restaurant that night too... no complaints. Good times overall.
author: Nithin R.

description: I highly recommend this restaurant, but keep in mind this was the first and only Persian Restaurant I've been to in this city.  I ordered the basic Persian dishes  - hummus for an appetizer and Shirazi salad and 2 different kebobs for the main meal.  Everything was delicious.  The portions are generous and reasonably priced.  The service was fast and friendly.  I liked the ambiance because the linens made it not necessarily casual, but I wouldn't say it's fancy either.  Somewhere in the middle.   I also appreciated the valet parking out front!  I would definitely come here again.
author: Deanna C.

description: Fantastic food! Really great flavors, and very well made. They work well with large groups too.
author: Don H.

description: By far the best persian restaurant in the bay area!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!FINAL!!!!!!!!!!
author: Samira J.

description:
I have eaten here twice with different friends this month, and each time the experience has been good. Both times we ordered the Kashke Bademjan appetizer (eggplant and mint garlic sauce) - yum! Spread it on the warm flat bread they provide with a little bit of the basil that they also provide- it is to die for!  The first time I ordered the Ghorme Sabzee (Lamb shank cooked in finely chopped onion,leek, scallions, chives & herbs, dried lime, Basmati rice) - and the lamb was nice, tender, and did not at all land in your stomach like a rock. And we all know that lamb can be a hit or miss meat. The second time I ordered the Poussin 
(Baby chicken with all the bones marinated in onion, saffron,
lime juice, vegetables and Basmati rice). The lime juice helps keep the chicken moist and tender - so you are not chewing on tough meat. I topped it off with a nice cup of hot Persian tea. The food here is excellent, and I will be a repeat customer when I am in the mood for good Persian food.
author: Annie Y.

description: Came here last night with a friend of mine. This place is my favorite Persian restaurant in the city. I tend to get my usual dishes which are, tahdig (crispy rice with a stew on top), we also got the kashkeh bademjoon (Egg plant dish with onions and bunch other stuff I don't know but my mother does!) My friend loved both appetizers I ordered and asked me to recommend another dish for her. We decided to go family style and have the Pousson (it's an organic hen) and sultani which is a skewer of ground beef and skewer of rib eye filet. The food and wine was great, my date even better. Being from Orange County with a large Persian community and with many great Persian restaurants I have to say Maykadeh is pretty much as good as they are. I will definitely be back.
author: Tony J.

description: I am ashamed it took me a month to write this review because Maykadeh is so delicious!  I've been twice and enjoyed everything I've eaten both times.  Only problem is there's too much good food and enough stomach space for it!  I can't wait to go back again.
author: Susannah R.

description: I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this place. Not only is the food excellent, the service is fantastic, and I checked with a co-worker of mine (who is Persian and lives in San Jose!) asking for a suggestion for a good Persian restaurant and without any prompting or hesitation, he said Maykadeh in SF! YUM!
author: Joyce L.

description: Loved this place. The fesenjoon was delish, as was their warm bread, hummus, feta plate, kebabs & yogurt sauce. mmm good.
author: N A.

description: Very good Persian good for a person who never had Persian food before.  A Persian friend took me here to try out since I was curious about it and it did not disappoint!   I was quite please with the lamb kebab dishes with was pretty darn tasty and for a guy who does not care for eggplant.  They converted me with Kashke Bademjan appetizer which is the eggplant with mint sauce, never had eggplant like that and it was quite delicious.  Service was efficient and prompt and all in all I would go there again even if it is a bit pricey.  Good food can win anyone over.
author: Chris C.

description: The food was pretty authentic and pretty reasonably priced, but the service was absolutely atrocious!  If I didn't have my attention focused on catching up with my friend that was in town, I would have walked out before I even got the chance to taste the food.  It took a whole 15 minutes before someone even came by to take our drink order. Then they forgot to even bring me my drink!  Which is incredible because they sure didn't forget to charge me for it.  Good job fellas.
author: Andrew C.

description: Best Persian outside of Burbank. Finally a place I can get a decent kabob!
author: Britany L.

description: The food was good, but didn't WOW me.  Fairly pleasant atmosphere, but it was a little strange because all the staff was visibly chugging wine whenever they went behind the counter, or back to the kitchen (including the manager on duty).  I guess when I go out to dinner I want to feel that the waitstaff is giving up their evening of fun/drinking to serve ME!  Is that wrong?
author: Pancake ..

description: This is a wonderful place - excellent food, amazing photographs of Iran on the walls, good music, lovely ambiance, great vibe. Lucky to have it in our 'hood. Also, once when I was cooking something that needed sumac (a persian spice) at 8pm, I called them and they actually gave me, gratis, a bunch of this rare and delicious spice. Very cool.  p. s.  ask for the "crunchy rice" - it is a tasty treat!  p.s.s. our dog is named makeda which is amharic-- aka as ethiopian--  for the "queen of sheba" ....  the owners are really gracious and kind-hearted.
author: Victoria Z.

description: nice atmosphere with friendly service.  portions are very generous and i left very satisifed.  i actually prefer this to alborz.
author: Helen T.

description: I have eaten here once, and it was pretty good. I am not necessarily versed in Persian cuisine but it was tasty and the service prompt. The dishes are nice and definitely a departure from your everday cuisine. I would try the eggplant dishes, which were very tasty and vegetarian to boot.
author: Benjamin L.

description: So, my boyfriend's roommate is quite the expert on Persian food, so why not try out the Persian restaurant right around the corner?  Four of us got there with only one other seated table in the restaurant and it quickly filled up while we ate.  Really great appetizers....very tasty entrees....good coursing and service!  We had some really tasty meat and chicken kebabs, and some other main entree that our friend described as "Persian curry."  Awesome.  Very flavorful and very rich...we all needed a little walk uphill and cigarette to end the meal!  Only downside was perhaps the limited beverage list and the eclectic music but....none of us were complaining!  We'll go again, for sure.  And yeah, the expert gave his approval...
author: Emma H.

description:
i come here so often that i think that the hostess always comes by and says 'hi'-- while bringing me a cup of persian tea i always order. in fact i always order the same barg (filet mignon) + joojeh (chicken thighs) + koo bideh (mixture of meats in log-form). why deviate from something so good? 

the heaping plate of rice is perfectly seasoned with saffron-- i recommend sprinkling some of the reddish spice in the white jar. roasted tomatoes are juicy. 

always a default DELICIOUS place to go any time of day. if you desire takeout, they always remember to wrap the onion and basil in with some warm pita. 

persian is a great ethnic twist to 'meat and potatoes/rice'. yum.
author: Melissa H.

description: Good food and friendly service.  Definately on my list of places to return to next time I make it in to SF.
author: Kevin S.

description: Went there last night for a small Graduation party and had a great experience.  Food was perfect.  Meat was extremely tender and delicious (We ordered the Soltani of course).  All appetizers were served very fast and tasted wonderful.   Service was also excellent.  We were treated very well by all the employees.  No wait needed to be seated at around 6pm on a Saturday night.  Even when certain dishes were taking a bit of time to cook, the male employees kept checking on us and not leaving us in the dark waiting.  Prices have gone up since the last I been there but since I eat here only once a year on special occasions, it was well worth it.
author: nima s.

description: The service was a little slow, but the food is amazing and definitely not something to rush through anyway! The Baba Ghanoush appetizer is my favorite (large portion, too). I've tried the Khoresht Bademjan, the Khoresht Fesenjoon, and the Khoresht Ghaymeh entrees and all of them were wonderful.
author: Kate M.

description: if they told me i could only eat one kind of food for the rest of my life, this would be it. maykadeh has been our family's favorite restaurant for years. i've tried many things on their menu, and all of them have deep, satisfying flavor. their kubideh is outstanding, always tender and consistently flavorful and delicious. also love the baby chicken on a skewer, and they have an incredible appetizer of lamb's tongue (never thought i'd like it, but it's absolutely delicious.. tender, with what i believe was either a mustard or curry sauce)... service is always outstanding, and atmosphere is a nice combination of both sophisticated and homey.. love it.
author: Emel M.

description: First time I have had Persian food.  The Kashke Bademjan was delish!  Clean and great staff.  We will return!
author: On C.

description: This place is great for persian food.  Its hard to find some real persian food in the Bay Area, I would think it would be easy, but its not.  This isn't the most amazing persian food, but thats me being biased because I've been to Iran and know what to food tastes like there, but you'll never find true persian food here.  The service is a bit off though, you either get perfect service, or mediocore service, but its worth it no matter what.  Try it out, decide for yourself if you like it or not, I think its worth the money and the drive.
author: Sahra G.

description: Typically, I'd write about what I know, which is Italian and Peruvian food.  But if someone put a gun to my head and asked me to say my third favorite food, I wouldn't hesitate to say Persian.  I've eaten at Maykadeh a few times and haven't been disappointed. The only thing is that I should probably try something else besides the kabobs.  Love the rice!!! Not a fan of the yogurt drink, my own problem.
author: Diego P.

description: I enjoyed it completely.  The food was great--best feta I've ever eaten.  Barley soup was amazing.  Basil accompaniment was super fresh.  Lamb dishes my wife and I both had were cooked to perfection.  Service is slow.  But, I don't like to be rushed.  We went in planning to sit and relax and enjoy the place and this is exactly what happened.  I'd return.
author: Frank M.

description: After having Persian food at different restaurants in LA this place is the best I've had in the Bay Area. It can be busy but it's worth it. The chicken kabob is served with a large amount of rice with saffron. Parking in North Beach can be tricky, suggest trying Grant or Stockton a couple blocks north.
author: k k.

description: This place is great.  They serve yummy food and the restaurant is very clean.  The atmosphere is classy but casual and the service is really good.  The kababs are juicy and delicious.  If you want middle eatern food, this is the place to go in SF.  Just tried their delivery and that was good.  Healthy and tasty....
author: Ali S.

description: I went back to Maykadeh after three years, no I know why I avoided the place for past three years.  The food is way to salty, I had chicken kabob with bone ($20), but I swear, if I wasn't super hungry I would have sent it back. The salt level was unbearable, that was the same experience I had from three years ago.  There were 9 of us there, 8 of us got our food, however the 9th  person  was waiting for 4 minutes.  I finally flagged the waiter down to get his attention that we can't start till everyone got their food.  It is unfortunate since 4 other people in our party that  got chicken had similar experience.  Two people in our party ordered ground beef kabob that were burned ( pitched black) and when we complained instead of simple apology the manager claimed that specific kabob has to be like that otherwise it will be uncooked.  I promise you as 54 year old Persian man I had my fair share of that kabob and the manager was just trying to cover up for a bad execution of the dish.
author: Payman A.

description: The Ghorme Sabzee is excellent.  The tender lamb falls off the bone.  Great flavor.  Prices are reasonable given the quality of the food and the large portions.
author: C A.

description: Been here five times and never been disapointed. The appetizer itself - fresh pita, mint, leaves, onion - is filling and tasty.   Ambience is excellent. Service is generally good.  The safron flavored koobideh kabob is great.  Prices are quite reasonable.  great formula for success.
author: Marco P.

description: Food was quite good. However, we certainly felt rushed. Main course was brought quickly and dropped on table well before appetizer had been finished. As a result table was way crowded and we had to hurry in order to finish appetizer so that main course would not become cold. Check was dropped off with out asking if we were interested in dessert/coffee etc...We felt they just wanted to turn the table. Baklava was extremely dry and I would pass on this. Additionally, in attempting to pay, we were informed the restaurant does not accept AMEX cards. No where was this disclosed up front. What would happen if we had no other form of payment?
author: Denis B.

description: Excellent food and pretty good service. If you know Persian food than most of this is the real thing. The people sure are.
author: Lloyd M.

description:
I went here for the second time last week. The first time we went was a while back (5 years maybe). I remembered the food as being fantastic, a real treat in north beach since I've only had a few meals there that I actually enjoyed (too many tourist traps if you ask me).

The most recent time we went, the food definitely lived up to our expectations. I had a chicken kabob that was well cooked (not dry at all) with some really great vegetables on the side. I also had a cup of great coffee which stood in for one of their deserts (I will say they looked fantastic).

This place is definitely worth a visit!
author: Avid E.

description: Definitely the best Persian food in SF! I love this place!! The zereshk polo and baghali polo (Sunday only) are particularly delicious. The joojeh kabobs are succulent and fantastic. Highly recommended!!
author: L T.

description:
Bad bad bad Persian food.  The rice was dry, and the tahdeek was stale.  The fesenjoon (which is supposed to be a little sweet and a little sour) was plain bitter.  The kashk-bademjahn (whey and eggplant) was not bad, but was so small I felt like I needed another one.  I think the food was prepared days before it was served.  

The waitstaff was lackluster and at times, rude.  

If you want Persian food, try Alborz, or, if you want to travel outside of the city, Shalizar.
author: d v.

description:
We went there for dinner on our day off in the city, as I craving some kabob. Ordered koobideh kabob, which I thought was below average.
Asked the waiter if I could change it to some other dish. The owner came over and gave me hell with his eyes and words for not liking his koobideh. Might I say, he was very rude. 16 years of dinning in bay area have not seen such rude treatment.

Interestingly,  I visited their SJ location for dinner last month; it was closed! the window sign said: " closed for remodeling,  see you soon".  Later I found out it is closed for good due to lack of customer service. Dooh!

In any event, we won't be going back anytime soon, as don't want our evening to be ruined again.
author: P L.

description:
My husband and I are going through the 2008 Zagat book and decided to try Maykadeh for lunch.  It was great.  

I had the Berg and he had the lamb.  Both were superb.  The hummus was also very good.  They do a great job getting the spices absolutely right.  

There was a photo of an iranian town on the wall and the waiter took the time to answer our inquiries about it and pointed out several interesting things about it.

The ambiance was very nice and comfortable.  

Highly recommend.
author: Karen B.

description: Last evening my husband and I had food delivered from Maykadeh.  Unfortunately, the dinners (beef filet kabob and chicken kabob) were overpriced.  The chicken was dry and overcooked.  The black delivery boxes were filled primarily with white rice, then one broiled tomato, part of a broiled onion and a reasonable portion of each protein.  The eggplant/feta cheese appetizer was the only semi-acceptable part of the meal.  It is the first and last time that we will be visiting or ordering from this restaurant in our neighborhood.
author: Marlene W.

description: Decided to go here for lunch with few freinds after I read the reviews. Not a good idea. The so called head server - some Persian guy in his later 20's or early 30's - was too busy being a flirt and the poor waitrresses were doing all the work! The food was cold, the kabobs were burnet and seemed as if were prepared earlier and re-heated. Left with a heavy bill and tottaly emabarassed!!
author: Shawn B.

description: the food is quite good, and the ingredients pretty fresh. Nice place. I even order takeout from here once inawhile through grub hub. First time eating their in person was last night, service was ok, food was good, had a big problem with fruit flies at my table which was a turnoff... my wine was on the table for like 15 minutes and there were four fruit flies swimming in it.. was fighting them off for the rest of the meal.. parking is a bastard in this area-
author: adrian t.

description: great soltani and appetizers, but honestly it is overpriced compared to other Persian places, especially for weekday lunch time. And they didn't allow substituting rice for salad or another type of rice
author: Hamed H.

description: I first went to this restaurant some 20 years ago, in the 80's, with some Persian friends.  My shattered memory tells me that we had a good meal and an enjoyable time.  How disappointed I was on my return!  The atmosphere is still lovely, but the food (compared to other Persian and Middle Eastern restaurants in the Bay Area) is mediocre and the service is atrocious.  We had two servers, both Chinese, whose English was almost unintelligible and one of whom, when asked how to approach the appetizer of onion/feta/basil/radish, said "Eat it."  When we asked the other about ordering the Feta Spread appetizer (thinking it was something spreadable), she said, "it' same as what you have but also tomato."  We ordered a hummus appetizer which was truly unpalatable.  Our entrees, a lamb dish and a chicken dish, were not remarkable although the rice was superb.  It was funny when the server brought out the entrees before the appetizer plates were cleared; she stood staring at the tiny, cluttered table before asking us to hold the entree dishes!  I will try Alborz next and give this a pass in the future.
author: Barbara C.

description:
went for a friends birthday. this place gets lots of hype, but that may be because how many persian places are there in the city? if you want to taste lamb tongue or brain just for the kicks, then totally go. otherwise, service was super slow, and didn't get better until they had their late night cocktails. seriously, they were much better when the place was shutting down. i had the Ghorme Sabzee (lamb) which was drowned in a mystery sauce., but OK. 

the staples are good, like hummus. but then you can't mess up hummus, can you? i will agree the pomengranate martini, their signature drink, is delicious. Too bad they thought they wouldn't be able to make more because they were running out of mint. okay food, inconsistent service, more mint please.
author: eve e.

description: A bit pricey for the small portions they serve. I guess we are used to our Los Angeles Persian Restaurants with the big plates and reasonable prices.  We definitely have had better and tastier Persian kabob's before. And the Shish kabob is usually not 3 pieces on a skewer but rather 8-10. Nice design and flowers and very clean and friendly staff.
author: Sam K.

description: Maykadeh one of few good Middle Easter/Med joints in Bay area. Do yourself a favor and please go here at least once in your lifetime. You will thank me later.
author: Che G.

description: Seriously high quality food.  Parking is convenient with valet and very nice wait service to boot.  I recommend any of the meat kabobs (our party of 5  tried two types of chicken, lamb, and filet).  Rice superb.  Appetizers were interesting - we went for the lamb tongue.  The wine and dessert were really amazing as well, I followed the advice of other reviews and wasn't disappointed.  Highly recommend others trying this place.
author: C Y.

description: We've been customers for almost 20 years now. Walked in yesterday and were seated next to a large party of Russians who brought a few small children with them. Never mind the noise every other patron had to endure from this crowd, their children were given free reign of our corner (by the window) and were more than a nuisance and eventually their balloons ended up in my wife's face. She yet again reminded the kids to stick close to their parents and yet again asked the mother to keep  better watch of her brood. I then chimed in to tell the mother she needs to either take much better care of her kids or simply leave them at home at which he got offended I had the balls to even suggest such a thing. Her husband then got into the the act after 2 of his friends bleeted something in my direction, physical threats were made (not that I was scared in any way, I've seen their ilk plenty before), and as anyone can imagine our family dinner was more than ruined. What is more upsetting than that is that the 2 owners and their wait staff made a quick disappearing act in the kitchen while all of this took place instead of stepping in and doing what's right. In the end, we were presented with a bill and not even an apology of any sort save, ll this while the entire dinner experience was more than bad (save for food, which was good as usual). Can't even give them a one star at this point and can't recommend this place to anyone any longer, this after almost 2 decades of patronizing the place and bringing them lots of new customers and business. Never mind their head waiter was his usual self, filling just my beer glass while not doing the same for my daughter, not placing a small appetizer plate for her, taking my plate as I was still consuming my main course, etc, etc, etc. While I used to overlook such transgressions in years past this last visit coupled with the waiter's disappearing act when he was supposed to be there first and foremost to control things was something that cannot be overlooked. The only reason the place didn't end up looking like a Wild West Saloon is due to me deciding not to escalate things past the point of no return, and no other reason at all, we were there for a family outing. Should we have called the cops and empty out the place? In hind sight, absolutely! No paying patron deserves less service than others and safety is the key importance to anyone, IMO.
author: Greg P.

description: Maykadeh has been fabulous since it opened - ask for the tadiq (a fabulous rice dish, and tachin, this amazing chicken dish, and these divine lambs' tongues in a saffron cream sauce - the whole place is attractive, the owner is a wonderful man; I have hosted many a dinner here and every one of them was a howling success.  Go - you'll love it!
author: Gail M.

description: Excellent food!  A little too pricy though. It is a homey small restaurant in SF with wonderful tasty menu. The bad thing about it is only parking space just like anywhere else in SF you will get lucky to find a space to park your car or you would have to use the valet parking or pricy parking lots.
author: Natalie J.

description: the service here can vary, but the food is solid and authentic:  great persian stews (khoresht), kabobs, and desserts.  they even have some vegetarian options!  the ambiance is definitely odd -- i would say it's more of a friend/family atmosphere than a date place, although i have seen googly eyed couples staring at each other over salad shirazi...
author: G C.

description: been coming here for over 15 years.  great staff and nice place and authentic persian food.  dont like the americanized grilled veggies on the side that they give you now and the fact that they dont offer ground chicken kabob.  the doogh needs salt so i always add it.  rice portions are small.  but hey, this isnt san jose or LA so they can do this.  but importantly it is authentic persian food and delicious.
author: Yelper S.
